analyzed: bhū tala mātram jñāyate na ghaṭaḥ tad abhāvaḥ vā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that only the ground is known, not the pot or its absence.

original: tena yadi bhavānapi ghaṭādijñānābhāvayuktaṃ bhūtalajñānamaṅgīkuryāt tato jñānābhāvāṅgīkartavya ityuktameva /
analyzed: tena yadi bhavān api ghaṭa ādi jñāna abhāva yuktam bhū tala jñānam aṅgīkuryāt tatas jñāna abhāva aṅgīkartavyaḥ iti uktam eva
translated: Therefore, if you also accept the knowledge of the ground as associated with the absence of the knowledge of the pot and so on, then it is said that the absence of knowledge must be accepted.

original: tena naivaṃ bhramitavyam abhāvavādināpi svarūpamātraṃ dṛṣṭvā ca paścātkiñcitsmaraṇannapīti vadatā bhāvajñānātirekeṇa tanmātravedanamaṅgīkṛtam /
analyzed: tena nā evam bhramitavyam abhāva vādinā api svarūpa mātram dṛṣṭvā ca paścāt kiñcid smaraṇat api iti vadatā bhāva jñāna atirekeṇa tanmātra vedanam aṅgīkṛtam
translated: Thus, one should not be deluded in this way. Even the proponent of non-existence, by saying merely seeing the form and then remembering something later, accepts the knowledge of that mere thing in excess of the knowledge of existence.

original: tadeva dṛśye pratiyogini nāstīti vyavahārakāraṇatvānnāstīti śabdasyārthābhāvādbhūtalavedanameva kāraṇamiti vaktavyam /
analyzed: tat eva dṛśye pratiyogini na asti iti vyavahāra kāraṇa tvāt na asti iti śabdasya artha abhāvāt bhū tala vedanam eva kāraṇam iti vaktavyam
translated: That very thing is the cause of the usage it does not exist in the visible counter-correlate. Therefore, the cause must be stated to be the knowledge of the ground itself, due to the meaning of the word non-existence.

original: tataśca ghaṭavatyapi prasaṅga iti sthitaṃ dūṣaṇam ////
analyzed: tatas ca ghaṭavati api prasaṅgaḥ iti sthitam dūṣaṇam
translated: And from that, the established fault is that there would be the same consequence even when there is a pot.

original: atha bhāve deśāntarasthe deśāntaragrahaṇaṃ kāraṇamiti mataṃ /
analyzed: atha bhāve deśa antara sthe deśa antara grahaṇam kāraṇam iti matam
translated: Now, if it is the view that the cause of the usage it does not exist is the apprehension of a place other than the place of the existent,

original: tataḥ śābaleyasthitaṃ gotvaṃ dhāvaleye nāstīti vyavahriyeta /
analyzed: tatas śābaleya sthitam go tvam dhāvaleye na asti iti vyavahriyeta
translated: then the cowness residing in the śābaleya would be used in the dhāvaleya as it does not exist.

original: sthūṇāntarasthitaśca vaṃśaḥ sthūṇāntare 'nusyūto 'pi tatra nāstīti vyavahartavyaḥ syāt /
analyzed: sthūṇā antara sthitaḥ ca vaṃśaḥ sthūṇā antare tatra na asti iti vyavahartavyaḥ syāt
translated: And the bamboo placed between the pillars, though connected between the pillars, would have to be treated as non-existent there.

analyzed: atas tra abhāvaḥ eva na asti iti vyavahāra kāraṇam
translated: Therefore, here the absence itself is the cause of the convention of non-existence,

analyzed: na anyatra sadbhāvaḥ
translated: not the existence elsewhere.

original: smaryamāṇe ghaṭe bhūtalavedanaṃ nāstīti vyavahārakāraṇamiticet / na /
analyzed: smaryamāṇe ghaṭe bhū tala vedanam na asti iti vyavahāra kāraṇam iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that when the pot is remembered, the cognition of the ground is the cause of the convention of non-existence, it is not so.

analyzed: gṛhyamāṇasya api pārśva deśeṣu abhāva vyavahārāt
translated: Because even of what is being grasped, the convention of non-existence is made in the neighboring regions.

original: saṃpratyānītasya ca ghaṭasya gṛhyamāṇasyaiva prāgayamiha nāsīt iti prākkālīnābhāvavyavahārāt //
analyzed: saṃpratyānītasya ca ghaṭasya gṛhyamāṇasya eva prāk ayam iha na āsīt iti prāc kālīna abhāva vyavahārāt
translated: And because of the convention of non-existence prior to the pot that is being brought and is being grasped itself, that this was not here before, it is not so.
The statement of the Prabhakara view.

original: nanu bhavanmate pramīyamānasya ghaṭasya prākkālīnābhāvajñānaṃ bhāvapramāṇabhāvo hyabhāvajñānakāraṇam /
analyzed: nanu bhavat mate pramīyamānasya ghaṭasya prāc kālīna abhāva jñānam bhāva pramāṇa bhāvaḥ hi abhāva jñāna kāraṇam
translated: But in your view, the knowledge of the non-existence of the pot that is being measured is the absence of the means of knowing existence, which is the cause of the knowledge of non-existence.

original: na ca pramāyamāṇo 'pi ghaṭaḥ prākkālasaṃbandhitayā na pramīyate ataḥ prākkālasaṃbandhagocarapramāṇānudayāttatkālīnābhāvajñānaṃ yuktameveti
analyzed: na ca pramāyamāṇaḥ pi ghaṭaḥ prāk kāla saṃbandhi tayā na pramīyate atas prāk kāla saṃbandha gocara pramāṇa anudayāt tad kālīna abhāva jñānam yuktam eva iti
translated: And even though the pot that is being measured is not measured in relation to past time, therefore, because the means of knowing that has the object of the relation to past time does not arise, the knowledge of non-existence at that time is proper.

analyzed: ced na
translated: If this is argued, it is not so.

analyzed: ayogya tvāt
translated: Because it is not suitable.

analyzed: na hi prāc kāla saṃbandhaḥ dhunā pramātum yogyaḥ
translated: For the relation to past time is not suitable to be measured now.

analyzed: yogya pramāṇa abhāvaḥ ca abhāva jñāna kāraṇam na pramāṇa abhāva mātram
translated: And the absence of a suitable means of valid knowledge is the cause of the knowledge of non-existence, not merely the absence of a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: prāc kāle tu yogyasya eva prāmāṇasya anudayaḥ āsīt
translated: But at the previous time, there was only the non-arising of a suitable means of valid knowledge.

original: na hi tadānīṃ ghaṭābhāvaḥ sannapi pramitaḥ pratiyogino ghaṭasyāparāmarśāt tadapekṣatvāccābhāvajñānasya /
analyzed: na hi tadānīm ghaṭa abhāvaḥ san api pramitaḥ pratiyoginaḥ ghaṭasya aparāmarśāt tad apekṣa tvāt ca abhāva jñānasya
translated: For even though the absence of the pot existed at that time, it was not cognized, because the counter-correlate, the pot, was not perceived, and because the knowledge of absence depends on that.

original: ata eva ghaṭābhāvo 'dhunā smaryata iti na yuktam /
analyzed: atas eva ghaṭa abhāvaḥ dhunā smaryate iti na yuktam
translated: For this very reason, it is not correct to say that the absence of the pot is now remembered.

analyzed: apramitasya smaraṇa yogāt
translated: Because what is not cognized cannot be remembered.

original: yaścāyaṃ prākkālīnaḥ pramāṇānudayaḥ so 'dhunā pramāṇodayena naṣṭo nābhāvajñānamutpādayitumarhati /
analyzed: yaḥ ca ayam prāc kālīnaḥ pramāṇa anudayaḥ saḥ dhunā pramāṇa udayena naṣṭaḥ na abhāva jñānam utpādayitum arhati
translated: And that non-arising of means of valid knowledge at the previous time, which is now destroyed by the arising of means of valid knowledge, cannot give rise to the knowledge of non-existence.

original: uddhṛtamiva netraṃ rūpabuddhim ////🔽atha naṣṭo 'pi pramāṇānudayaḥ saṃprati smaryamāṇo hyastanāgnijñānam /
analyzed: uddhṛtam iva netram rūpa buddhim  atha naṣṭaḥ pramāṇa anudayaḥ saṃprati smaryamāṇaḥ hyastana agni jñānam
translated: Like an eye that has been removed cannot produce the cognition of form.🔽Or, even if the non-arising of means of valid knowledge that has ceased is now remembered, like the knowledge of fire from the previous day,

original: syādevaṃ yadi pramāṇābhāvo jñāyamānatayā meyābhāvaṃ bodhayet liṅgamiva liṅginam /
analyzed: syāt evam yadi pramāṇa abhāvaḥ jñāyamāna tayā meya abhāvam bodhayet liṅgam iva liṅginam
translated: it could be so if the absence of means of valid knowledge, when cognized, would bring about the knowledge of the absence of the object to be cognized, just as an inferential mark brings about the knowledge of the thing to be inferred.

original: na ca tathā saṃbhavati anavasthāprasaṅgāt /🔽prameyābhāvaṃ bodhayet jñātavyaḥ /
analyzed: na ca tathā saṃbhavati anavasthā prasaṅgāt  prameya abhāvam bodhayet jñātavyaḥ
translated: But that is not possible, because of the logical fallacy of infinite regress.🔽It would bring about the knowledge of the absence of the object to be cognized.

analyzed: saḥ u pi ca abhāva tvāt anyena abhāva jñānena jñātavyaḥ
translated: And that too, because of being an absence, would have to be cognized by another knowledge of absence.

analyzed: saḥ u pi anyena iti na janma sahasreṇa api ghaṭa abhāvaḥ vadhāryeta
translated: And that also by another, and so on ad infinitum. Thus, even in a thousand births, the absence of the pot could not be ascertained.

analyzed: tasmāt sattā mātreṇa eva pramāṇa abhāvaḥ bhāva jñānam utpādayati netra ādi vat iti aṅgīkartavyam
translated: Therefore, it must be accepted that the absence of a means of valid knowledge produces the knowledge of absence merely by its existence, like the eye and other sense organs.

original: ataḥ pramīyamāṇasya ghaṭasya kathaṃ prākkālābhāvapramitiriti vaktavyam ////
analyzed: atas pramīyamāṇasya ghaṭasya katham prāc kāla abhāva pramitiḥ iti vaktavyam
translated: Hence, it must be explained how there can be ascertainment of the absence of the pot prior to its existence, when the pot is being ascertained.

original: ucyate sattāmātreṇa jñānābhāvo jñāyābhāvaṃ bodhayatīti samyaguktam /
analyzed: ucyate sattā mātreṇa jñāna abhāvaḥ jñāya abhāvam bodhayati iti samyak uktam
translated: It is said that it is rightly stated that the absence of knowledge of an object is produced merely by the existence of the absence of knowledge.

analyzed: asti eva tu adhunā dṛśyamānasya api ghaṭasya
translated: However, even the pot that is now being seen does exist.
But there is no arising of the knowledge capable of apprehending the pot's connection with the prior time.

original: sahi prākkālisaṃbandhitayā smartuṃ yogyaḥ sannapi na smaryate /🔽nacāvaśyaṃpramāṇābāva
analyzed: sa hi prāc kāli saṃbandhi tayā smartum yogyaḥ san api na smaryate  naca avaśyam pramāṇa
translated: Although it is capable of being remembered as connected with the prior time, it is not remembered.🔽And it is not necessarily the case that the absence of a means of valid knowledge

original: evābhāvasya bodhakaḥ smaraṇajñānasyāpi yogyatve satyanudayo bhāvaṃ bodhayatyeva /
analyzed: eva abhāvasya bodhakaḥ smaraṇa jñānasya api yogya tve sati anudayaḥ bhāvam bodhayati eva
translated: alone conveys the absence. Even the non-arising of the knowledge of memory, when it is capable, conveys the existence.

original: tena saṃprati dṛśyamāno 'pi ghaṭo yadi prāgapyāsīttato 'vaśyaṃ tatra sthitena pramitaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tena saṃprati dṛśyamānaḥ pi ghaṭaḥ yadi prāk api āsīt tatas vaśyam tatra sthitena pramitaḥ syāt
translated: Therefore, if the pot that is now being seen existed earlier also, then it would have been necessarily ascertained by one who was present there.

analyzed: pramitaḥ ca adhunā smartavyaḥ syāt
translated: And it would have been remembered now.

original: evaṃ satyapi na smaryate so 'yaṃ smartavyaviṣayasmaraṇānudayaḥ saṃprati vidyamānaḥ saṃpratitanaṃ prākkālīnābhāvaviṣayaṃ vijñānaṃ janayatīti
analyzed: evam sati api na smaryate saḥ yam smartavya viṣaya smaraṇa anudayaḥ saṃprati vidyamānaḥ saṃpratitanam prāc kālīna abhāva viṣayam vijñānam janayati iti
translated: Even so, the non-arising of the memory of the object to be remembered, which exists now, produces the cognition of the non-existence in the past, which has the past as its object.

analyzed: na kiñcid anupapannam
translated: So nothing is illogical.

analyzed: bhāṣye ca pramāṇa abhāva śabdaḥ smaraṇa abhāvasya api upalakṣaṇa arthaḥ
translated: And in the commentary, the word 'absence of means of knowledge' is a synecdoche for the absence of memory.

analyzed: tathā vārtike pi
translated: So also in the Vārttika.

original: yadvā pramāṇasya smaraṇaphalatvāttadabhāvo 'pi phalataḥ pramāṇābāva eveti śakyate vaktum //
analyzed: yat vā pramāṇasya smaraṇa phala tvāt tad abhāvaḥ pi phalataḥ pramāṇa abāvaḥ eva iti śakyate vaktum
translated: Or, it can be said that the absence of that [memory] is, in effect, the absence of the means of knowledge, because the means of knowledge has memory as its result.

analyzed: nanu na sattā mātreṇa yogya anupalabdheḥ abhāva bodhaka tvam yuktam
translated: The objections of Prabhākara have been stated.🔽Now, it is not proper for the non-apprehension of the possible to indicate absence merely by its existence.

analyzed: satyām api tasyām kadācid abhāva buddhi anudayāt
translated: Because even when it exists, the cognition of absence does not arise sometimes.

analyzed: asatyām api kadācid udayāt
translated: And it arises sometimes even when it does not exist.

original: tathāhi yo 'ṅgulīyakabubhutsayā sasantamasāvapavarakadeśaṃ hastābhyāṃ sarvataḥ parāmṛṣṭavān tasya tāvat sarvadeśaparāmarśāt vastuto yogyānupalabdhirjātaiva /
analyzed: tathā hi yaḥ ṅgulīyaka bubhutsayā sa santam asau apavaraka deśam hastābhyām sarvatas parāmṛṣṭavān tasya tāvat sarva deśa parāmarśāt vastutas yogya anupalabdhiḥ jātā eva
translated: To explain: One who, out of a desire to find a ring, has touched all around a dark room with his hands, for him, due to the touching of all places, the non-apprehension of the possible has indeed arisen in reality.

original: atha ca kiṃ sarvo deśaḥ parāmṛṣṭaḥ kiṃ vā kaściddeśo syāditi saṃdihāno yogyānupalabdheraniścayāt satyāpi tasyāṃ nāṅgulīyakasyābhāvamavadhārayati
analyzed: atha ca kim sarvaḥ deśaḥ parāmṛṣṭaḥ kim vā kaścid deśaḥ syāt iti saṃdihānaḥ yogya anupalabdheḥ aniścayāt satyā api tasyām na aṅgulīyakasya abhāvam avadhārayati
translated: Now, does he doubt whether the whole place is touched or only a part of it? Because the non-apprehension of the possible is uncertain, even when it exists, he does not ascertain the absence of the ring.

original: kadācittu sarvato 'parāmṛśyāpi sarvataḥ parāmṛṣṭamiti bhrāntyā yogyānupalabdhiṃ niścityāsatyāmeva tasyāṃ bhrāntyāṅgulīyakasyābhāvamavadhārayati
analyzed: kadācid tu parāmṛśya api sarvatas parāmṛṣṭam iti bhrāntyā yogya anupalabdhim niścitya asatyām eva tasyām bhrāntyā aṅgulīyakasya abhāvam avadhārayati
translated: Sometimes, even though not touched from everywhere, he mistakenly ascertains the non-apprehension of the possible by the mistaken notion that it is touched from everywhere, and mistakenly ascertains the absence of the ring even when it does not exist.

analyzed: tasmāt jñāta tayā eva yogya anupalabdhiḥ abhāva jñāna kāraṇam iti abhyupagantavyam
translated: Therefore, it must be accepted that the non-apprehension of the possible is the cause of the knowledge of absence only through being known.

analyzed: tathā ca anavasthā prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And thus there is the contingence of an infinite regress.

original: tasmātsvasaṃvedyā tanmātrasaṃvideva dṛśyasya pratiyogino 'bhāvo na tatvāntaram / /
analyzed: tasmāt sva saṃvedyā tanmātra saṃvid eva dṛśyasya pratiyoginaḥ bhāvaḥ na tatva antaram
translated: Therefore, the absence of the visible counter-entity is only the cognition of that much, which is self-evident, and not a different entity.

original: nanu cābhāvalaṅgīkāre tanmātradhīrapi na kadācinnirūpayituṃ śakyate /
analyzed: nanu ca abhāva laṅgīkāre tanmātra dhīḥ api na kadācid nirūpayitum śakyate
translated: But if absence is accepted, the cognition of that much cannot be ascertained at any time.

analyzed: na ca bhū tala dhīḥ eva tanmātra dhīḥ
translated: And the cognition of the ground is not the cognition of that much.

analyzed: saṃsṛṣṭa dhiyaḥ api tanmātra tā āpātāt
translated: Because even a mixed cognition would be that much.

analyzed: tatra api bhū tala avabhāsāt
translated: Because even there, the ground appears.

original: ato ghaṭādivedanābhāve sati yā bhūtaladhīḥ sā tanmātradhīḥ /
analyzed: atas ghaṭa ādi vedanā abhāve sati yā bhū tala dhīḥ sā tanmātra dhīḥ
translated: Therefore, when there is the absence of the cognition of the pot etc., the cognition of the ground is the cognition of that much.

analyzed: evam ca jñāna abhāva aṅgīkārāt abhāva apahnavaḥ narthakaḥ
translated: And thus, since the non-existence of knowledge is accepted, the denial of non-existence is pointless.

analyzed: katham tarhi etat nirūpayitavm  tat abhidhīyate ghaṭa ādi abhāvaḥ sti prameyam
translated: How then is this to be determined?🔽It is said that the non-existence of a pot, etc. is an object of knowledge.

original: yogyapramāṇānudayaśca tasya sattāmātreṇaiva netrādivadbodhako na jñātatayā /
analyzed: yogya pramāṇa anudayaḥ ca tasya sattā mātreṇa eva netra ādi vat bodhakaḥ na jñāta tayā
translated: And the non-occurrence of a suitable means of knowledge is the indicator of its existence merely by its presence, like the eye, etc., not by its being known.

analyzed: yatas anavasthā syāt
translated: Because there would be an infinite regress.

original: yattu satyāpi yogyānupalambho hi kāraṇaṃ tatra yogyatvaṃ jñātatayaiva kāraṇaṃ na sattāmātreṇa /
analyzed: yat tu satyā api yogya anupalambhaḥ hi kāraṇam tatra yogya tvam jñāta tayā eva kāraṇam na sattā mātreṇa
translated: But even when the suitable non-apprehension is the cause, the suitability is the cause only by being known, not merely by its existence.

original: tataḥ yogyatvaṃ kadācidajñātaṃ nābhāvamavadhārayati kadācittvavidyamānameva yogyatvaṃ bhrāntyā niścityābhāvamavadhārayati /
analyzed: tatas yogya tvam kadācid ajñātam na abhāvam avadhārayati kadācid tu avidyamānam eva yogya tvam bhrāntyā niścitya abhāvam avadhārayati
translated: Therefore, suitability sometimes does not determine non-existence when unknown, but sometimes it determines non-existence by ascertaining the non-existent suitability through error.

original: upalabdhyabhāvastu sanmātratayā kāraṇaṃ na jñātatayā /🔽tena nānavasthāpattiriti sarvamavadātam /
analyzed: upalabdhi abhāvaḥ tu sat mātra tayā kāraṇam na jñāta tayā  tena na anavasthā āpattiḥ iti sarvam avadātam
translated: But the absence of apprehension is the cause merely by its existence, not by its being known.🔽Therefore, there is no infinite regress. Thus everything is clear.

analyzed: atas sti abhāva ākhyam prameyam
translated: Therefore, there is an object of knowledge called non-existence.

analyzed: abhāvasya anupalabdhi gamya tvam
translated: Non-existence is to be known by non-apprehension.

analyzed: na ca tat aindriyakam
translated: And it is not perceptible.

analyzed: indriya vyāpāra abhāve pi tad jñāna utpatti darśanāt
translated: Because its knowledge arises even in the absence of the operation of the sense organs.

original: yo 'hani prātaḥkāle gṛhe 'vasthito madhyandinasamaye pṛcchyate kimasmingṛhe prātaḥkāle
analyzed: yaḥ hani prātaḥkāle gṛhe vasthitaḥ madhyandina samaye pṛcchyate kim asmin gṛhe prātaḥkāle
translated: He who is in the house in the morning and is asked at midday whether

original: māthuraḥ kiścitpuruṣaḥ śuklavāsā dīrghatamo lohitavarṇaḥ samāgataḥ iti sa tadānīmeva
analyzed: māthuraḥ kiścid puruṣaḥ śukla vāsāḥ dīrghatamaḥ lohita varṇaḥ samāgataḥ iti sa tadānīm eva
translated: a certain person, a Māthura, wearing white clothes, tall, red-complexioned, came to the house in the morning, he at that very moment

analyzed: yogya smaraṇa anudayāt tasya abhāvam prātar kālīnam avadhārayati vinā eva indriya vyāpāreṇa
translated: determines the non-existence in the morning, without any operation of the sense organs, because the recollection of what is possible does not arise.

original: na ca prātaravagato 'bāvastadā smaryata iti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca prātar avagataḥ bāvaḥ tadā smaryate iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that the non-existence perceived in the morning is remembered at that time.

analyzed: pratiyoginaḥ māthurasya tadānīm kathañcid api buddhau anārohāt
translated: Because the opponent, the Māthura, is not at all brought to mind at that time.

analyzed: a buddhi sthe ca pratiyogini bhāve tad abhāva jñāna saṃbhavāt
translated: And when the opponent is not present in the mind, the knowledge of its non-existence is not possible.

analyzed: evam ca yatra api idānīm eva anuparata indriya vyāpāreṇa saṃnihita deśa kāla vartti abhāvaḥ pratīyate
translated: And in this way, where the non-existence occurring in the present time and place is cognized by the operation of the sense organs that has not yet ceased,

original: tatrāpi yogyajñānānudayasyaiva kḷptasāmarthyasya kāraṇatvasaṃbhavānnendriyasya kāraṇatvaṃ kalpayituṃ śakyam /
analyzed: tatra api yogya jñāna anudayasya eva kḷpta sāmarthyasya kāraṇa tva saṃbhavāt na indriyasya kāraṇa tvam kalpayitum śakyam
translated: there also, because the non-arising of the knowledge of what is possible, whose capacity is established, is possible as the cause, it is not possible to imagine that the sense organ is the cause.

analyzed: tasmāt na pratyakṣaḥ bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, non-existence is not perceived.

analyzed: na api anumeyaḥ
translated: Nor is it inferable.

analyzed: ajñātena tena kasyacid liṅgasya saṃbandha grahaṇa saṃbhavāt
translated: Because it is unknown, it is not possible to grasp the relation of any mark with it.

original: yadatra kaiściducyate dṛśyasya sattādarśanavyāptā tena🔽vyāpakībhūtadarśananivṛttyā vyāpyasya dṛśyasya nivṛttiravasīyata iti tannirastam /
analyzed: yat atra kaiścid ucyate dṛśyasya sattā darśana vyāptā tena  vyāpakībhūta darśana nivṛttyā vyāpyasya dṛśyasya nivṛttiḥ avasīyate iti tat nirastam
translated: What some say here, that the existence of the visible is pervaded by the perception of existence,🔽by the cessation of the pervader, the perception, the cessation of the pervaded, the visible, is concluded, that is refuted.

original: vyāpakanivṛttyā vyāpyanivṛttimanumimānenāvaśyaṃ dṛṣṭāntadharmiṣu nivṛttidvayamavagamya tato dṛśyanivṛttiranumātavyā /
analyzed: vyāpaka nivṛttyā vyāpya nivṛttim anumimānena avaśyam dṛṣṭānta dharmiṣu nivṛtti dvayam avagamya tatas dṛśya nivṛttiḥ anumātavyā
translated: By one who infers the cessation of the pervaded by the cessation of the pervader, the cessation of both is necessarily understood in the example-subject, and from that the cessation of the visible is to be inferred.

analyzed: nivṛtteḥ ca abhāva ātmikayai na pratyakṣeṇa grahaṇam saṃbhavati
translated: And the cessation, which is of the nature of non-existence, cannot be grasped by perception.

original: nivṛttyantareṇa tadanumāne tadapi nivṛttirūpatvānnivṛttyantareṇānumātavyam tadapi tathetyanavasthāpattiḥ /
analyzed: nivṛtti antareṇa tad anumāne tat api nivṛtti rūpa tvāt nivṛtti antareṇa anumātavyam tat api tathā iti anavasthā āpattiḥ
translated: If that is inferred by another cessation, that too, being of the nature of cessation, must be inferred by another cessation. That too is like that, so there is the fault of infinite regress.

analyzed: atas vaśyam kvacid pramāṇa antara bhūtayā anupalabdhyā abhāvaḥ pratyetavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, somewhere the non-existence must necessarily be understood by non-apprehension, which is a different means of knowledge.

analyzed: pramite ca tasmin paścāt bhavatu anumānam
translated: And after that is ascertained, let there be inference.

original: siddhaṃ tāvadabhāvasya pramāṇāntaratvaṃ śabdopamānārthāpattayastu nāśaṅganīyā eva /
analyzed: siddham tāvat abhāvasya pramāṇa antara tvam śabda upamāna artha āpattayaḥ tu na āśaṅganīyāḥ eva
translated: The fact that non-existence is a different means of knowledge is established. But verbal testimony, analogy, and presumption are not even to be suspected.

analyzed: atas siddham ṣaṣṭham pramāṇam
translated: Therefore, the sixth means of valid knowledge is established.

analyzed: etāvanti eva ca pramāṇāni
translated: And there are only these many means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: yat tu adhikam saṃbhava ākhyam pramāṇam sahasra ādi saṃkhyayā avayava bhūta śata ādi saṃkhyā avagatiḥ āḍhaka pramāṇena avayava kuḍava parimāṇa avagatiḥ kaiścid iṣyate
translated: As for the means of valid knowledge called 'adhikam' (more), by which the number of parts such as hundred is understood by the number such as thousand, and the measure of the part kudava is understood by the measure of adhaka, it is accepted by some.

analyzed: tad avinābhāva nimitta tvāt anumānam eva
translated: That is inference itself, because it is based on the invariable concomitance.

original: vaṭevaṭe vaiśravaṇaḥ ityādikaṃ caitihyaṃ pramāṇameva na bhavati nirṇayābhāvāt /🔽prāmāṇyepi vā'game 'ntargatatvānna pramāṇāntaram /
analyzed: vaṭevaṭe vaiśravaṇaḥ iti ādikam caitihyam pramāṇam eva na bhavati nirṇaya abhāvāt  prāmāṇye api vā āgame ntargata tvāt na pramāṇa antaram
translated: And the statement Vaiśravaṇa is in every banyan tree etc. is not a means of valid knowledge at all, because there is no certainty.🔽Even if it is a means of valid knowledge, it is not a separate means of valid knowledge because it is included in the scriptures.

analyzed: prātibhākhyam api pramāṇam kaiścid iṣṭam śvas te bhrātā āgantā iti ādikam
translated: Some accept the means of valid knowledge called 'prātibhā' (intuition), such as Your brother will come tomorrow.

analyzed: tat tu liṅga ādi ābhāsa jam
translated: But that arises from the semblance of an inferential mark etc.

analyzed: aniścāyaka tvāt eva apramāṇam
translated: It is not a means of valid knowledge because it does not bring about certainty.

analyzed: atas yat kāśyapīyaiḥ pratibhā agamyam ṛṣīṇām dharma adharma tvam āśritam tat asāram
translated: Therefore, the view of the Kāśyapīyas that the dharma and adharma of the sages are known by intuition is worthless.

analyzed: loka prasiddhiḥ api pratyakṣa antargatā eva iti na pramāṇa antaram
translated: And the popular belief is also included in perception itself, so it is not a separate means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: atas ṣaḍ eva pramāṇāni
translated: Therefore, there are only six means of valid knowledge.

original: tathā ca bhagavadrāmāyaṇe rāma ṣaḍyuktayo loke yābhiḥ sarvo 'nudṛśyate iti /
analyzed: tathā ca bhagavat rāmāyaṇe rāma ṣaḍ yuktayaḥ loke yābhiḥ sarvaḥ nu dṛśyate iti
translated: And so in the Blessed Ramayana, Rama, the six methods in the world by which everything is seen.

analyzed: iti ābhāva vādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the doctrine of non-existence.

analyzed: citra ādi aihika phala codanāsu ākṣepaḥ
translated: Objection to the injunctions of pictures etc. having this-worldly fruits.

original: lokaprasiddhasvataḥprāmāṇyadarśanena pratyakṣādīnāṃ tadantargatasyāpi ca śāstrasya svataḥprāmāṇyāt codanālakṣaṇor'tho dharmaḥ
analyzed: loka prasiddha svatas prāmāṇya darśanena pratyakṣa ādīnām tad antargatasya api ca śāstrasya svatas prāmāṇyāt codanā lakṣaṇa ūrthaḥ dharmaḥ
translated: Since perception etc. and even the scripture included within it have self-validity by the view of self-validity well-known in the world, the meaning characterized by injunction is dharma.

original: iti pratijñāter'the sādhite saṃprati animittaṃ vidyamānopalambhanatvāt ityanena citrādicodanānāmaihikaphalānāṃ pratyakṣādibhirasaṃvādena visaṃvādena 🔽ca prāmāṇyamākṣipyate /🔽pūrvoktastu nanvatathābhūtaṃ ityākṣepaḥ paralokaphalasvargakāmādicodanāviṣaya iti viṣayabhedādapaunaruktyam ////🔽nanu ca nanvatathābhūtamapyarthaṃ brūyāccodaneti codanāmātraparigrahādaviśeṣeṇaivāsāvākṣepaḥ tathehāpi yadā tāvadasau vidyamānāsīt tadā phalaṃ
analyzed: iti pratijñāta irthe sādhite saṃprati animittam vidyamāna upalambhana tvāt iti anena citra ādi codanānām aihika phalānām pratyakṣa ādibhiḥ asaṃvādena visaṃvādena  ca prāmāṇyam ākṣipyate  pūrva uktaḥ tu nanu atathābhūtam iti ākṣepaḥ para loka phala svarga kāma ādi codanā viṣayaḥ iti viṣaya bhedāt apaunaruktyam  nanu ca nanu atathābhūtam api artham brūyāt codanā iti codanā mātra parigrahāt aviśeṣeṇa eva asau ākṣepaḥ tathā iha api yadā tāvat asau vidyamānā āsīt tadā phalam
translated: When the proposition is established, now the validity of the injunctions of pictures etc. having this-worldly fruits is objected to by the reason because of the apprehension of the existent, by the non-accord and contradiction with perception etc.🔽The previous objection But it is not so is with regard to the injunctions having heaven etc. as the other-worldly fruits, so there is no repetition due to the difference in the subject-matter.

analyzed: na dattavatī
translated: But the objection is in general by the inclusion of mere injunctions, saying The injunction may speak of an object which is not so, so here also when it existed, it did not give the fruit.

original: yadā phalamutpadyate tadāsau nāsti kathamasatī phalaṃ dāsyatītyākṣepasya svargakāmacodanāsvapi tulyatvādaviśeṣatvamiti nāsti viṣayabhedaḥ /
analyzed: yadā phalam utpadyate tadā asau na asti katham asatī phalam dāsyati iti ākṣepasya svarga kāma codanāsu api tulya tvāt aviśeṣa tvam iti na asti viṣaya bhedaḥ
translated: When the result is produced, it does not exist. How can a non-existent give a result? This objection is equally applicable to injunctions for heaven-seeking, so there is no difference. Thus there is no difference in the subject matter.

original: ucyate pūrvākṣepastāvatparalokaphalaviṣaya eva /🔽tatra hi pramāṇāntarāpekṣaḥ śabdo na svātantryeṇa pramāṇam /
analyzed: ucyate pūrva ākṣepaḥ tāvat paraloka phala viṣayaḥ eva  tatra hi pramāṇa antara apekṣaḥ śabdaḥ na svātantryeṇa pramāṇam
translated: It is said: First, the objection is only about the result in the next world.🔽There, the word depends on another means of knowledge and is not a means of knowledge by itself.

original: na ca codanārthe pramāṇāntaramasti ato 'pramāṇaṃ codanetyayamākṣepaḥ /
analyzed: na ca codanā arthe pramāṇa antaram asti pramāṇam codanā iti ayam ākṣepaḥ
translated: And there is no other means of knowledge for the meaning of the injunction, therefore this objection is that the injunction is not a means of knowledge.

analyzed: sa ca ayam para loka phala viṣayaḥ eva bhavati
translated: And this is only about the result in the next world.

original: paśukāmacodanāsu hi yadi tāvatkarmānantarameva paśvādīnyupalabhyante tato 'pekṣitamūlapramāṇalābhātsiddhyati codanāyāḥ prāmāṇyam /
analyzed: paśu kāma codanāsu hi yadi tāvat karma anantaram eva paśu ādīni upalabhyante tatas u pekṣita mūlapramāṇa lābhāt siddhi ati codanāyāḥ prāmāṇyam
translated: In the injunctions for one desiring cattle, if cattle etc. are perceived immediately after the action, then the authority of the injunction is established by obtaining the required basic means of knowledge.

original: atha nopalabhyate tataḥ pramāṇāntarabādhenaiva sukhaprāmāṇyamabhidhātuṃ śakyata iti kimākṣepasārūpyapratipādanavyasanena /🔽tasmātsa tāvatparalokaphalaviṣaya eva /
analyzed: atha nā upalabhyate tatas pramāṇa antara bādhena eva sukha prāmāṇyam abhidhātum śakyate iti kim ākṣepa sārūpya pratipādana vyasanena  tasmāt sa tāvat para loka phala viṣayaḥ eva
translated: If not perceived, then the authority of the injunction can be refuted only by another means of knowledge. So what is the use of establishing the similarity of the objection?🔽Therefore, that objection is only about the result in the next world.

analyzed: ayam tu aihika phala viṣaya
translated: But this one is about the result in this world.

original: na hi pāralaukikasya phalasyānantarakālānupalabdhyā nirāsaḥ saṃbhavati /
analyzed: na hi pāralaukikasya phalasya anantara kāla anupalabdhyā nirāsaḥ saṃbhavati
translated: For it is not possible to deny the existence of a transcendental result merely on the ground of its not being perceived immediately after the act.

analyzed: na hi tena anantaram bhavitavyam
translated: For it is not necessary that it should come immediately after the act.

analyzed: janma antara bhāvita tvāt
translated: Because it is produced in a subsequent birth.

original: nanu asatī kathaṃ phalaṃ dāsyatītīdaṃ tulyam /
analyzed: nanu asatī katham phalam dāsyati iti idam tulyam
translated: But how can a non-existent thing produce a result? This is equally applicable to the case of the transcendental result.

analyzed: na iti brūmaḥ apūrva dvāreṇa saṃbhavāt
translated: We say no, because it is possible through an unseen potency.

original: svargo hi svabhāvāddehāntarānubhavanīyatvādanantarāsaṃbhavitvena śāstrārthāvadhāraṇavelāyāmeva kālāntare niścīyata ityapūrvamantarbhāvyaiva
analyzed: svargaḥ hi svabhāvāt deha antara anubhavanīya tvāt anantara asaṃbhavi tvena śāstra artha avadhāraṇa velāyām eva kāla antare niścīyate iti apūrvam antar bhāvyā eva
translated: For heaven, being by nature to be experienced in another body, is ascertained at the time of determining the meaning of the scripture itself as occurring at some future time, not immediately. Thus the unseen potency is implied in it.

analyzed: tatra śāstra arthaḥ vadhāryate
translated: And the meaning of the scripture is ascertained in that way.

original: tacca cirasthāyīti kāraṇasyāvināśātsaṃbhavati kālāntare svargasyotpattiḥ /🔽paścādayastvanantaramapi saṃbhavantīti tatsādhanatvena codyamānānāṃ citrādīnāṃ śāstrārthāvadhāraṇasamaye
analyzed: tat ca cira sthāyi iti kāraṇasya avināśāt saṃbhavati kāla antare svargasya utpattiḥ  paścādayaḥ tu anantaram api saṃbhavanti iti tad sādhana tvena codyamānānām citra ādīnām śāstra artha avadhāraṇa samaye
translated: And that being a long-lasting entity, the production of heaven at some future time is possible due to the non-destruction of the cause.🔽But the other things like painting, etc., being possible even immediately after, when enjoined as means to that [heaven],

original: 'pūrvapraṇāḍīsamāśrayaṇe kāraṇaṃ na kiñcidastīti svarūpeṇaiva phalasādhanatvaṃ śāstrārtho 'vadhāryate /
analyzed: pūrva praṇāḍī samāśrayaṇe kāraṇam na kiñcid asti iti svarūpeṇa eva phala sādhanatvam śāstra arthaḥ vadhāryate
translated: there is no reason for them to depend on the unseen potency as a connecting link at the time of determining the meaning of the scripture. Thus the meaning of the scripture is ascertained as the means to the result in their own form.

analyzed: tathā ca anantaram eva palena
translated: And so the result must follow immediately.

analyzed: kāla antare karma svarūpasya vinaṣṭa tvāt kāraṇa tva abhāvāt
translated: Because at a later time, the form of the action having been destroyed, there is no causal relation.

analyzed: anantaram ca phalam anupalabdhyā eva nirastam iti aprāmāṇyam citra ādi codanānām
translated: And the result following immediately is refuted by non-apprehension itself. Therefore the injunctions regarding pictures etc. are not valid.

analyzed: citra ādi codanāsu ākṣepa parihārau
translated: The objection and reply regarding the injunctions of pictures etc.

original: nacānuṣṭhānānantaraṃ phalānupalabdhyaiva śāstrārthe 'pūrvamantarbhāvayituṃ śakyate śāstrārthāvadhāraṇapūrvakaṃ hyanuṣṭhānaṃ nānuṣṭhānapūrvakaṃ
analyzed: na ca anuṣṭhāna anantaram phala anupalabdhyā eva śāstra arthe pūrvam antarbhāvayitum śakyate śāstra artha avadhāraṇa pūrvakam hi anuṣṭhānam na anuṣṭhāna pūrvakam
translated: And the result of an action cannot be inferred merely from the non-apprehension of the result after the performance of the action, because the performance of an action is preceded by the ascertainment of the purpose of the scripture, not the other way around.

analyzed: tasmāt aihikānām atra ākṣepaḥ iti yuktaḥ viṣaya bhedaḥ
translated: Therefore, it is proper to distinguish the subject-matter of injunctions of actions producing results in this life and those producing results in the next life.

analyzed: viṣaya bhedāt ca nyāyaḥ api bhidyate
translated: And because of the difference in subject-matter, the reasoning also differs.

analyzed: para loka phalāsu pramāṇa apekṣita tvām ākṣepa nyāyaḥ
translated: In the case of injunctions producing results in the next life, the reasoning is based on the requirement of valid knowledge.

original: atratu pramāṇāntaravirodha iti nyāyabhedādapaunaruktyam /🔽athavā pūrvoktaṃ svamate sūtrāṇi vyācakṣaṇo sūtritamevākṣepaṃ darśitavān /
analyzed: atra tu pramāṇa antara virodhaḥ iti nyāya bhedāt apaunaruktyam  athavā pūrvoktam sva mate sūtrāṇi sūtritam eva ākṣepam darśitavān
translated: But here, the reasoning is based on the contradiction with another means of knowledge. Thus, there is no repetition due to the difference in reasoning.🔽Or, while explaining the sūtras according to his own view, he has shown the objection as stated in the sūtra.

analyzed: idānīm tu vṛtti kāra matena sūtreṇa eva ākṣepaḥ kriyate
translated: Now, the objection is raised by the sūtra itself according to the view of the commentator.

analyzed: tat iha
translated: That is here.

analyzed: citra ādi vākyāni pramāṇāni apramāṇāni vā iti vicāryate
translated: It is being considered whether statements about paintings etc. are valid or not.

original: tadarthaṃ ca kiṃ teṣāṃ pramāṇāntaravirodho 'sti na veti /
analyzed: tad artham ca kim teṣām pramāṇa antara virodhaḥ sti na vā iti
translated: And for that purpose, whether they are contradicted by other means of knowledge or not.

analyzed: tatra phalānām anantaram upalabdhavyānām anupalambhāt atatsādhanatvam citra ādīnām avagamyate
translated: There, the non-perception of the effects that are to be perceived immediately after is understood to be not their means of accomplishment.

analyzed: tat idam pratyakṣa avisaṃvāde vaśyaṃbhāvini sati tad abhāvāt aprāmāṇyam
translated: This is invalidity due to the absence of that, when there is necessarily non-contradiction with perception.

original: kvacittu pratyakṣavirodhādapramāṇyaṃ sa eṣa yajñāyudhī yajamāno 'ñjasā svargaṃ yātīti yajñāyudhīti hi yajñāyudhasaṃyogāccharīramucyate /
analyzed: kvacid tu pratyakṣa virodhāt apramāṇyam saḥ eṣa yajñāyudhī yajamānaḥ ñjasā svargam yāti iti yajñāyudhī iti hi yajñāyudha saṃyogāt śarīram ucyate
translated: But in some cases, invalidity is due to contradiction with perception, as in This sacrificer with sacrificial implements goes to heaven directly. For sacrificer with sacrificial implements refers to the body due to the connection with sacrificial implements.

analyzed: yajamāna śabdaḥ api hi kartṛ vacanaḥ tasya eva vācakaḥ na ātmanaḥ
translated: And the word sacrificer also denotes the agent, and refers to him alone, not to the self.

analyzed: tasya sarvagata tvena abhimatasya kriyaḥ virahiṇaḥ kartṛ tva ayogāt yajñāyudha saṃyoga abhāvāt ca
translated: Because the self, which is considered to be all-pervading and devoid of action, cannot be an agent, and also because there is no connection with sacrificial implements.

analyzed: saṃyoga abhiprāyaḥ ca ayam yajñāyudhi iti śabdaḥ pātra cayana stuti artha tvāt
translated: And this word sacrificer with sacrificial implements is intended to refer to the connection, because it is for the purpose of praising the selection of the vessel.

analyzed: na sva svāmi saṃbandha abhiprāyaḥ
translated: It is not intended to refer to the relation between master and servant.

original: prāgapi pātracayanāttatsaṃbhavāt śarīrasya ca pratyakṣaviruddhaṃ svargamanam /
analyzed: prāk api pātra cayanāt tad saṃbhavāt śarīrasya ca pratyakṣa viruddham svar gamanam
translated: Even before the collection of the sacrificial vessels, because that is possible, and because the going to heaven is contrary to perception.

analyzed: na ca kāla antare pi saṃbhavati
translated: And it is not possible even at a later time.

analyzed: yāti iti vartamāna apadeśāt
translated: Because of the statement in the present tense he goes.

analyzed: bhasmībhūtasya ca kāla antare pi tad asaṃbhavāt
translated: And because it is impossible even at a later time for one who has become ashes.

analyzed: na ca śarīra vyatiriktaḥ kaścid ātmā asti tasmāt apramāṇam
translated: And there is no self apart from the body. Therefore it is not a valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: evam apauruṣeyasya api aprāmāṇye svarga kāma codanāyām api nā āśvasitum yuktam iti apramāṇyam eva āyātam
translated: Thus, if even that which is not of human origin is invalid, it is not proper to rely on the injunction one who desires heaven should offer the agnihotra either. Thus invalidity has come.

original: evaṃ pratyakṣānupalabdhivirodhena pratyakṣavirodhena cākṣipte prāmāṇye virodhaparihāramupekṣyaiva
analyzed: evam pratyakṣa anupalabdhi virodhena pratyakṣa virodhena ca ākṣipte prāmāṇye virodha parihāram upekṣya eva
translated: Thus, when validity is refuted by the non-apprehension of perception and by the contradiction of perception, the proponent of the conclusion, disregarding the resolution of the contradiction,

analyzed: kāraṇa doṣa nirākaraṇena pūrvoktam eva svatas prāmāṇyam sva pakṣa sādhana tvena siddhāntavādī
translated: shows the same self-validity stated earlier by the removal of the faults of the cause, as the proof of his own position,

original: darśayati autpattikastu śabdasyārthena saṃbandhastasya jñānamupadeśa iti /
analyzed: darśayati autpattikaḥ tu śabdasya arthena saṃbandhaḥ tasya jñānam upadeśaḥ iti
translated: saying But the relation of the word with the object is innate, and the knowledge of that is instruction.

original: pūrvaṃ hi pratyakṣādīnāṃ svataḥprāmāṇyasya lokasiddhātvāttadantargatatvācca śāstramapi puruṣānupraveśābhāvātpuruṣāśrayatvācca śabdadoṣasyāduṣṭemeva
analyzed: pūrvam hi pratyakṣa ādīnām svatas prāmāṇyasya loka siddhātvāt tad antargata tvāt ca śāstram api puruṣa anupraveśa abhāvāt puruṣa āśraya tvāt ca śabda doṣasya
translated: For, firstly, the self-validity of perception etc. is well-established in the world, and since the scriptures are included within them, the scriptures are also valid. And because the scriptures are not dependent on human beings, and because the faults of words are dependent on human beings, the scriptures are indeed faultless.

analyzed: śāstram atas pramāṇam iti uktam
translated: Therefore, the scriptures are valid.

analyzed: iti citra ākṣepa vādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the argument of Citrā.

analyzed: śabda arthayoḥ saṃbandha ākṣepaḥ
translated: The objection to the relation between word and meaning.

analyzed: evam saṃbandha nitya tayā aprāmāṇyam nirākṛtya svatas prāmāṇye sthāpite
translated: Thus, having refuted the invalidity due to the eternality of the relation, and having established self-validity,

original: paraḥ punarāha syādetat naiva śabdasyārthenāsti saṃbandhaḥ kuto 'sya pauruṣeyatāpauruṣeyatāveti /
analyzed: paraḥ punar āha syāt etat na eva śabdasya arthena asti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: the opponent says again: This may be so, but there is no relation between the word and its meaning at all. How then can it be either human or non-human?

original: tathāhi na tāvatsaṃyogo 'sti tadbhāve hi kṣurādiśabdoccāraṇe mukhyasya pāṭanāpi syāt /
analyzed: tathā hi na tāvat saṃyogaḥ sti tad bhāve hi kṣura ādi śabda uccāraṇe mukhyasya pāṭanā api syāt
translated: To explain: First of all, there is no conjunction, for if it existed, there would be actual cutting even when words like 'razor' are uttered.

analyzed: na ca kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ
translated: Nor is there the relation of cause and effect.

analyzed: dvayoḥ api nitya tvāt
translated: Because both are eternal.

original: nanu varṇasphoṭajātyādivikalpena vyaktyākṛtisaṃbandhādivikalpena ca bāhyayoḥ śabdārthayordurnirūpatvādgakārādyākāraṃ vijñānameva śabdaḥ /
analyzed: nanu varṇa sphoṭa jāti ādi vikalpena vyakti ākṛti saṃbandha ādi vikalpena ca bāhyayoḥ śabda arthayoḥ durnirūpa tvāt gakāra ādi ākāram vijñānam eva śabdaḥ
translated: But because external words and meanings are difficult to determine due to the alternatives of letters, sphoṭa, universals, etc., and the alternatives of the relation of individual and configuration, etc., the cognition itself in the form of the letter 'ga' is the word.

original: tajjanitaṃ ca gavādyākāravijñānamevārthaṃ iti kāryakāraṇatvameva śabdārthayoḥ saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: tad janitam ca gavādi ākāra vijñānam eva artham iti kārya kāraṇa tvam eva śabda arthayoḥ saṃbandhaḥ
translated: And the cognition produced by that, having the form of a cow etc., is itself the object. Thus, the relation between word and meaning is just that of cause and effect.

analyzed: na evam
translated: It is not so.

analyzed: nirālambana jñāna anutpatteḥ
translated: Because cognition without an object does not arise.

analyzed: saṃbandha antaram tu na āśaṅganīyam eva
translated: But another relation need not be suspected at all.

analyzed: pratyāyya pratyāyaka tvam saṃbandhaḥ iti
translated: If it is argued that the relation is that of the word being the indicator and the meaning being the object indicated,

analyzed: ced na
translated: that is not so.

analyzed: asati saṃbandhe pratyāyaka tva asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because without a relation, the word's being an indicator is not possible.

original: kena saṃbandhena śabdor'thaṃ pratyāyayatītyetadeva hi nirūpyate /
analyzed: kena saṃbandhena śabdaḥ ṛtham pratyāyayati iti etat eva hi nirūpyate
translated: By what relation does the word indicate the meaning? This is what is being determined.

analyzed: tatra pratyāyaka tvāt eva pratyāyaka tvam iti ātma āśraya doṣa āpattiḥ
translated: There, if it is said that the word is an indicator because it indicates, then there is the fault of self-dependence.

analyzed: tasmāt na asti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no relation.

original: asati ca saṃbandhe vastvantarasya vastvantarabodhakatvāsaṃbhavādanirūpitahetuviśeṣaṃ svapnajñānavadyādṛcchikaṃ śabdārthajñānaṃ na pramāṇaṃ
analyzed: asati ca saṃbandhe vastu antarasya vastu antara bodhaka tva asaṃbhavāt anirūpita hetu viśeṣam svapna jñānavat yādṛcchikam śabda artha jñānam na pramāṇam
translated: And in the absence of a relation, because it is not possible for one thing to make another thing known, the knowledge of the word and meaning, which is accidental like dream knowledge without a determined cause, is not a means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: laukikaḥ tu sati api śabda prāmāṇye
translated: But even in the absence of the word being a means of valid knowledge, the worldly usage

analyzed: pramāṇa antara vaśāt kathañcid saṃgaccheta api
translated: could somehow be reconciled by the power of another means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: vaidikaḥ tu vyavahāraḥ śabda eka śaraṇa tvāt an ādartavyaḥ syāt nirmūla tvāt
translated: But the Vedic usage, being solely dependent on the word, would have to be disregarded because it is rootless.

analyzed: syāt evam yadi asaṃbandhaḥ śabda arthayoḥ
translated: This would be so if there were no connection between the word and its meaning.

original: asti tu saṃbandhaḥ pratyāyya ityayameva saṃbandho bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: asti tu saṃbandhaḥ pratyāyyaḥ iti ayam eva saṃbandhaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: But there is a connection, namely, the power to convey meaning. This very connection will be the connection.

analyzed: yat ca indriya liṅga ādi vat saṃnikarṣa vyāpti ādi saṃbandha anapekṣam artha pratipādanam idam eva abhidhānam iti ucyate
translated: And that which conveys the meaning without depending on connections such as proximity, pervasion, etc., like a sense organ or an inferential mark, is called abhidhāna (denotation).

analyzed: tat eva ca saṃjñā saṃjñi tvam
translated: And that itself is the relation of name and named.

original: tenocyate saṃjñāsaṃjñilakṣaṇaḥ saṃbandha iti ////🔽kiṃ punaḥ śabdasyārthapratipādane pramāṇam /🔽śabdānantaramarthapratipattireva /
analyzed: tena ucyate saṃjñā saṃjñi lakṣaṇaḥ saṃbandhaḥ iti  kim punar śabdasya artha pratipādane pramāṇam  śabda anantaram artha pratipattiḥ eva
translated: Therefore it is said that the relation is characterized by the relation of name and named.🔽What, then, is the evidence for a word's ability to convey meaning?🔽The cognition of the meaning immediately after the word.

analyzed: nanu iyam abhiprāya anumāna dvāreṇa eva upapannā
translated: Isn't this explained simply by inferring the speaker's intention?

analyzed: na iti brūmaḥ
translated: We say no.

analyzed: artha abhiprāya śūnyena api svāpa ādi avasthāyām para vaśa prayuktaiḥ api śabdaiḥ artha pratipatti darśanāt
translated: Because even when there is no intention to convey meaning, as in the state of sleep, etc., the cognition of meaning is seen even when words are used involuntarily by others.

original: tathā puruṣāntarakṛtamapauruṣeyaṃ vā vedavākyamanarthajñairapi prayujyamānaṃ vyutpannānāmarthabuddhiṃ janayatyeva /
analyzed: tathā puruṣa antara kṛtam apauruṣeyam vā veda vākyam anartha jñaiḥ api prayujyamānam vyutpannānām artha buddhim janayati eva
translated: Similarly, even when the Vedic statements are made by another person or are not human in origin, they produce the cognition of meaning in those who are learned, even when used by those who do not understand the meaning.

analyzed: tasmāt pratyāyakaḥ śabdaḥ
translated: Therefore, a word is a conveyor of meaning.

analyzed: kim iti tarhi prathama śravaṇe na pratyāyayati
translated: But then why doesn't it convey the meaning when first heard?

analyzed: sahakāri virahāt saṃjñā tva grahaṇam api śabdasya arthe pratyayataḥ ṅgam netrasya iva ālokaḥ
translated: Even the apprehension of the name is a factor in the word's conveying its meaning, like light is for the eye, due to the absence of cooperating factors.

original: tena yaḥ puruṣāntarebhyo ayaṃ puruṣāntarebhyo ayaṃ śabdo 'sya saṃjñeti jñātavān tasyaiva pratyāyayati nānyasyeti na doṣaḥ //
analyzed: tena yaḥ puruṣa antarebhyaḥ ayam puruṣa antarebhyaḥ ayam śabdaḥ sya saṃjñā iti jñātavān tasya eva pratyāyayati na anyasya iti na doṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, it conveys the meaning only to one who has known that this word has this name among other words, not to anyone else. Thus there is no fault.

analyzed: śabda artha saṃbandha anitya tve ākṣepaḥ
translated: Objection to the impermanence of the relation between word and meaning.

analyzed: nanu emaḥ tu nāma saṃbandhaḥ
translated: Well then, let there be this relation.

analyzed: sa tu pauruṣeyaḥ iti tvad uktyā eva āpannam
translated: But it follows from your statement that it is human.

original: tathāhi na hi śabdasyārthena saṃyogagādātmyādisaṃbandhaḥ kintu pratyāyakatvam /
analyzed: tathā hi na hi śabdasya arthena saṃyoga gādātmya ādi saṃbandhaḥ kintu pratyāyaka tvam
translated: For thus, the relation of a word with its meaning is not one of conjunction, identity, or the like, but rather of being the conveyor.

analyzed: tat ca puruṣa adhīnam iti uktam
translated: And that depends on humans, as stated.

original: ato devadattādiśabdasyeva asyārthasyeyaṃ saṃjñetyevaṃ saṃbandhe kṛte paścācchabdasyārthapratipādanamiti siddhaṃ pauruṣeyatvam ////
analyzed: atas devadatta ādi śabdasya iva asya arthasya iyam saṃjñā iti evam saṃbandhe kṛte paścāt śabdasya artha pratipādanam iti siddham pauruṣeya tvam
translated: Therefore, just as in the case of words like Devadatta, this is the name of this meaning, once the relation is established in this way, the word later conveys the meaning. Thus it is established that it is human.

original: iti saṃbandhākṣepaḥ pūrvākṣiptaṃ saṃbandhanityatvamasamādhāyedānīṃ atha gaurityatra kaḥ śabdaḥ iti kayā saṃgatyā kena vā prayojanena śabdasvarūpaṃ
analyzed: iti saṃbandha ākṣepaḥ pūrva ākṣiptam saṃbandha nitya tvam a samādhāya idānīm atha gauḥ iti atra kaḥ śabdaḥ iti kayā saṃgatyā kena vā prayojanena śabda svarūpam
translated: Thus ends the objection to the relation. Without resolving the previously raised objection to the permanence of the relation, now, in the sentence What is the word 'cow'? with what relevance and for what purpose is the nature of the word being discussed?

original: saṃgatistāvatprāsaṅgīkā saṃbandhaprastāvāt saṃbandhinorapi śabdārthayoḥ prastutatvātsvarūpaṃ nirūpyate /
analyzed: saṃgatiḥ tāvat prāsaṅgīkā saṃbandha prastāvāt saṃbandhinoḥ api śabda arthayoḥ prastuta tvāt svarūpam nirūpyate
translated: The connection is incidental, because it is the occasion for the relation, and because the relata, the word and its meaning, are also the subject matter.

analyzed: prayojanam api tad avayava āśritānām ūha ādīnām satya tvam
translated: The purpose is also the truth of the effects based on its parts, such as understanding.

original: niravayave hi vākye pade vā vācake 'vayavānāṃ mṛṣātvāt tadāśritānyapi kāryāṇi mṛṣā bhaveyuḥ ////
analyzed: niravayave hi vākye pade vā vācake vayavānām mṛṣātvāt tad āśritāni api kāryāṇi mṛṣā bhaveyuḥ
translated: For in a sentence or word without parts, the parts being false, the effects based on them would also be false.

analyzed: kiñca saṃbangha siddhi artham avaśyam varṇānām vācaka tvam samarthanīyam
translated: Moreover, in order to establish the relation, the denotativeness of the letters must necessarily be established.

original: anyathā hi teṣāṃ saṃgatyābhāvādvācakabhāvo nirādhāratvānna syānnatarāṃ nityatvamiti tatsiddhyarthaṃ vācakatvaṃ samarthayituṃ śabdasvarūpaṃ
analyzed: anyathā hi teṣām saṃgatyā abhāvāt vācaka bhāvaḥ nirādhāra tvāt na syāt natarām nitya tvam iti tad siddhi artham vācaka tvam samarthayitum śabda svarūpam
translated: Otherwise, due to the absence of connection between them, the denotative nature would not exist because it would be without a basis, and even less so would there be eternality. Therefore, in order to establish that, the denotativeness is being established by examining the nature of the word.

analyzed: ki gauḥ iti atra varṇāḥ eva śabdaḥ
translated: Is the word in What is a cow? just the letters themselves?

analyzed: uta tebhyaḥ ṛtha antaram iti etat prādhānyena nirūpyate  varṇa avayava ga tva go śabda avayavi jāti nirākaraṇam tu prāsaṅgikam
translated: Or is it something different from them? This is being examined primarily.🔽The refutation of the parts of letters, the universal of the word cow, and the whole word is incidental.

analyzed: varṇāḥ eva śabdaḥ iti avadhāraṇa samarthana artham
translated: In order to support the determination that the word is just the letters.

analyzed: tatra varṇānām api pudgala ākhyāna avayava anārhatāḥ saṃgirante tattva vayava anupalambhāt ayuktam
translated: There, the Jains also proclaim that even the letters have parts called pudgalas. This is unreasonable, because the real parts are not perceived.

analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa tāvat avayavāḥ na upalabhyante
translated: First, the parts are not perceived by direct perception.

analyzed: varṇeṣu sākalya vaikalya grahaṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no perception of the whole or the incomplete in the letters.

analyzed: na anumānena
translated: Not by inference either.

analyzed: taiḥ saha kasyacid liṅgasya saṃbandha agrahaṇāt
translated: Because no relation with any inferential mark is grasped with them.

analyzed: na ca sāmānyatas dṛṣṭam
translated: And not by the universal agreement.

analyzed: nahi yat yat vastu tasya tasya avaśyam avayavaiḥ bhavitavyam
translated: For it is not the case that whatever exists must necessarily consist of parts.

analyzed: paramāṇūnām niravayava tvāt
translated: Because atoms are partless.

analyzed: te pi sa avayavāḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that they too have parts,

original: tadavayavā api tathā syustataḥ paramapi tathetyekasyaiva māṣāvayavino 'nantāvayavitvaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tad avayavāḥ api tathā syuḥ tatas param api tathā iti ekasya eva māṣa avayavinaḥ nanta avayavi tvam syāt
translated: then those parts would be the same, and so on, so that a single bean with parts would have infinite parts.

original: tataścaikenaiva māṣeṇa tilena vā sarvaṃ jagadvyāpyeta /
analyzed: tatas ca ekena eva māṣeṇa tilena vā sarvam jagat vyāpyeta
translated: And then the entire world would be pervaded by a single bean or sesame seed.

analyzed: anantaiḥ avayavaiḥ mūrtaiḥ anyonyasya avara kāśam a prayacchadbhiḥ ananta deśa vyāpteḥ
translated: Because infinite material parts, not giving way to each other, would pervade infinite space.

analyzed: tasmāt niravayavāḥ paramāṇavaḥ varṇāḥ ca
translated: Therefore, atoms and letters are partless.

analyzed: tathā ga tva jātiḥ au tva jātiḥ ca niṣprāmāṇikā eva
translated: Similarly, the universal of going and the universal of being are also baseless.

original: nanu drutavilambitamadhyeṣūdāttānudāttasvariteṣu sānunāsikaniranunāsikayorhrasvadīrghapluteṣu ca pratyabhijñāyamānā jātiḥ kathaṃ nāstīti śakyate 🔽'bhidhātum /
analyzed: nanu druta vilambita madhyeṣu udātta anudātta svariteṣu sa anunāsika niranunāsikayoḥ hrasva dīrgha pluteṣu ca pratyabhijñāyamānā jātiḥ katham na asti iti śakyate  / bhidhātum
translated: But how can it be said that the recognized class does not exist in the quick, slow, and medium [tones], in the acute, grave, and circumflex [tones], in the nasal and non-nasal, and in the short, long, and protracted [vowels], which are recognized?🔽[Answer:] It is true.

analyzed: satyam  pratyabhijñā  sā tu pratyabhijñā
translated: [The recognition is] true.

analyzed: sā tu vyakta eka tvāt eva upapannā
translated: But that [recognition] is possible only because of the identity of the individual.

analyzed: druta ādi bheda ābhāsaḥ tu druta ādi avasthā bheda ālambanaḥ na vyakti bhedam āpādayitum alam bhavati
translated: And the appearance of difference in quickness, etc. is based on the difference in the states of quickness, etc., and cannot bring about the difference in the individual.

analyzed: ga tva ādi jāti nirākaraṇam
translated: Refutation of the class of going, etc.

original: bhedābhedāvabhāso 'pi dvedhā bhavati /🔽kvacidbhedo dharmiviṣayo yathā śābaleyādiṣvayaṃ gaurayaṃ
analyzed: bheda abheda avabhāsaḥ pi dvedhā bhavati  kvacid bhedaḥ dharmi viṣayaḥ yathā śābaleya ādiṣu ayam gauḥ ayam
translated: The appearance of difference and non-difference also occurs in two ways.

original: gaurayamiti jāterātmalābhaḥ /🔽kvacittu bhedābhāvabhāso dharmādabhedāvabhāsaśca dharmiṇamālambateekasminneva devadatte yuvāyaṃ vṛddho 'yaṃ kṛśo 'yamiti na tatra jātiraṅgīkriyate
analyzed: gauḥ ayam iti jāteḥ ātmalābhaḥ  kvacid tu bheda abhāva bhāsaḥ dharmāt abheda avabhāsaḥ ca dharmiṇam ālambate ekasmin eva devadatte yuvā ayam vṛddhaḥ yam kṛśaḥ yam iti na tatra jātiḥ aṅgīkriyate
translated: In some cases, the difference is based on the individual, as in the case of the spotted cow, etc., where it is said this is a cow, this is a cow, this is a cow, and the class obtains its own existence.🔽But in some cases, the appearance of the absence of difference and the appearance of non-difference from the property are based on the individual, as in the case of Devadatta himself, where it is said this is young, this is old, this is thin. There, the class is not accepted.

original: tadiha drutādiṣu dharmiviṣayo 'bhedo dharmiviṣayastu bhedaḥ tathāhi īdṛśo 'trāvabhāsaḥ
analyzed: tat iha druta ādiṣu dharmi viṣayaḥ bhedaḥ dharmi viṣayaḥ tu bhedaḥ tathā hi
translated: Here, in the case of quickness, etc., the non-difference is based on the individual, but the difference is based on the individual. Thus, the appearance here is as follows:

original: anenāyamakāro drutamuccārito 'nena vilambitamiti na tu ayamakāro druto 'yaṃ tu vilambita
analyzed: anena ayam akāraḥ drutam uccāritaḥ nena vilambitam iti na tu ayam akāraḥ drutaḥ yam tu vilambita
translated: By this [the letter] a is pronounced quickly, by this slowly, but not that this a is quick, this one is slow.

analyzed: iti yena dharmi bhedaḥ jātiḥ ca aṅgīkriyetām
translated: By which the difference of the substratum and the universal would be accepted.

analyzed: nanu kārśya ādīnām krama varti tvāt ekasmin devadatte yuktaḥ samāveśaḥ
translated: But because thinness and so on occur in sequence, their inclusion in one Devadatta is proper.

original: anunāsikādīnāntu dharmāṇāṃ yugapadanekavaktruccārite varṇe samavetānāṃ kathamekavarṇaviṣayatvam /
analyzed: anunāsika ādīnām tu dharmāṇām yugapad aneka vaktṛ uccārite varṇe samavetānām katham eka varṇa viṣaya tvam
translated: But for the properties such as nasalization, which occur simultaneously in a letter pronounced by many mouths, how can they pertain to one letter, since they are mutually exclusive?

analyzed: na hi viruddha dharmān ekaḥ dharmī yugapad bibharti
translated: For a substratum does not simultaneously bear mutually exclusive properties.

analyzed: satyam
translated: True,

original: natvete paramārthato varṇadharmā dhvanidharmāstvete varṇe kevalamābhāsante /
analyzed: na tu ete paramārthataḥ varṇa dharmāḥ dhvani dharmāḥ tu ete varṇe kevalam ābhāsante
translated: but these are not really properties of the letter, they are properties of the sound, which appear only in the letter.

original: yathālpe mahati ca darpaṇe yugapaddṛśyamāne mukhe 'lpatvaṃ mahatvaṃ ceti /
analyzed: yathā alpe mahati ca darpaṇe yugapad dṛśyamāne mukhe lpa tvam maha tvam ca iti
translated: Just as smallness and largeness are seen simultaneously in a face reflected in a small or large mirror.

original: tasmādvarṇasya vyaktyekatve 'pi na virodha ityaprāmāṇikī gatvādijātiḥ ////
analyzed: tasmāt varṇasya vyakti eka tve pi na virodhaḥ iti aprāmāṇikī ga tva ādi jātiḥ
translated: Therefore, even though the letter is one, there is no contradiction. Thus the universal of ghoṣavat and so on is not authoritative.

analyzed: evam go śabda avayavī api
translated: Thus the indivisible whole of the word 'go'

analyzed: gakāra ādīnām ayaugapadyāt sarvagata tvāt ca avayavi ārambha asāmarthyāt
translated: is also not possible, because the letters g and so on do not occur simultaneously and because they are all-pervading, they are incapable of producing an indivisible whole.

original: sarvatra hi kāraṇaparimāṇādadhikaṃ kāryaparimāṇam tantupaṭayoriva na ca vibhubhyo varṇebhyaḥ parimāṇādhikyaṃ kasyacidbhavati /
analyzed: sarvatra hi kāraṇa parimāṇāt adhikam kārya parimāṇam tantu paṭayoḥ iva na ca vibhubhyaḥ varṇebhyaḥ parimāṇa ādhikyam kasyacid bhavati
translated: For everywhere the magnitude of the effect is greater than that of the cause, as in the case of the thread and the cloth. And from the all-pervading letters, no one has a greater magnitude.

analyzed: a taḥ na asi avayavī
translated: Therefore, there is no whole.

analyzed: tad abhāve ca tad ādhāram go śabda tvam dūra apāstam
translated: And in the absence of that, the quality of being the word 'cow' based on that is far removed.

analyzed: tasmāt varṇaḥ eva śabdaḥ
translated: Therefore, the word is only a letter.

analyzed: āha gṛhṇīmaḥ etat avayava avayavi gadvā ādikam na asti iti
translated: He says: We accept this, that there is no dispute between the parts and the whole.

analyzed: na tu varṇāḥ eva śabdāḥ iti
translated: But the letters are not the word.

analyzed: artha pratyaya anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the cognition of the meaning is not possible.

analyzed: tathā hi na hi eka akṣara vijñānāt artha dhīḥ upajāyate
translated: For thus, the cognition of the meaning does not arise from the cognition of a single letter.

analyzed: vācaḥ ca krama varti tvāt sāhityam na avakalpate
translated: And because speech occurs in sequence, simultaneity is not possible.

analyzed: ucyate yathā āgneya ādi karmāṇi krama vartini santi api
translated: It is said: Just as the Agnihotra and other rites, though occurring in sequence,

analyzed: saṃhatya kurvate kāryam ekam varṇāḥ tathā eva naḥ
translated: jointly perform a single action, so it is for us with the letters.

analyzed: varṇānām artha pratyāyaka tvam
translated: The letters have the nature of expressing the meaning.

analyzed: nanu krama vartinām api utpatti apūrva vaśena yuktam sāhityam
translated: But even for those occurring in sequence, simultaneity is proper by the power of the unseen potency produced by them.

analyzed: varṇānām tu katham
translated: But how is it for the letters?

original: teṣāmapi saṃskāreṇa bhaviṣyati tatsadbhāve kiṃ pramāṇam /
analyzed: teṣām api saṃskāreṇa bhaviṣyati tad sadbhāve kim pramāṇam
translated: Even for them, it will be by the impression. What is the evidence for their existence?

analyzed: yat eva āgneya ādiṣu
translated: The same as for the Agnihotra and others.

original: yathāhi teṣāṃ śāstreṇa saṃhatyakāritāvagamātsvarūpataśca tadasaṃbhavādapūrvaṃ dvāraṃ kalpyate /🔽tathā varṇānāmapyekaikaśo 'bhidhānādarśanātsakaloccāraṇe cāvagamātsaṃhatyakāritve niścite svarūpeṇāsaṃbhavātsaṃskārakalpanaṃ yuktameva /
analyzed: yathā hi teṣām śāstreṇa saṃhatya kāri tā avagamāt svarūpataḥ ca tad asaṃbhavāt apūrvam dvāram kalpyate  tathā varṇānām api ekaikaśas bhidhāna adarśanāt sakala uccāraṇe ca avagamāt saṃhatya kāri tve niścite svarūpeṇa asaṃbhavāt saṃskāra kalpanam yuktam eva
translated: Just as, because it is understood that they function collectively according to the scriptures, and because that is impossible in their nature, an unseen entity is imagined as the means,🔽in the same way, because the individual letters are not seen to denote, and because they are understood when all are uttered, their collective functioning being ascertained, and because that is impossible in their nature, the imagination of a modification is quite proper.

analyzed: tadvat eva ca eka kartṛ tvam krama viśeṣaḥ ca ādriyate viparyayeṇa artha abhidhāna adarśanāt
translated: In the same way, the oneness of the agent and the particular order are accepted, because the denotation of meaning is not seen otherwise.

analyzed: sphoṭa vāda khaṇḍanam
translated: Refutation of the theory of sphoṭa.

original: nanvevaṃ prativarṇaṃ saṃskārakalpanādekakalpanā syāt tadvaramekameva śabdatvaṃ kalpitam /
analyzed: nanu evam prativarṇam saṃskāra kalpanāt eka kalpanā syāt tat varam ekam eva śabda tvam kalpitam
translated: If in this way the modification is imagined for each letter, there would be the imagination of oneness. It is better to imagine just one sound.

analyzed: na evam
translated: Not so.

analyzed: dṛśya a darśanena nirasta vat
translated: Like what is rejected by the non-perception of the visible.

analyzed: śabdaḥ hi pratyakṣa grāhyaḥ bhyupagamyate
translated: For sound is accepted as perceptible.

analyzed: na ca pratyakṣeṇa kiñcid prakāśate
translated: And nothing is manifested by perception.

analyzed: tena na asti iti avagacchāmaḥ
translated: Therefore we understand that it does not exist.

original: tvayāpi hi śabdatvaṃ kalpayitvā punaḥ saṃskārakalpanāvaśyaṃ kartavyā /
analyzed: tvayā api hi śabda tvam kalpayitvā punar saṃskāra kalpanā avaśyam kartavyā
translated: Even by you, having imagined sound, the imagination of modification must necessarily be done again.

analyzed: dhvanayaḥ hi na pratyekam sphoṭam abhivyañjati
translated: For the sounds do not individually manifest the sphoṭa.

original: sāhityaṃ ca kramavartināṃ saṃskāradvārameveti tulyaṃ tatkalpanam ////
analyzed: sāhityam ca krama vartinām saṃskāra dvāram evā iti tulyam tad kalpanam
translated: And the association of the successive impressions is also only through the impressions themselves. So the assumption is the same in both cases.

analyzed: syāt matam
translated: It may be argued as follows:

analyzed: pratyekam eva nādāḥ śabdam abhivyañjanti
translated: The individual sounds manifest the word.

original: nacaivamuttaranādavaiyarthyam /🔽pūrve hi nādāḥ śabdasphuṭamabhivyañjanti uttarottare sphuṭaṃ sphuṭataraṃ ca vyañjantīti nottareṣāmānarthakyam /
analyzed: na ca evam uttaranāda vaiyarthyam  pūrve hi nādāḥ śabda sphuṭam abhivyañjanti uttarottare sphuṭam sphuṭataram ca vyañjanti iti na uttareṣām ānarthakyam
translated: And thus the later sounds are not useless.🔽For the earlier sounds manifest the word clearly, and the later ones manifest it more and more clearly, so the later ones are not useless.

original: yadyevaṃ tato ya evottare nādāḥ sphuṭābhivyaktisamarthāstaireva bhavitavyamalaṃ pūrveḥ ////
analyzed: yadi evam tatas ye eva uttare nādāḥ sphuṭa abhivyakti samarthāḥ taiḥ eva bhavitavyam alam
translated: If that is so, then it should be only by those later sounds that are capable of clear manifestation, and not by the earlier ones.

original: nanu na kaścidapi nādaḥ svato 'sya sphuṭābhivyaktiṃ karoti kintu sarve te pratyekaṃ vyañjakāḥ /
analyzed: nanu na kaścid api nādaḥ svatas sphuṭa abhivyaktim karoti kintu sarve te pratyekam vyañjakāḥ
translated: But no sound at all manifests it clearly by itself, rather all of them are individual manifestors.

original: sa tu na drāgeva sphuṭamavabhāsate prathamamasphuṭāvabhāsitaḥ san punaḥ punaḥ śrūyamāṇaḥ sphuṭaḥ bhavati /
analyzed: sa tu na drāk eva sphuṭam avabhāsate prathamam asphuṭa avabhāsitaḥ san punar punar śrūyamāṇaḥ sphuṭaḥ bhavati
translated: But it does not appear clearly at once. Having been first heard indistinctly, it becomes clear when heard again and again.

original: tadyathā dūrādavasthitaḥ sahakāraḥ prathamaṃ hastipalālakūṭādisādhāraṇarūpeṇa pratibhātaḥ
analyzed: tat yathā dūrāt avasthitaḥ sahakāraḥ prathamam hasti palāla kūṭa ādi sādhāraṇa rūpeṇa pratibhātaḥ
translated: For example, a mango tree standing far away is first perceived as having a form common to an elephant's trunk, a heap of wood, etc.

original: punarālocyamāno vṛkṣātmanā prakāśate punaḥsahakārātmanā sphaṭo bhavati tadvadeva draṣṭavyam // //
analyzed: punar ālocyamānaḥ vṛkṣa ātmanā prakāśate punar sahakāra ātmanā sphaṭaḥ bhavati tadvat eva draṣṭavyam  /
translated: Again, when reflected upon, it appears in the form of a tree. Again, it becomes clear in the form of a mango fruit. It should be seen in the same way.

original: yadyevaṃ ya eva te pūrvai nādāstairevābhyasyamānairīdṛśī sphuṭābhivyaktiḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi evam ye eva te pūrvaiḥ nādāḥ taiḥ eva abhyasyamānaiḥ īdṛśī sphuṭa abhivyaktiḥ syāt
translated: If it is so, then by the mere repetition of those same sounds that existed before, such clear manifestation would occur.

analyzed: uttaraiḥ vā kevalaiḥ abhyasyamānaiḥ
translated: Or by the mere repetition of the subsequent ones alone.

analyzed: tatra vijātīya nāda āśrayaṇam anarthakam
translated: In that case, the reliance on dissimilar sounds is pointless.

analyzed: tathā
translated: Similarly,

original: pratyekaṃ hi vyañjakatve satyuttarairasphuṭābhivyaktiḥ pūrvaiśca sphuṭābhivyaktiḥ syāditi vyutkrameṇāpyuccāraṇaṃ syāt /
analyzed: pratyekam hi vyañjaka tve sati uttaraiḥ asphuṭa abhivyaktiḥ pūrvaiḥ ca sphuṭa abhivyaktiḥ syāt iti vyutkrameṇa api uccāraṇam syāt
translated: if each sound were the manifester, then the manifestation by the subsequent ones would be unclear, and the manifestation by the previous ones would be clear. Thus, the utterance would occur in reverse order as well.

analyzed: atas pekṣita krama viśeṣa aneka vijātīya nāda samuccaya āśrayaṇāt avaśyam pūrva nāda āhita saṃskāra sahita antima nāda abhivyaṅgyaḥ sphoṭaḥ iti avaśya aṅgīkartavyam iti
translated: Therefore, since it necessarily relies on the combination of many dissimilar sounds with specific required sequence, the sphoṭa is necessarily accepted as manifested by the final sound along with the impressions deposited by the previous sounds.

analyzed: tulyā saṃskāra kalpanā
translated: The postulation of impressions is the same.

analyzed: yat vā tava evā iyam saṃskāra anta kalpanā
translated: Or this postulation of another impression is yours alone.

original: matpakṣe tu smṛtihetubhireva saṃskāraiḥ siddhyatyarthāvagatiriti na saṃskārāntaraṃ kalpayitavyama ////
analyzed: mad pakṣe tu smṛti hetubhiḥ eva saṃskāraiḥ siddhi atyartha avagatiḥ iti na saṃskāra antaram kalpayitavyam
translated: But in my view, the understanding of the meaning is accomplished by the impressions that are the cause of memory. Therefore, another impression need not be postulated.

original: nanu mamāpi ta eva bhaviṣyanti / na /
analyzed: nanu mama api te eva bhaviṣyanti na
translated: But they will be the same for me also. No.

analyzed: teṣām smṛteḥ anyatra avyāpārāt
translated: Because they do not operate elsewhere than in memory.

original: matpakṣe tu smṛtireva janayantor'thapratipattiṃ saṃskārā janayanti /🔽tathāhi pratyekavarṇānubhavabhāvitaiḥ saṃskāraiḥ saṃhatya sarvavarṇagocaraikā smṛtirjanyate /
analyzed: mad pakṣe tu smṛtiḥ eva janayantaḥ ūrtha pratipattim saṃskārāḥ janayanti  tathā hi pratyeka varṇa anubhava bhāvitaiḥ saṃskāraiḥ saṃhatya sarva varṇa gocarā ekā smṛtiḥ janyate
translated: But in my view, the impressions themselves, while producing memory, produce the cognition of the meaning.🔽For thus, by the impressions formed by the experience of each letter, a single memory is produced, having all the letters as its object.

original: tasyāṃ ca yugapadavabhāsamānā varṇā vinaiva saṃskārāntareṇa saṃhatyārthapratyayaṃ janayanti ////
analyzed: tasyām ca yugapad avabhāsamānāḥ varṇāḥ vinā eva saṃskāra antareṇa saṃhatya artha pratyayam janayanti
translated: And in that [memory], the letters appearing simultaneously, without any other impression, produce the cognition of the meaning collectively.

analyzed: tvad pakṣe tu na evam saṃbhavati
translated: But in your view, this is not possible.

original: tathāhi nādā hi na jñāyamānatayā sphoṭaṃ vyañjayanti /
analyzed: tathā hi nādāḥ hi na jñāyamāna tayā sphoṭam vyañjayanti
translated: For the sounds do not manifest the sphoṭa by being cognized.

analyzed: na ca yugapad sattā asti krama varti tvāt
translated: And they do not exist simultaneously, because they occur in sequence.

analyzed: atas saṃskāra dvāram eva sāhityam iti avarjanīyam saṃskāra antara kalpanam
translated: Therefore, their collectivity can only be through impressions. So the postulation of another impression is unavoidable.

analyzed: atha matam
translated: Now, if it is thought:

analyzed: satyam na smṛti hetubhiḥ sphoṭa abhivyaktiḥ
translated: It is true that the sphoṭa is not manifested by those which are the causes of memory.

original: ye tu varṇopalabdhihetavo nādajanyāḥ śrotragatāḥ saṃskārāstaireva varṇānāmiva sphoṭābhivyaktirbhaviṣyati kiṃ saṃskārāntarakalpanayeti /
analyzed: ye tu varṇa upalabdhi hetavaḥ nāda janyāḥ śrotra gatāḥ saṃskārāḥ taiḥ eva varṇānām iva sphoṭa abhivyaktiḥ bhaviṣyati kim saṃskāra antara kalpanayā iti
translated: But those modifications in the ear that are the cause of the perception of the letters, and are not produced by sound, will themselves manifest the sphoṭa, just as they do the letters. What need is there to assume any other modifications?

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: This is not correct.

analyzed: teṣām kṣaṇika tvāt
translated: Because they are momentary.

analyzed: na hi adya varṇa upalabdhi hetuḥ saṃskāraḥ ntya varṇa śravaṇa velāyām avatiṣṭhate
translated: The modification that is the cause of the perception of the first letter does not persist at the time of hearing the last letter.

analyzed: yadi avatiṣṭhate tatas visarjanīya śravaṇa velāyām api gakāra śravaṇam anuvarteta
translated: If it did persist, then even at the time of hearing the visarga, the hearing of the g sound would continue.

analyzed: tasmāt kṣaṇabhaṅginaḥ te
translated: Therefore, they are momentary.

original: ato na teṣāṃ saṃhatya sphoṭābhivyañjakatvaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: atas na teṣām saṃhatya sphoṭa abhivyañjaka tvam bhavati
translated: So they cannot collectively manifest the sphoṭa.

analyzed: pratyeka abhivyaktau ca uttarottareṣām anarthaka tvam iti uktam
translated: And if each one manifests it, then the later ones would be meaningless, as stated.

analyzed: athavā dhvani yogaḥ eva śrotra saṃskāraḥ na anyaḥ
translated: Or rather, the modification of the ear is just the conjunction with the sound, nothing else.

original: tasya ca vispaṣṭameva bhaṅgukatvamityuktam ////🔽athavā dhvanisaṃyoga eva śrotrasaṃskāro nānyaḥ /
analyzed: tasya ca vispaṣṭam eva bhaṅguka tvam iti uktam  athavā dhvani saṃyogaḥ eva śrotra saṃskāraḥ na anyaḥ
translated: And it is clearly momentary, as stated.🔽Or rather, the modification of the ear is just the contact with the sound, nothing else.

analyzed: tasya ca vispaṣṭam eva bhaṅgura tvam gatvara tvāt ghavanīnām
translated: And it is clearly momentary, because the sounds are transient.

analyzed: tasmāt anye sthāyinaḥ saṃskārāḥ kalpyāḥ
translated: Therefore, other permanent modifications must be assumed.

original: tathā varṇātiriktaḥ śabdaḥ kalpya iti bahvapramāṇakamāpannam /
analyzed: tathā varṇa atiriktaḥ śabdaḥ kalpyaḥ iti bahu apramāṇakam āpannam
translated: Similarly, it would lead to the postulation of a word-sound apart from the letters, which would require many more unestablished assumptions.

original: matpakṣe tu dṛḍhasmṛtiviparivartināṃ varṇānāṃ vācakatvānna kiñcidūnam ////
analyzed: mad pakṣe tu dṛḍha smṛti viparivartinām varṇānām vācaka tvāt na kiñcid ūnam
translated: But in my view, since the letters that are the content of firm memory are expressive, nothing is lacking.

original: nanu yugapatsmaryamāṇānāṃ vācakatve vyutkrameṇāpyuccāritā varṇā vācakāḥ syuḥ / na /
analyzed: nanu yugapad smaryamāṇānām vācaka tve vyutkrameṇa api uccāritāḥ varṇāḥ vācakāḥ syuḥ na
translated: But if the letters that are remembered simultaneously are expressive, then the letters uttered in a different order would also be expressive. No,

analyzed: tad kramasya api aṅga tvāt
translated: because the order is also a part.

analyzed: kaḥ punar kramaḥ u ṅgam
translated: But what is the order that is a part?

original: na hi varṇānāṃ vibhūnāṃ nityānāṃ ca svarūpataḥ kramavattvam /
analyzed: na hi varṇānām vibhūnām nityānām ca svarūpataḥ kramavat tvam
translated: For the letters, which are all-pervading and eternal, do not have order in their own nature.

analyzed: na pratīti kramaḥ
translated: Nor is the order of cognition,

original: tasyāḥ smṛtirūpāyā ekatvāt /🔽evaṃ tarhi dhvanikramo yo varmeṣvāropitaḥ pratibhāsate so 'ṅgamityadoṣaḥ /
analyzed: tasyāḥ smṛti rūpāyāḥ eka tvāt  evam tarhi dhvani kramaḥ yaḥ varma iṣu āropitaḥ pratibhāsate saḥ ṅgam iti adoṣaḥ
translated: because that is of the nature of memory and is one.🔽If that is so, then the order of the sound-manifestations that is superimposed on the letters and appears is the part. There is no fault.

original: tasmādvyañjakānāṃ dhvanīnāṃ krameṇa vyaṅgyeṣu varṇeṣu samāropitena tadvantaḥ smaryamāṇā varṇā vācakāḥ nānyaḥ śabdo 'stīti siddham //
analyzed: tasmāt vyañjakānām dhvanīnām krameṇa vyaṅgyeṣu varṇeṣu samāropitena tadvantaḥ smaryamāṇāḥ varṇāḥ vācakāḥ na anyaḥ siddham
translated: Therefore, the letters that are remembered as having that order, which is superimposed on the expressed letters by the manifesting sound-manifestations, are expressive. There is no other sound. This is established.

analyzed: iti sphoṭa vādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the theory of sphoṭa.
The beginning of the examination of the meaning of words.

original: atha gaurityasya śabdasya kor'thaḥ iti vācyanirūpaṇopakramavyājenākṛtisadbhāvaṃ pratipādayati saṃbandhanityatvasiddhaye /
analyzed: atha gauḥ iti asya śabdasya kaḥ ṛthaḥ iti vācya nirūpaṇa upakrama vyājena ākṛti sadbhāvam pratipādayati saṃbandha nitya tva siddhaye
translated: Now, what is the meaning of the word 'cow'? Under the pretext of explaining the meaning of the word, he teaches the existence of the universal in order to establish the eternality of the relation.

analyzed: na hi asatyām ākṛtaḥ vyaktibhiḥ śabdasya apauruṣeyaḥ saṃbandhaḥ tāsām anitya tvāt
translated: For, without a universal, the relation of a word with its meaning cannot be eternal, because the individuals are not eternal.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇasya api nityasya abhāvāt ākṛti abhāve
translated: And because there is no eternal indicative mark, the universal does not exist.

analyzed: tasmāt ākṛtiḥ asti na asti iti vicāryate
translated: Therefore, it is considered whether the universal exists or not.

original: sādhite tu tatsadbhāve saiva śabdābhidheyetyākṛtyadhikaraṇe vakṣyate //
analyzed: sādhite tu tad sadbhāve sā eva śabda abhidheyā iti ākṛti adhikaraṇe vakṣyate
translated: But when its existence is established, it will be said in the chapter on the universal that it alone is denoted by words.

analyzed: bauddha matena jāti khaṇḍanam
translated: Refutation of the universal according to the Buddhist view.

original: tatra saugatāḥ svalakṣaṇameva paramārthaṃ manyamānā nākṛtisadbhāvaṃ manyante /
analyzed: tatra saugatāḥ sva lakṣaṇam eva paramārtham manyamānāḥ na ākṛti sadbhāvam manyante
translated: There, the Buddhists, considering the individual alone to be real, do not accept the existence of the universal.

original: tathāhi pṛthaktve vyaktito jātirdṛśyeta pṛthageva sā /
analyzed: tathā hi pṛthaktve vyaktitaḥ jātiḥ dṛśyeta pṛthak eva sā
