translated: And if it were natural, by what could it be destroyed?

original: āgamikaṃ dhyānādi tajjanyaṃ vā svarūpajñānaṃ brahmāvidyāṃ nāśayatīti cet / na /
analyzed: āgamikam dhyāna ādi tad janyam vā svarūpa jñānam brahma avidyām nāśayati iti ced na
translated: If it be said that the scriptural (teaching) or meditation, etc., or the knowledge produced by them, destroy the ignorance of Brahman, (we reply) no.

original: nahyāgamo vā dhyānādayo vā tajjanyaṃ vā jñānaṃ nityajñānātmakabrahmātiriktamasti yadavidyāṃ nāśayet /
analyzed: na hi āgamaḥ vā dhyāna ādayaḥ vā tad janyam vā jñānam nitya jñāna ātmaka brahma atiriktam asti yat avidyām nāśayet
translated: For there is no scripture or meditation, etc., or knowledge produced by them, other than Brahman, which consists of eternal knowledge, that could destroy ignorance.

analyzed: tat varam asmāt māyā vādāt māhāyānika vādaḥ
translated: It is better for us to be Māyāvādins than to be Mahāyāyānists.

original: yatra nīlapītādivaicitryaṃ kāryakāraṇabhāvo baddhamuktādivyavasthā ca saṃtānabhedena samarthyate /
analyzed: yatra nīla pīta ādi vaicitryam kārya kāraṇa bhāvaḥ baddha mukta ādi vyavasthā ca saṃtāna bhedena samarthyate
translated: Where the variety of blue, yellow, etc., the relation of cause and effect, the distinction of the bound and the liberated, etc., are maintained by the difference of the series (of cognitions).

analyzed: nityam ekarasam niṣprapañcam ātmānam upeyuṣām tu samasta loka veda ja vyavahāra ucchittiḥ eva syāt
translated: But for those who adopt the Self as eternal, of one taste, and free from conceptual content, there would be a complete destruction of all the usages of the world, the Vedas, and the scriptures.

original: yadapyāhuḥ ajñānajanyaḥ prapañco jñānena vināśyate mṛgatoyavat svapnaprapañcavacceti /
analyzed: yat api āhuḥ ajñāna janyaḥ prapañcaḥ jñānena vināśyate mṛga toya vat svapna prapañca vat ca iti
translated: As for what they also say: The world, which is produced by ignorance, is destroyed by knowledge, like a mirage or a dream,

original: tadapyayuktam yadi kulālādivyāpārasthānīyenājñānena ghaṭavadutpannaḥ prapañco musalasthānīyena jñānena
analyzed: tat api ayuktam yadi kulāla ādi vyāpāra sthānīyena ajñānena ghaṭa vat utpannaḥ prapañcaḥ musala sthānīyena jñānena
translated: that also is improper. If the world, which is produced by ignorance, which is like the activity of a potter, etc., is destroyed by knowledge, which is like a hammer,

analyzed: nāśyate tathā api na asatvam prapañcasya syāt
translated: even so, the non-existence of the world would not result.

analyzed: utpatti vināśa yoga ādi nitya tā mātram syāt na atyanta abhāvaḥ
translated: [The opponent may say:] It would be mere permanence, the mere non-occurrence of origination and destruction, not absolute non-existence.

analyzed: kena ca jñānena nāśaḥ
translated: By what knowledge is destruction [known]?

analyzed: na ātma jñānena
translated: Not by the knowledge of the self.

analyzed: virodha abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no contradiction [between the self and destruction].

analyzed: niṣprapañca ātma jñānena iti ced na
translated: If it is said that it is by the knowledge of the self free from conceptual proliferation, no.

analyzed: tatra ātma jñāna aṃśasya avirodhāt
translated: Because the part of the knowledge of the self in that [knowledge] is not contradictory.

analyzed: niṣprapañca tva jñānam vināśakam iti pāriśeṣyāt āpannam prapañca abhāvaḥ ca niṣprapañca tvam
translated: The knowledge of the absence of conceptual proliferation is the destroyer, it is concluded by elimination. And the absence of conceptual proliferation is the state of being free from conceptual proliferation.

analyzed: na ca vidyamānam prapañce tad abhāva jñānam utpattum arhati
translated: And the knowledge of that absence cannot arise in the existent conceptual proliferation.

original: jñānena hyutpannena prapañco nāśayitavyaḥ prāk ca jñānātsadrūpa eva prapañcastisminsadrūpe 'vasthite kathaṃ tadabhāvaviṣayasya jñānasyotpattiḥ
analyzed: jñānena hi utpannena prapañcaḥ nāśayitavyaḥ prāk ca jñānāt sat rūpaḥ eva prapañcaḥ tismin sat rūpe vasthite katham tad abhāva viṣayasya jñānasya utpattiḥ
translated: For the conceptual proliferation must be destroyed by the knowledge that arises, and the conceptual proliferation exists in the form of existence prior to the knowledge. How can the knowledge whose object is that absence arise when it exists in that form of existence?

analyzed: tatra jñāna utpattau satyām prapañcasya nāśaḥ
translated: When that knowledge arises, there is destruction of the conceptual proliferation.

analyzed: tad vināśe ca sati tad abhāva viṣaya jñāna utpattiḥ iti itaretarāśraya tvam
translated: And when that destruction exists, the arising of the knowledge whose object is that absence - this is mutual dependence.

analyzed: etena mṛgatṛṣṇikā jalasya jñāna vināśya tvam pratyūḍham
translated: By this, the destruction by knowledge of the water in a mirage is refuted.

original: na hi tajjalaṃ sat paścānnāśyate prāgapi hi tatra naiva jalaṃ /
analyzed: na hi tat jalam sat paścāt nāśyate prāk api hi tatra na eva jalam
translated: For that water, which is existent, is not destroyed later. Even before, there is no water in it.

original: ajalameva hi raśmiprataptamūṣaraṃ bhrāntyā jalātmanāvagataṃ paścādbādhakena yathāvasthitarūpamavagamyata ityalamanena bālajalpitena //
analyzed: ajalam eva hi raśmi prataptam ūṣaram bhrāntyā jala ātmanā avagatam paścāt bādhakena yathā avasthita rūpam avagamyate iti alam anena bāla jalpitena
translated: For a mirage, which is not water at all, is apprehended as water by error; but afterwards, by the counteracting cognition, it is apprehended as it really is. Enough of this prattle of the ignorant!

analyzed: iti advaita mata nirāsaḥ
translated: Thus ends the refutation of the doctrine of non-duality.

analyzed: ardhajaratīya advaita vādena pūrvapakṣaḥ
translated: The prima facie view based on the doctrine of half-non-duality.

original: kecittvaupaniṣadāḥ paramārthata evātmā prapañcarūpeṇa svecchayā pariṇamatīti manyante /🔽tathā ca sā sadeva somyedamagra āsīdekamevādvitīya tadaikṣata bahusyāṃ prajāyeya
analyzed: kecid tu aupaniṣadāḥ paramārthataḥ eva ātmā prapañca rūpeṇa sva icchayā pariṇamati iti manyante  tathā ca sā sat eva somya idam agre āsīt ekam eva advitīya tat aikṣata bahusyām prajāyeya
translated: Some Upaniṣadic scholars think that the Self really transforms itself into the form of the world by its own will.🔽And thus it is said: In the beginning, O dear one, this was indeed Being, one only without a second. It thought: 'Let me be many, let me procreate.'

analyzed: iti ekasya eva sanmātra rūpatayā prāk avasthita ātmanaḥ neka vyoma ādi bheda bhinna prapañca rūpeṇa
translated: Thus the transformation of the Self, which existed before as mere Being, into the form of the world, differentiated by the various spaces etc.,

analyzed: bījasya iva pariṇāmaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: is shown to be like the transformation of a seed.

original: tasmādvā etasmādātmana ākāśaḥ saṃbhūta ityaupaniṣadāṃ vādāḥ purāṇavādāścāsminnarthe śataśo dṛśyante /
analyzed: tasmāt vai etasmāt ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ iti aupaniṣadām vādāḥ purāṇa vādāḥ ca asmin arthe śataśas dṛśyante
translated: Therefore, from this Self, space was produced. These Upaniṣadic statements and the Purāṇic statements are seen in this matter by the hundreds.

original: puruṣa evedaṃ sarvaṃ neha nānāsti kiñcana ityādi tu dharmibhedābāvābhiprāyam /
analyzed: puruṣaḥ eva idam sarvam na iha nānā asti kiñcana ityādi tu dharmi bheda abāva abhiprāyam
translated: But the statement This entire world is indeed the Person; there is no multiplicity here at all is with the intention that there is no difference in the substratum.

original: tadyathaiko vṛkṣaḥ prādeśamātrādūrdhvaṃ nānāśākho 'vasthito dūrasthairnānāvṛkṣā iti /
analyzed: tat yathā ekaḥ vṛkṣaḥ prādeśa mātrāt ūrdhvam nānā śākhaḥ vasthitaḥ dūra sthaiḥ nānā vṛkṣāḥ iti
translated: For example, a tree, a cubit high, is seen to have many branches, and those at a distance see it as many trees.

analyzed: tathā nāma rūpa prapañcam nānā rūpam paśyatām
translated: Similarly, the world of names and forms is seen to have many forms by those who are far away from the truth.

original: mūlakāraṇasyaikasyātmano 'yaṃ nānārūpaḥ pariṇāma ityevamajānatāṃ tattvakathanārthā evaṃvidhā vādāḥ /
analyzed: mūlakāraṇasya ekasya ātmanaḥ yam nānā rūpaḥ pariṇāmaḥ iti evam a jānatām tattva kathana arthāḥ evaṃvidhāḥ vādāḥ
translated: For those who do not know that this manifold transformation of the one root cause, the Self, is so, these statements are made in order to teach the truth.

analyzed: sarvam ekasya eva vistāraḥ na kiñcid atra nānā asti iti
translated: The whole is the expansion of the one alone; nothing here is manifold.

original: ye ca punarasattvavādāḥ prapañcaviṣayā avidyāvādā bhrāntivādā māyāvādāśca te sarve prapañcasyānityatvādaupacārikāḥ /
analyzed: ye ca punar asattva vādāḥ prapañca viṣayāḥ avidyā vādāḥ bhrānti vādāḥ māyā vādāḥ ca te sarve prapañcasya anitya tvāt aupacārikāḥ
translated: And those statements about non-existence, which are about the world, about ignorance, about delusion, and about illusion, are all figurative when applied to the impermanence of the world,

analyzed: yathā mṛga toya rajju sarpa svapna prapañca ādayaḥ kiñcid kālam āvirbhūya paścāt vilīyante
translated: just as the world of mirages, water, snakes, and dreams appears for a while and then disappears.

analyzed: tathā bheda prapañca rūpaḥ brahma pariṇāmaḥ pi āvirbhavati vilīyate ca iti āvirbhāva tirobhāva dharmaka tva sāmyāt asan iti upacaryate
translated: Similarly, the transformation of Brahman in the form of the manifold world appears and disappears. Because of the similarity in having the property of appearance and disappearance, it is figuratively called non-existent.

original: tasya cāsatkalpatve tadviṣayasya jñānasyāpi siddhyatyaupacārikaṃ bhrāntitvam /
analyzed: tasya ca asat kalpa tve tad viṣayasya jñānasya api siddhi ati aupacārikam bhrānti tvam
translated: And when that is like non-existence, the knowledge that has it as its object is also figuratively called deluded.

original: māyānibandhanatvaṃ ca indro māyābhiḥ pururūpa īyate ityādiṣu yuktamupacāreṇa vaktum /
analyzed: māyā nibandhana tvam ca indraḥ māyābhiḥ puru rūpaḥ īyate ityādiṣu yuktam upacāreṇa vaktum
translated: And it is proper to speak figuratively of the binding of illusions in passages such as Indra moves about with many forms through illusions.

original: ātmaivaikaḥ satyaḥ ici ca tasyaiva nityatvāducyate /
analyzed: ātmā eva ekaḥ satyaḥ ca tasya eva nitya tvāt ucyate
translated: And it is said that the Self alone is the one truth, because it alone is eternal.

original: yathā go aśvā eva paśavo 'nyetvapaśava iti tadevaṃ draṣṭavyam ////
analyzed: yathā go aśvāḥ eva paśavaḥ nyetu a paśavaḥ iti tat evam draṣṭavyam
translated: Just as cows and horses are animals, while others are non-animals, that is how it should be seen.

original: yastvevaṃvidhānvādānyathāśrutārthāngṛhṇāti sa paśvantareṣvapaśutvavādaṃ ādityo yūpaḥ ityādi ca yathāśrutaṃ gṛhṇīyāt /
analyzed: yaḥ tu evaṃvidhān vādān yathāśruta arthān gṛhṇāti sa paśu antareṣu apaśutva vādam ādityaḥ yūpaḥ ityādi ca yathāśrutam gṛhṇīyāt
translated: But one who takes such statements literally, as having the meaning heard, would take the statement about other animals being non-animals, and the sun is the sacrificial post, etc., literally.

analyzed: atha tatra pramāṇa antara virodhaḥ saḥ tra api samānaḥ
translated: Now, if there is contradiction with other means of knowledge in those cases, it is the same here.

analyzed: atha arthavāda tvāt tatra na yathāśruta artha grahaṇam
translated: Or, if the meaning is not to be taken literally there because it is a mere statement,

analyzed: tat api samānam
translated: that is also the same here.

analyzed: prapañcasya api asatya tvam vairāgya janana artham
translated: The unreality of the world is for the purpose of generating dispassion.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ ca parama artha tvam mumukṣūṇām utsāha janana artham
translated: And the ultimate reality of the Self is for the purpose of generating enthusiasm in those who desire liberation.

analyzed: vispaṣṭam ca etat mṛd piṇḍa vikāra dṛṣṭānta darśanāt
translated: And this is clearly seen from the example of the modifications of a lump of clay.

original: tataśca yathā kāraṇabhūtamṛtpiṇḍajñānena mṛnmayo vikāraḥ sarvo vijñāto bhavati śarāvādivikāro hi vācārambhaṇaṃ nāmadheyamātraṃ mṛttikasyaiva
analyzed: tatas ca yathā kāraṇa bhūta mṛd piṇḍa jñānena mṛd mayaḥ vikāraḥ sarvaḥ vijñātaḥ bhavati śarāva ādi vikāraḥ hi vācā ārambhaṇam nāmadheya mātram mṛttikasya eva
translated: And therefore, just as by the knowledge of the causal clay-ball, all modifications of clay become known, for the modifications like pot, etc. are mere verbal expressions, mere names, of clay itself,

analyzed: evam prapañcasya iva satyam
translated: in the same way, the world is real like clay.

original: evaṃ prapañcopi sadvijñānena vijñāto bhavati vikāro hi vācārambhaṇaṃ nāmadheyamātraṃ
analyzed: evam prapañcaḥ api sat vijñānena vijñātaḥ bhavati vikāraḥ hi vācā ārambhaṇam nāmadheya mātram
translated: Thus, the world also becomes known by the knowledge of the real. For the modifications are mere verbal expressions, mere names,

original: sadityeva satyamityukte jñāyata etat yathāvirbhāvatirobhāvadharmā nānāvidho vikāraḥ🔽śarāvādiḥ prapañco mṛttikā ca sarvatrānapāyinī teṣāṃ kāraṇaṃ kāryakāraṇayoścāvasthāmātrabhedātsvarūpabhedābhāvātkāraṇajñānena
analyzed: sat iti eva satyam iti ukte jñāyate etat yathā āvirbhāva tirobhāva dharmāḥ nānāvidhaḥ vikāraḥ  śarāva ādiḥ prapañcaḥ mṛttikā ca sarvatra anapāyinī teṣām kāraṇam kārya kāraṇayoḥ ca avasthā mātra bhedāt svarūpa bheda abhāvāt kāraṇa jñānena
translated: when it is said that only the real is true, it is understood that the various modifications which have the nature of manifestation and disappearance,

analyzed: tat sarvam kāryam avasthā bhedena ajñātam api sva rūpeṇa jñātam bhavati
translated: like the pot, etc., and the clay which is everywhere imperishable, are the cause of them. And by the knowledge of the cause, all that effect, though unknown in its different states, becomes known in its own nature, because there is no difference in the nature of the cause and effect, only a difference in their states.

original: tathā prapañcopyāvirbhāvatirobhāvadharmānavasthāyī tatkāraṇaṃ cātmā sadrūpaḥ sarvānuyāyī nāpāyadharmā /
analyzed: tathā prapañca upya āvirbhāva tirobhāva dharma anavasthāyī tad kāraṇam ca ātmā sat rūpaḥ sarva anuyāyī na apāya dharmā
translated: In the same way, the world also, which is not stable due to having the nature of manifestation and disappearance, and its cause, the Self, which is of the nature of existence, pervades everything and does not have the nature of destruction,🔽is known by the knowledge of the Self.

original: tasminvijñāte sarvaṃ tadātmakamavijñātamapi vyāsarūpeṇa samāsena jñātaṃ bhavatītyetadatra vivakṣitamiti /
analyzed: tasmin vijñāte sarvam tad ātmakam avijñātam api vyāsa rūpeṇa samāsena jñātam bhavati iti etat atra vivakṣitam iti
translated: When that is known, then all that, though unknown, becomes known in brief in the form of Vyāsa. This is what is intended here.

analyzed: tasmāt ekasya eva ātmanaḥ pariṇāmaḥ yam bheda prapañcaḥ nanu asan eva
translated: Therefore, this manifold universe of distinctions is indeed unreal, being only a transformation of the one Self.

original: asatve hi kathaṃ sadvijñānena vijñātaḥ syācchaśaviṣāṇavat /
analyzed: a satve hi katham sat vijñānena vijñātaḥ syāt śaśaviṣāṇa vat
translated: If it were unreal, how could it be known by the knowledge of the real, like the horn of a hare?

original: na hi mṛtpiṇḍe vijñāte sati śaśaviṣāṇaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavati tathā prapañcopi syāt /
analyzed: na hi mṛd piṇḍe vijñāte sati śaśa viṣāṇam vijñātam bhavati tathā prapañcaḥ api syāt
translated: For when a lump of clay is known, the horn of a hare does not become known. The same would be the case with the universe.

original: tatastu prastutahānireva syāt ekopyātmāntaḥkaraṇopādhibhedādbhinno jīva ityucyate jīvabhedācca bandhamuktivyavasthāpyupapanneti ////
analyzed: tatas tu prastuta hāniḥ eva syāt ekaḥ upi ātma antaḥkaraṇa upādhi bhedāt bhinnaḥ jīvaḥ iti ucyate jīva bhedāt ca bandha mukti vyavasthā api upapannā iti
translated: Then there would be a loss of the subject matter. Even one Self is called the individual soul, because of the difference of the internal organ as an adjunct. And because of the difference of individual souls, the establishment of bondage and liberation is logically possible.

analyzed: tat idam ayuktam
translated: This is not correct.

original: cidrūpasyātmano jaḍarūpapariṇāmāsaṃbhavāt /🔽ekatve cātmanaḥ sarvaśarīre me duḥkhamiti /
analyzed: cit rūpasya ātmanaḥ jaḍa rūpa pariṇāma asaṃbhavāt  eka tve ca ātmanaḥ sarva śarīre me duḥkham iti
translated: Because it is impossible for the Self, which is of the nature of consciousness, to transform into the nature of the insentient.🔽And if the Self were one, then just as one experiences pain in one's foot and head as one's own, so too one would experience all pleasure and pain as one's own.

original: pāde me mukhaṃ śirasi me vedanetivat sarvasukhaduḥkhopalabdhiśca syāt /
analyzed: pāde me mukham śirasi me vedanā iti vat sarva sukha duḥkha upalabdhiḥ ca syāt
translated: For example, one says I have pain in my foot and I have pain in my head.

analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa upādhi bhedāt abhinnaḥ jīvaḥ iti ucyate jīva bhedāt ca bandha mukti vyavasthā api upapannā iti
translated: It is said that the individual soul is non-different due to the difference in the internal organ as limiting adjunct, and the arrangement of bondage and liberation is logically established due to the difference in individual souls.

analyzed: tat idam ayuktam
translated: This is not correct.

analyzed: cit rūpasya ātmanaḥ jaḍa rūpa pariṇāma asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because it is impossible for the self, which is of the nature of consciousness, to transform into something of the nature of the insentient.

original: ekatve cātmanaḥ sarvaśarīreṣu pratasaṃdhānaṃ syāt devadatto 'haṃ yajñadatto 'hameveti /
analyzed: eka tve ca ātmanaḥ sarva śarīreṣu syāt devadattaḥ ham yajñadattaḥ ham eva iti
translated: And if the self were one, there would be a complete merging in all bodies, as in I am Devadatta, I am Yajnadatta.

original: tathā devadattaśarīre me sukhaṃ yajñadattaśarīre me duḥkhamiti /
analyzed: tathā devadatta śarīre me sukham yajñadatta śarīre me duḥkham iti
translated: Similarly, My happiness is in Devadatta's body, my pain is in Yajnadatta's body.

analyzed: pāde me sukham śirasi me
translated: My happiness is in the foot, my pain is in the head.

analyzed: vedanā iti vat sarva sukha duḥkha upalabdhiḥ ca syāt
translated: Like this, there would be the experience of all happiness and pain.

analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa bhedāt vyavasthā iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the arrangement is due to the difference in the internal organ,

analyzed: acetana tvāt
translated: that is not so, because it is insentient.

analyzed: na hi antaḥkaraṇam sukha duḥkhe anubhavati acetana tvāt
translated: The internal organ does not experience happiness and pain, because it is insentient.

original: ātmā tvanubhavitā sa ca sarvatraika iti kaḥ pratisaṃdhānaṃ vārayet /
analyzed: ātmā tu anubhavitā sa ca sarvatra ekaḥ iti kaḥ pratisaṃdhānam vārayet
translated: But the self is the experiencer, and that is one everywhere. Who can prevent the merging?

analyzed: tasmāt idam api na atīva sundaram iti
translated: Therefore, this is also not very beautiful.

analyzed: iti ātma pariṇāma vāda nirāsaḥ
translated: Thus ends the refutation of the doctrine of the transformation of the self.

analyzed: sāṃkhya matena pūrvapakṣaḥ
translated: The prima facie view is presented from the Sankhya point of view.

original: ātmabhedaṃ prakṛtipariṇāmaṃ ca jagat sāṃkhyā manyante /
analyzed: ātma bhedam prakṛti pariṇāmam ca jagat sāṃkhyāḥ manyante
translated: The Sankhyas consider the world to be a transformation of the self and the primordial matter.

original: dvividhaṃ ca sāṃkhyaṃ nirīśvaraṃ seśvaraṃ ca /
analyzed: dvividham ca sāṃkhyam nirīśvaram sa īśvaram ca
translated: And Sāṃkhya is of two kinds, with and without Īśvara.

original: nīrīśvaravādistāvagadāhuḥ prakṛtiracetanā triguṇātmikā pradhānaśabdābhidheya mahadādiviśeṣaparyantena prapañcarūpeṇa cetanānāmupabhogāya pariṇāmatīti
analyzed: prakṛtiḥ acetanā triguṇa ātmikā pradhāna śabda abhidheya mahat ādi viśeṣa paryantena prapañca rūpeṇa cetanānām upabhogāya pariṇāmati iti
translated: First, those who advocate the absence of Īśvara say: Prakriti, which is insentient and consists of the three guṇas, is denoted by the word pradhāna. It evolves into the form of the universe, from the great principle up to the specific, for the enjoyment of the sentient beings.

analyzed: sa īśvara vādinaḥ pi evam āhuḥ
translated: Those who advocate the presence of Īśvara also say this.

original: iyāṃstu viśeṣaḥ puruṣaśabdābhidheyamīśvaraṃ kleśakarmavipākāśayairaparāmṛṣṭamāśritya prakṛtirjagatsṛjatīti /🔽yathā hi saṃskṛtaṃ kṣetramadhiṣṭhāya tatsaṃparkavaśādbījamaṅkurādikrameṇa mahāntaṃ
analyzed: iyān tu viśeṣaḥ puruṣa śabda abhidheyam īśvaram kleśa karma vipāka āśayaiḥ aparāmṛṣṭam āśritya prakṛtiḥ jagat sṛjati iti  yathā hi saṃskṛtam kṣetram adhiṣṭhāya tad saṃparka vaśāt bījam aṅkura ādi krameṇa mahāntam
translated: However, there is this difference: Prakriti creates the world, relying on Īśvara, who is denoted by the word puruṣa, and is untouched by afflictions, actions, results, and latent impressions.🔽Just as a cultivated field, acting as the substratum, by the power of its contact, the seed produces a great tree through the stages of sprout, etc.,

analyzed: vṛkṣam ārabhate tathā sarva vyāpinī prakṛtiḥ tad saṃparka vaśāt mahat ahaṅkāra tanmātra ādi krameṇa
translated: in the same way, Prakriti, which pervades everything, by the power of its contact, evolves through the stages of the great principle, ego, subtle elements, etc.,

analyzed: pariṇamantī viśeṣa antam prapañcam ārabhace iti
translated: and produces the universe up to the specific.

analyzed: itihāsa purāṇeṣu api prāyeṇa etat eva matam
translated: And this view is generally accepted in the Itihāsas and Purāṇas.

analyzed: sā iyam prakṛti upādānā sṛṣṭiḥ
translated: This creation is based on Prakriti.

analyzed: īśvaraḥ tu nimitta mātram
translated: But Īśvara is merely the instrumental cause.

analyzed: kṣetrajñāḥ tu bhoktāraḥ
translated: And the individual souls are the enjoyers.

analyzed: prakṛtiḥ eva tu sarva kāryāṇām kartrī iti bhogyā
translated: But Nature itself is the agent of all effects, and so is the object of enjoyment.

original: sā ca sarvatraikā bhoktṝṇāṃ ca bhedādbaddhamuktavyavasthopapattiḥ /
analyzed: sā ca sarvatra ekā bhoktṝṇām ca bhedāt baddha mukta vyavasthā upapattiḥ
translated: And that is the same everywhere, and the distinction of the enjoyers leads to the establishment of the bound and the liberated.

original: tathā ca ajāmekāṃ lohitaśuklakṛṣṇāṃ bahvīḥ prajā janayantīṃ sarūpāḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca ajām ekām lohita śukla kṛṣṇām bahvīḥ prajāḥ janayantīm sarūpāḥ
translated: And thus: She who is unborn, one, red, white, and black, giving birth to many beings of the same form.🔽For the unborn one, delighting, lies down; another unborn one, having enjoyed, abandons her.

original: ajo hyeko juṣamāṇo 'nuśete jahātyenāṃ bhuktabhogamajo 'nyaḥ iti vyaktameva bhogyāyāḥ dāstarhyaipaniṣadāḥ kathaṃ /
analyzed: ajaḥ hi ekaḥ juṣamāṇaḥ nuśete jahāti enām bhukta bhogam ajaḥ nyaḥ iti vyaktam eva bhogyāyāḥ dāḥ tarhi aipaniṣadāḥ katham
translated: Thus it is clearly stated that the object of enjoyment is the same. Then how are the non-Upanishad-knowing ones?

original: availakṣaṇyeneti brūmaḥ bhedaśabdo hi vailakṣaṇyavacano loke prasiddhaḥ /
analyzed: a vailakṣaṇyena iti brūmaḥ bheda śabdaḥ hi vailakṣaṇya vacanaḥ loke prasiddhaḥ
translated: We say by non-distinction. For in the world, the word difference is well-known to express distinction.

analyzed: tathā hi su sadṛśeṣu vaktāraḥ bhavanti
translated: Thus, when speaking of things that are very similar, people say:

analyzed: na asya asya ca kaścid bhedaḥ sti iti
translated: There is no difference at all between this and that.

analyzed: tathā ātmanām api nara paśu tiryak bheda bhinna śarīra vartinām śarīra saṃbandham apohya kevalam
translated: Similarly, for the souls also, residing in bodies distinguished by the difference of human, animal, and lower species, having excluded the connection with the body, and being examined only

analyzed: naija rūpeṇa nirūpyamāṇānām padma rajaḥ paramāṇu dvaya vat na kiñcid api vailakṣaṇyam asti iti anena abhiprāyeṇa ekatva vādāḥ
translated: in their own nature, like the pollen of a lotus and a particle, there is not the slightest distinction. With this intention, the doctrines of oneness

analyzed: nānātva niṣedha vādāḥ ca
translated: and the denial of plurality.

original: etadabhiprāyameva caitadapi bhadavadvāsudevavacanam vidyāvinayasaṃpanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini /
analyzed: etad abhiprāyam eva ca etat api bhadavat vāsudeva vacanam vidyā vinaya saṃpanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini
translated: And this statement of the venerable Vāsudeva also has this very meaning: The wise see with equal vision a Brahmin endowed with learning and humility, a cow, an elephant,

original: śuni caiva śvapāke ca paṇḍitāḥ samadarśinaḥ iti /🔽tathaiva indro māyābhiḥ pururūpa īryate iti svayamavilakṣaṇo 'pyātmā narapaśvādivicitraśarīrasaṃparkavaśādbhrāntyā svayamapi vilakṣaṇarūpaḥ
analyzed: śuni ca eva śvapāke ca paṇḍitāḥ sama darśinaḥ iti  tathā eva indraḥ māyābhiḥ puru rūpaḥ īryate iti svayam avilakṣaṇaḥ pi ātmā nara paśu ādi vicitra śarīra saṃparka vaśāt bhrāntyā svayam api vilakṣaṇa rūpaḥ  /
translated: a dog, and an outcaste.

analyzed: pratīyate iti arthaḥ
translated: Similarly, Indra is said to be manifested with many forms by his magical powers. The meaning is that although the Self is not different by itself, due to contact with various bodies of men, animals, etc., it is mistakenly perceived as having a different form by itself.

analyzed: ye ca bhuktānām kṣetrajñānām īśvareṇa saha ekatvāt āste pi atyanta sāmyāt vailakṣaṇya abhāvāt ca
translated: And those who are absorbed in the Kṣetrajñas who have enjoyed, due to identity with the Lord, also due to absolute similarity and lack of difference,

analyzed: tathā ca śruti antaram
translated: and thus another Śruti says:

original: yadā paśyaḥ paśyate rukmavarṇaṃ kartāramīśaṃ puruṣaṃ brahmayonim //
analyzed: yadā paśyaḥ paśyate rukma varṇam kartāram īśam puruṣam brahma yonim
translated: When the seer sees the golden-hued creator, the Lord, the Person, the source of Brahman,

original: tadā vidvānpuṇyapāpe vidhūya nirañcanaḥ paramaṃ sāmyamupaiti itīśvarasādṛśyāpattimeva muktasya darśayati /
analyzed: tadā vidvān puṇya pāpe vidhūya nirañcanaḥ paramam sāmyam upaiti iti īśvara sādṛśya āpattim eva muktasya darśayati
translated: then the wise one, having shaken off merit and demerit, free from attachment, attains the highest equality, it shows that the liberated one attains identity with the Lord.

original: tathā bhagavatā vāsudevenāpyuktam idaṃ jñānamupāśritya mama sādharmyamāgatāḥ //
analyzed: tathā bhagavatā vāsudevena api uktam idam jñānam upāśritya mama sādharmyam āgatāḥ
translated: Similarly, the Lord Vāsudeva also said: Having resorted to this knowledge, they have come to be of the same nature as me.

original: sarge 'pi nopajāyante pralaye na vyathanti ca iti ////
analyzed: sarge pi na upajāyante pralaye na vyathanti ca iti
translated: They are not born even at the beginning of creation, nor do they perish at the time of dissolution.

original: yattu mamaivāṃśo jīvaloke jīvabhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ iti bhagavadvacanaṃ tatsvāmibhṛtyabhāvaparam yathā khalvamātyā rājñoṃśā vyapadiśyante tathā
analyzed: yat tu mama eva aṃśaḥ jīva loke jīva bhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ iti bhagavat vacanam tat svāmi bhṛtya bhāva param yathā khalu amātyāḥ rājñaḥ oṃśāḥ vyapadiśyante tathā
translated: As for the statement of the Lord, My portion, eternal, has become the individual soul in the world of living beings, that refers to the relation of master and servant. Just as ministers are called portions of the king,

analyzed: iti ucyate
translated: so the individual soul is said to be a portion of the Lord.

analyzed: anyathā jīva tva nāśāt sanātana tva anupapattiḥ
translated: Otherwise, because of the indestructibility of the individual soul, its eternality would be impossible.

analyzed: yāni api vibheda janake jñāne nāśam ātyantikam gate
translated: And those statements of the Puranas, such as When the knowledge that produces distinctions has been utterly destroyed,

original: ātmano brahmaṇo bhedamasantaṃ kaḥ kariṣyati ityādīni purāṇavacanāni teṣāyamevārthaḥ
analyzed: ātmanaḥ brahmaṇaḥ bhedam asantam kaḥ kariṣyati ityādīni purāṇa vacanāni teṣām ayam eva arthaḥ
translated: who will make the non-existent distinction of the individual soul and Brahman? - their meaning is this:

analyzed: vailakṣaṇyam ātmanaḥ brahmaṇaḥ ca anyatvam atyantam avidyamānam eva ajñāna nimittam ajñāne vinaṣṭe
translated: The difference between the individual soul and Brahman, which is utterly non-existent, is due to ignorance. When ignorance is destroyed,

analyzed: svayam eva vilīyate iti
translated: it dissolves by itself.

original: vispaṣṭaṃ hi parāparapuruṣayorbhede gītādipūpadarśitaḥ uttamaḥ puruṣastvanyaḥ paramātmetyudāhṛtaḥ /
analyzed: vispaṣṭam hi para apara puruṣayoḥ bhede gītā ādipu upadarśitaḥ uttamaḥ puruṣaḥ tu anyaḥ paramātmā iti udāhṛtaḥ
translated: For the difference between the higher and lower persons is clearly shown in the Gita and other scriptures. The highest person is said to be different, the supreme Self.

analyzed: ca kartā bhoktā maheśvaraḥ
translated: He is the one who approves of the six sense objects, the agent, the enjoyer, the great Lord.

analyzed: paramātmā iti ca api uktaḥ dehe smin puruṣaḥ paraḥ iti
translated: And it is also said that the Supreme Self is the highest Person in this body.

analyzed: alam ati dūram gatvā
translated: Let us stop going too far.

analyzed: tasmāt prakṛti upādānā iyam prapañca sṛṣṭiḥ iti na an upādāna upālambhaḥ
translated: Therefore, the creation of the universe is dependent on primordial matter. There is no fault of criticizing what is not a cause.

original: sāṃkhyamatakhaṇḍanam /🔽atrābhidhīyate kathaṃ khalvekarūpā prakṛtirnarapaśutiryagbhedabhinnaṃ prapañcamārabhate nahyavilakṣaṇaṃ
analyzed: sāṃkhya mata khaṇḍanam  atra abhidhīyate katham khalu eka rūpā prakṛtiḥ nara paśu tiryak bheda bhinnam prapañcam ārabhate na hi avilakṣaṇam
translated: Refutation of the Sāṃkhya view.

analyzed: kāraṇam vilakṣaṇam kāryam nirmātum arhati
translated: Here it is said: How can primordial matter, which is of one form, produce the universe which is differentiated into men, animals, and insects? For a non-different cause cannot produce a different effect.

analyzed: kṣetrajña gata dharma adharma sahāya vaicitryāt vaicitryam ita ced  na
translated: If it is argued that the diversity is due to the diversity of the virtues and vices belonging to the individual souls, it is not so.

analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa vṛtti tvāt dharma adarmayoḥ
translated: Because virtue and vice belong to the modifications of the internal organ.

original: antakaraṇasya ca kāryavargāntaḥpātitvāt sarvasya mahadādeḥ kāryasya prākṛtapratisaṃcāre
analyzed: anta karaṇasya ca kārya varga antaḥpāti tvāt sarvasya mahat ādeḥ kāryasya prākṛta pratisaṃcāre
translated: And because the internal organ is included among the effects, and because all effects beginning with Mahat, on the dissolution of the world,

original: prakṛtau vilīnatvāddharmādharmāvapi tasyāmavasthāyāmavidyamānāveveti na tadbalena vaicitryam /
analyzed: prakṛtau vilīna tvāt dharma adharmau api tasyām avasthāyām avidyamānau eva iti na tad balena vaicitryam
translated: merge into primordial matter, therefore virtue and vice also do not exist in that state, and hence there is no diversity due to their power.

analyzed: mahat ādi vikāra ārambhe ca asyāḥ kim kāraṇam
translated: And what is the cause of the origin of the modifications beginning with Mahat?

analyzed: svarūpam evā iti ced sarvadā ārambha prasaṅgaḥ tatas pralaya anupapattiḥ
translated: If it is said to be its own nature, then there would be the contingence of origination at all times, and hence dissolution would be impossible.

analyzed: īśvara icchayā vikriyate na
translated: If it be said that it is modified by the will of God, no.

analyzed: īśvarasya samasta kleśa rahitasya apāsta samasta kāmasya icchā asaṃbhāvāt
translated: Because the will of God, who is free from all afflictions and has abandoned all desires, is not possible.

analyzed: icchāyāḥ ca api antaḥkaraṇa dharma tvāt tasmin kāle tad asaṃbhavāt
translated: And because will is a property of the internal organ, it is not possible at that time.

analyzed: kiñca prākṛte pralaye prakṛta mātram ātmānaḥ ca kevalam avatiṣṭhante
translated: Moreover, in the natural dissolution, only the primordial matter and the souls remain alone.

analyzed: sarve ca ātmānaḥ nirviśeṣāḥ sarveṣām caitanya mātra rūpa tvāt
translated: And all souls are without distinction, because they are of the nature of pure consciousness.

analyzed: na ca dharma adharma kṛtam api vailakṣaṇyam ātmānām saṃbhavati
translated: And no difference among the souls can be due to merit and demerit.

analyzed: tayoḥ ātma dharma tva abhāvāt
translated: Because merit and demerit are not properties of the soul.

analyzed: antaḥkaraṇa vṛtti tvāt tasya ca tadānīm abhāvāt iti uktam
translated: It has been said that they are properties of the internal organ, and that is not possible at that time.

original: evaṃ ca dharmādharmarahiteṣu nirviśeśeṣu puruṣeṣvavasthiteṣu sargakāle prakṛtiḥ śarīrārambheṇātmano badhnātīti cet /
analyzed: evam ca dharma adharma rahiteṣu puruṣeṣu avasthiteṣu sarga kāle prakṛtiḥ śarīra ārambheṇa ātmanaḥ badhnāti iti ced
translated: And if it be said that when the souls are thus existing without merit and demerit and without distinction, at the time of creation, primordial matter binds the souls by beginning the formation of bodies,

analyzed: ye pūrva sṛṣṭau sthitāḥ
translated: then all those who existed in the previous creation,

original: ye ca brahmahatyākāriṇasteṣāṃ sarveṣāmaikavidhyameva syāt pūrvakṛtayordharmādharmayornaṣṭatvat ////
analyzed: ye ca brahmahatyā kāriṇaḥ teṣām sarveṣām aikavidhyam eva syāt pūrva kṛtayoḥ dharma adharmayoḥ naṣṭa tvat
translated: and all those who have committed the sin of Brahmanicide, would all be of the same nature, because the merit and demerit previously done would have perished.

original: nanu nāśo nāma nātyantābhāvaḥ kintu kāraṇe kāryāṇāṃ tirobhāvamātraṃ vināśaḥ /
analyzed: nanu nāśaḥ nāma na atyanta abhāvaḥ kintu kāraṇe kāryāṇām tirobhāva mātram vināśaḥ
translated: But destruction is not absolute non-existence, rather destruction is the mere concealment of effects in their cause.

original: utpattirapi vidyamānānameva kāraṇe kāryāṇāmāvirbhavamātraṃ sarvaṃ kāryāṇāṃ na syāt /
analyzed: utpattiḥ api kāraṇe kāryāṇām āvirbhava mātram sarvam kāryāṇām na syāt
translated: And origination is also the mere manifestation of existing effects in their cause. All effects would not be.

analyzed: tantubhyaḥ paṭaḥ mṛttaḥ ghaṭaḥ iti
translated: From threads, a cloth; from clay, a pot.

analyzed: yathā āhuḥ asat akaraṇāt upādāna grahaṇāt sarva saṃbhava abhāvāt
translated: As they say: Because what is non-existent cannot be produced, because the material cause is grasped, because everything is not possible,

analyzed: śaktasya śakya karaṇāt kāraṇa bhāvāt ca satkāryam iti
translated: Because what is capable can produce what is capable, and because of the existence of the cause, the effect exists.

original: tathā nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ iti bhagavadvāsudevavacanam /
analyzed: tathā na asataḥ vidyate bhāvaḥ na abhāvaḥ vidyate sataḥ iti bhagavat vāsudeva vacanam
translated: Similarly, the statement of Lord Vasudeva: There is no existence of what is non-existent, nor non-existence of what is existent.

analyzed: tasmāt pralaye dharma ādeḥ śakti ātma anavasthita tvāt tad vaśena yuktam sṛṣṭi vaicitryam
translated: Therefore, at the time of dissolution, because Dharma etc. exist in the form of potency, it is proper that the variety of creation is due to that.

original: naitadevam na hi mṛtpiṇḍāvasthāyāṃ vā kapālāvasthāyāṃ vā ghaṭarūpamasti dṛśyādarśanavirodhāt ////
analyzed: na etat evam na hi mṛd piṇḍa avasthāyām vā kapāla avasthāyām vā ghaṭa rūpam asti dṛśya adarśana virodhāt
translated: This is not so. For the form of a pot does not exist in the state of a lump of clay or in the state of a shard, because of the contradiction of the non-perception of what is visible.

original: yattu nāsato vidyate bhāvaḥ iti vacanaṃ tadātmābhiprāyaṃ /
analyzed: yat tu na asataḥ vidyate bhāvaḥ iti vacanam tat ātma abhiprāyam
translated: As for the statement There is no existence of what is non-existent, that is with reference to the self.

original: pūrvatra hi natvevāhaṃ jātu nāsaṃ na tvaṃ neme janādhipāḥ //
analyzed: pūrvatra hi na tvā iva aham jātu na āsam na tvam na ime janādhipāḥ
translated: For in the previous verse it is said: Verily, I never was not, nor thou, nor these all kings;

analyzed: na ca eva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayam atas param
translated: And we all will not cease to exist after this.

analyzed: iti ātma nitya tvam
translated: Thus, this is said to establish the eternality of the self,

original: pratipādayitumupakrāntamevānenocyate nāvidyamānasyātmana utpattirna vidyamānasya vināśaḥ sarve evātmano 'nutpattivināśadharmāṇo nityā iti /
analyzed: pratipādayitum upakrāntam eva anena ucyate na a vidyamānasya ātmanaḥ utpattiḥ na vidyamānasya vināśaḥ sarve eva ātmanaḥ n utpatti vināśa dharmāṇaḥ nityāḥ iti
translated: which is being undertaken. The self, which does not exist, does not arise. The self, which exists, does not perish. All selves have the nature of non-arising and non-perishing, and are eternal.

analyzed: na punar kārya jātasya sarvasya nitya tva abhiprāyam
translated: It does not mean that the entire class of effects is eternal.

analyzed: asarvagata tvāt anupalabdhi virodhāt ca iti uktam
translated: It has been said that this is because they are not omnipresent and because of the contradiction with non-apprehension.

original: yadi paramupādānopādeyayorabhedamāśritya mṛdātmanādau ghaṭo vyavasthita ityucyate /
analyzed: yadi param upādāna upādeyayoḥ abhedam āśritya mṛd ātmanā ādau ghaṭaḥ vyavasthitaḥ iti ucyate
translated: If it is said that the pot exists in the form of clay from the beginning, relying on the non-difference of the primary and the derived,

analyzed: na ca tāvatā kārya siddhiḥ
translated: and the effect is not established by that alone.

analyzed: nahi mṛd avasthena ghaṭe na udaka āharaṇam kriyate
translated: For the pot in the state of clay does not perform the function of carrying water.

original: tathā dharmādharmāvapi svarūpeṇāvidyamānau prakṛtyātmanā sthitāvapi na svakāryāya paryāpyāviti na tadvaśena vaicitryasaṃbhavaḥ /
analyzed: tathā dharma adharmau api sva rūpeṇa avidyamānau prakṛti ātmanā sthitau api na sva kāryāya paryāpyau iti na tad vaśena vaicitrya saṃbhavaḥ
translated: Similarly, even though dharma and adharma exist in the form of prakṛti, they are not sufficient for their own effect, so diversity cannot arise under their control.

original: pramāṇamapi mahadādikrameṇa prakṛtipariṇāme kiñcinnāsti puruṣavacasāṃ pramāṇāntaragocarārthe pramāṇatvāsaṃbhavāt /
analyzed: pramāṇam api mahat ādi krameṇa prakṛti pariṇāme kiñcid nā asti puruṣa vacasām pramāṇa antara gocara arthe pramāṇa tva asaṃbhavāt
translated: And there is no pramāṇa at all in the transformation of prakṛti through the stages of mahat and so on, because the statements of the puruṣa cannot be pramāṇa with regard to an object that is the domain of another pramāṇa.

analyzed: vedānām api poruṣeya tvāt itara puruṣa vacana vat apramāṇyāt
translated: Because the Vedas are also composed by a person, like the words of other persons, they are not a means of valid knowledge.

original: yadi cu sṛṣṭipralayaparamparāmanādimaṅgīkṛtya pratisṛṣṭi sarveṣāṃ caiva nāmāni karmāṇi ca pṛthakpṛthak /
analyzed: yadi cu sṛṣṭi pralaya paramparām anādim aṅgīkṛtya pratisṛṣṭi sarveṣām ca eva nāmāni karmāṇi ca pṛthak pṛthak
translated: If, accepting the beginningless series of creation and dissolution, and at the beginning of each creation, all the names and actions separately,

original: vedaśabdebhya evādau pṛthaksaṃsthāśca nirmame ityādivacanaiḥ ṛtuliṅganyāyena nāmaprabhāvavyavahāravastūtpattyā
analyzed: veda śabdebhyaḥ eva ādau pṛthak saṃsthāḥ ca nirmame ityādi vacanaiḥ ṛtu liṅga nyāyena nāma prabhāva vyavahāra vastu utpattyā
translated: and the separate arrangements from the Vedic words alone, and so on, by the principle of the signs of the seasons, by the origin of the objects of the usage of names and their effects,

analyzed: śabdānām anādi artha saṃbaddhānām vedānām ca nitya tvam āśritya prāmāṇyam aṅgīkriyate
translated: and by relying on the eternity of the Vedas, whose words are eternally connected with their meanings, if validity is accepted,

analyzed: tathā api ekasya prajāpateḥ saṃpradāya pravartaka tve kṛtaka āśaṅkā syāt eva
translated: even then, in the case of a single Prajapati, the doubt of being the author would arise.

original: atha punaḥ aṣṭāśītisahasrāṇi saṃpradāyapravartakāḥ ityādivacanānurodhena bahūnāṃ
analyzed: atha punar aṣṭāśīti sahasrāṇi saṃpradāya pravartakāḥ ityādi vacana anurodhena bahūnām
translated: But again, in accordance with the statement that there are 88,000 propagators of the tradition, and so on, by many

original: maharṣīṇāṃ sṛṣṭyantarādhītaṃ vedaṃ smaratāṃ suptapratibuddhanyāyena saṃpradāyapravartakatvamāśritya
analyzed: mahā ṛṣīṇām sṛṣṭi antara adhītam vedam smaratām supta pratibuddha nyāyena saṃpradāya pravartaka tvam āśritya
translated: great sages remembering the Vedas studied in other creations, by relying on being the propagators of the tradition by the principle of one awakened from sleep,

analyzed: kṛtaka āśaṅkām nirasya nitya tā samarthyeta
translated: having refuted the doubt of being the author, eternity is established.

analyzed: tathā api anupādānām jagat nirmāṇam aśakyam abhyupagantum
translated: Still, it is impossible to accept the creation of the world without a material cause.

analyzed: prakṛti ādīnām hi upādāna tvam nirastam
translated: For the status of primordial matter and so on as the material cause has been refuted.

analyzed: aupaniṣadāḥ tu sṛṣṭi pralaya vādāḥ paurāṇikāḥ ca artha vāda tayā netavyāḥ
translated: But the doctrines of creation and dissolution set forth in the Upaniṣads and the Purāṇas should be interpreted as mere eulogies.

analyzed: bhavatu ca evam tathā api na asmākam kācid kṣatiḥ
translated: And even if this is so, we suffer no harm.

analyzed: saṃbandha nitya tva veda prāmāṇyayoḥ avighātāt
translated: Because the eternality of the relation and the validity of the Veda are not contradicted.

analyzed: iti sāṃkhya mata nirāsaḥ
translated: Thus ends the refutation of the Sāṃkhya view.

analyzed: vaiśeṣika matena pūrvapakṣaḥ
translated: The prima facie view using the Vaiśeṣika view.

analyzed: vaiśeṣikāḥ tu pauruṣeya tvam eva śabda artha saṃbandhānām vedānām ca aṅgīkurvantaḥ numānena
translated: But the Vaiśeṣikas, accepting the authorship of words and meanings and the Vedas, infer

original: sṛṣṭipralayāvīśvaraṃ ca siṣādhayiṣantaḥ prayogamāracayanti trividhaṃ hi vastujātaṃ
analyzed: sṛṣṭi pralayau īśvaram ca siṣādhayiṣantaḥ prayogam āracayanti trividham hi vastu jātam
translated: and seek to establish God as the creator and destroyer, they formulate the argument. For the class of entities is threefold,

analyzed: saṃpratipanna cetana kartṛkam ghaṭa ādi  saṃpratipanna a tad kartṛkam vyoma ādi
translated: the pot and so on, which are accepted as having an intelligent agent,🔽the sky and so on, which are accepted as not having that [agent],

analyzed: vipratipanna tad kartṛkam mahī mahīdhara dūrvā aṅkura ādi
translated: and the earth, mountains, durvā grass sprouts and so on, which are disputed as to having that [agent].

analyzed: tatra antimam adhikṛtya ucyate kṣiti ādikam buddhimat kartṛkam kāryatvāt ghaṭa ādi vat
translated: With regard to the last, it is said: The earth and so on have an intelligent agent as their maker, because they are effects, like a pot and so on.

analyzed: kāryatvam ca kṣiti ādeḥ sāvayavatvāt ghaṭa ādi vat
translated: And the fact that earth, etc., are effects is due to their being composed of parts, like a pot, etc.

analyzed: kim punar pṛthivī ādeḥ samavāyi kāraṇam
translated: What, again, is the inherent cause of earth, etc.?

analyzed: pārthiva āpya taijasa vāyīya paramāṇu jātam yathāsvam pṛthivī ap tejaḥ vāyūnām samavāyi kāraṇam
translated: The classes of earth, water, fire, and air atoms are the inherent causes of earth, water, fire, and air respectively.

original: na hi pralaye paramāṇūnāṃ pralayo 'smākamasti sāṃkhyādivat /
analyzed: na hi pralaye paramāṇūnām pralayaḥ smākam asti sāṃkhya ādi vat
translated: For us, there is no dissolution of atoms at the time of cosmic dissolution, as for the Sāṃkhyas and others.

original: kāryadravyāṇi tu dvyaṇukādīni sarvāṇyeveśvarecchayā viśliṣṭāvayavāni pralīyante /
analyzed: kārya dravyāṇi tu dvyaṇuka ādīni sarvāṇi eva īśvara icchayā viśliṣṭa avayavāni pralīyante
translated: But all the resultant substances, beginning with dyads, dissolve into the separated parts by the will of God.

analyzed: paramāṇavaḥ tu mithas saṃyuktāḥ tiṣṭhanti vyoma ādayaḥ ca kṣetrajñāḥ ca ātmīya dharma adharma yuktāḥ eva avatiṣṭhante
translated: The atoms remain uncombined with each other, and space, etc., and the individual souls remain with their own inherent qualities and faults.

original: sargakāle punarīśvarecchāṃ kṣetrajñādṛṣṭaṃ ca nimittamāsādya paramāṇuṣu karmāṇyutpadyante
analyzed: sarga kāle punar īśvara icchām kṣetrajña adṛṣṭam ca nimittam āsādya paramāṇuṣu karmāṇi utpadyante
translated: At the time of creation, actions arise in the atoms due to the will of God and the unseen force of the individual souls,

original: tadvaśācca mithaḥ saṃyuktāścatuṣṭayepi paramāṇalo dvyaṇukādikrameṇa yathāsvaṃ pṛthivyādikaṃ
analyzed: tad vaśāt ca mithas saṃyuktāḥ catuṣṭaye api paramāṇalaḥ dvi aṇuka ādi krameṇa yathāsvam pṛthivī ādikam
translated: and by their power, the atoms combine with each other in pairs, and in the four, they produce earth, etc., according to their nature, in the order of dyads, etc.

analyzed: bhūta catuṣṭayam ārabhante
translated: They produce the four elements.

analyzed: nimita bhūta kṣetrajña adṛṣṭa vaicitryāt ca jarāyu ja aṇḍa ja udbhid ja sveda ja bhinnam śarīra bhedam īśvara icchā kārita saṃyoga viśeṣa vaśāt paramāṇavaḥ ārabhante
translated: And from the diversity of the souls, which are the causes of the marks, they produce the different kinds of bodies, born from wombs, eggs, moisture, or spontaneously, by the power of the particular conjunctions brought about by the will of God.

analyzed: vaiśeṣika mata khaṇḍanam
translated: Refutation of the Vaiśeṣika view.

original: nanvedapi yuktam nahīcchāmātreṇa prayatnamantareṇa paramāṇuṣu spandotpattiḥ saṃbhavati /
analyzed: nanu etat api yuktam nahi icchā mātreṇa prayatnam antareṇa paramāṇuṣu spanda utpattiḥ saṃbhavati
translated: But this is also proper. For without effort, mere will cannot produce vibration in the atoms.

analyzed: icchā kārita prayatna vaśena śarīra spanda utpattiḥ adya tve pi dṛśyate
translated: Even now, the vibration of the body is seen to arise by the power of effort produced by the will.

analyzed: īśvaraḥ api prayatate iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that God also exerts, no.

analyzed: aśarīrasya prayatna asaṃbhavāt
translated: Because effort is impossible for a bodiless one.

original: sarvagatā api hyātmānaḥ śarīrapradeśa eva prayatnamārabhante na bahiḥ /
analyzed: sarva gatāḥ api hi ātmānaḥ śarīra pradeśe eva prayatnam ārabhante na bahis
translated: Even the omnipresent souls produce effort only in the parts of the body, not outside.

analyzed: atas śarīra apekṣaḥ prayatnaḥ
translated: Therefore, effort depends on the body.

original: pralayakāle ca sarvakāryāṇāṃ pralayādīśvaraśarīramapi pralīnamiti kathamaśarīraḥ prayateta /
analyzed: pralaya kāle ca sarva kāryāṇām pralayāt īśvara śarīram api pralīnam iti katham aśarīraḥ prayateta
translated: And at the time of dissolution, even the body of God dissolves due to the dissolution of all effects. How could a bodiless one exert?

analyzed: na ca aśarīrasya icchā api saṃbhavati mukta ātmanām iva
translated: And will is also not possible for a bodiless one, like for the liberated souls.

analyzed: na api jñānam saṃbhavati indriya ādeḥ abhāvāt
translated: Nor is knowledge possible, due to the absence of the senses and so on.

original: nityamasya jñānaṃ nityā cecchā nityaśca prayatna iti cet / na /
analyzed: nityam asya jñānam nityā ca icchā nityaḥ ca prayatnaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be said that his knowledge is eternal, his will is eternal, and his effort is eternal,—no (says the other party).

analyzed: sarva jñāna icchā prayatnānām anitya tva vyāpteḥ
translated: For the eternality of knowledge, will and effort are incompatible.

original: śakyate hi prayoktum kṣityādikaṃ nāśarīricetanakartṛkaṃ na nityaprayatnanityecchānityajñānakartṛkaṃ kāryatvāt ghaṭavaditi ////
analyzed: śakyate hi prayoktum kṣiti ādikam na aśarīri cetana kartṛkam na nitya prayatna nitya icchā nitya jñāna kartṛkam kārya tvāt ghaṭa vat iti
translated: For it is possible to argue thus: Earth, etc., are not produced by a non-embodied intelligent being, nor by one whose effort, will, and knowledge are eternal, because they are effects, like a jar.

analyzed: nanu ghaṭasya api īśvara kartṛkatvam asti eva iti sādhya hīnaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ
translated: But it may be said that the jar also has God as its maker, and so the example is devoid of the probandum.

analyzed: tathā api kulālasya api kartṛ tvāt na kevala īśvara kartṛka tvam ghaṭasya
translated: Even so, since the potter also is a maker, the jar is not made by God alone.

original: tataścaivaṃ prayoktavyaṃ kṣityādikaṃ na kevalāśarīryātmādikartṛkaṃ ghaṭāvaditi /
analyzed: tatas ca evam prayoktavyam kṣiti ādikam na kevala aśarīrya ātma ādi kartṛkam ghaṭa āvat iti
translated: Therefore, it should be argued thus: Earth, etc., are not made by an unembodied self alone, like a jar.

analyzed: vastu tvāt vyoma ādi vat iti hetu dṛśa ṣṭāntau sarvathā api
translated: But the reason and the example, viz., because they are entities, like the sky, etc., are entirely faultless.

original: tathā kṣityādikaṃ na buddhimatkartṛkaṃ śarīrikartṛkatvavirahāt vyomavaditi sākṣādeva pratisādhanaṃ kartavyam /
analyzed: tathā kṣiti ādikam na buddhimat kartṛkam śarīri kartṛkatva virahāt vyoma vat iti sākṣāt eva pratisādhanam kartavyam
translated: Similarly, it should be directly argued thus: Earth, etc., are not made by an intelligent being, because they are devoid of being made by an embodied being, like the sky.

analyzed: atha īśvara śarīram nityam aṅgīkṛtya pralaye sa śarīram eva īśvaram abhyupagacchet
translated: Now, if one accepts that God's body is eternal and even at the time of dissolution God has a body,

original: tataḥ sāvayavatvamīśvaraśarīre naikāntikaṃ na kṣityādeḥ kāryatvaṃ sādhayet /
analyzed: tatas sāvayavatvam īśvara śarīre na aikāntikam na kṣiti ādeḥ kāryatvam sādhayet
translated: Therefore, the fact that God's body has parts is inconclusive and cannot prove that the earth and so on are effects.

analyzed: sa śarīra kartṛka tvam ca dūrvā aṅkura ādīnām anupapannam anupalabdhi virodhāt
translated: And the fact that they are produced by a body-possessing agent is impossible, because it contradicts perception.

analyzed: kiñca prati kāryam prayatna bhedena bhavitavyam
translated: Moreover, there must be a difference in effort for each effect.

original: anyo hi pādasaṃcaraṇe prayatnaḥ anyaśca bāhūddharaṇe /
analyzed: anyaḥ hi pāda saṃcaraṇe prayatnaḥ anyaḥ ca bāhu uddharaṇe
translated: For the effort in moving the feet is different from that in raising the arms.

original: tathā sati yadyapīśvare prayatno nityaḥ syāttathāpi tasyaikatvānna vicitrakāryodayahetutvaṃ saṃbhavatīti vyartha evāsau /
analyzed: tathā sati yadi api īśvare prayatnaḥ nityaḥ syāt tathā api tasya eka tvāt na vicitra kārya udaya hetu tvam saṃbhavati iti vyarthaḥ eva asau
translated: Even if effort in God were eternal, still, because it is one, it cannot be the cause of the arising of various effects. Therefore, it is useless.

analyzed: yadi tu ananta kārya anurūpā anantā sarga kāle pi avasthānāt
translated: But if there are infinite efforts corresponding to infinite effects, even at the time of creation,

original: saṃyojakasya ca sargahetoḥ pralayakālepyavasthānāt ubhayoḥ parasparavidhātānna sṛṣṭiḥ syāt na pralayaḥ /
analyzed: saṃyojakasya ca sarga hetoḥ pralaya kāle ipi avasthānāt ubhayoḥ sṛṣṭiḥ syāt na pralayaḥ
translated: and if the connector, which is the cause of creation, exists even at the time of dissolution, then due to the mutual contradiction of the two, there would be neither creation nor dissolution.

analyzed: yat ca kṣetrajña adṛṣṭa vaicitrya upapattiḥ iti
translated: And the explanation that the diversity of effects is due to the diversity of unseen forces of individual souls.

analyzed: tat api ayuktam nahi dṛṣṭa kāraṇa vailakṣaṇī antareṇa adṛṣṭa vailakṣaṇya mātrāt kārya vailakṣaṇyam siddhi ati
translated: That is also incorrect. For the diversity of effects is not established merely from the diversity of unseen forces without the diversity of seen causes.

analyzed: na hi adṛṣṭa śatena api tāla bījam antareṇa
translated: For even by a hundred unseen [means], without a palm seed,

analyzed: tālavṛkṣaḥ niṣpadyate
translated: a palm tree does not grow.

original: vināpi bījamīśvaramahimnā sarvaṃ siddhyatīti cet / na /
analyzed: vinā api bījam īśvara mahimnā sarvam siddhi ati iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that everything can be accomplished by the greatness of God even without a seed, no [that is not so].

analyzed: tatra eva pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no evidence for that.

analyzed: nitya tve hi vedānām avasite tad prāmāṇya balena īśvarasya aparicchedyaḥ mahimā
translated: For when the eternality of the Vedas is established, the greatness of God cannot be determined by the power of their validity.

analyzed: sṛṣṭi pralayau
translated: The creation and dissolution [of the world]

analyzed: ṛtu liṅga nyāyam āśritya sidhyeyuḥ na vā
translated: could be established by relying on the principle of the signs of the seasons, or not.

analyzed: vedān tu an ādṛtya dṛṣṭa anusāreṇa parvate iva anumānam atyanta alaukika irthe pravartayatām upekṣā eva uttaram iti uparamyate
translated: But for those who, disregarding the Vedas, engage in inference about a completely non-empirical matter, like a mountain, following what is seen, the answer is simply to ignore it. Thus we desist.

analyzed: tasmāt na sarga ādi kāle pi saṃbandha kāraṇam
translated: Therefore, even at the time of creation, etc., there is no cause for the relation.

original: śabdārthasaṃbandhasya nityatvam /🔽aśakyaṃ ca kartuṃ sarvaśabdānāṃ saṃbandhakaraṇam yadā na kaścidapi śabdaḥ kenāpyarthena
analyzed: śabda artha saṃbandhasya nitya tvam  aśakyam ca kartum sarva śabdānām saṃbandha karaṇam yadā na kaścid api śabdaḥ kena api arthena
translated: The eternality of the relation between word and meaning.

original: saṃbaddhaṃ āsīt tadā kathaṃ saṃbandhaḥ kriyeta saṃbandhaṃ hi kurvatāvaśyaṃ kenacidvākyena
analyzed: saṃbaddham āsīt tadā katham saṃbandhaḥ kriyeta saṃbandham hi kurvatā avaśyam kenacid vākyena
translated: And it is impossible to make the relation of all words, when no word was related to any meaning at all, how could the relation be made then? For one making the relation must certainly make it with some sentence,

analyzed: sa kartavyaḥ gauḥ sāsnādimān ityādinā
translated: like A cow has a dewlap, etc.

analyzed: na ca aprasiddham artha pratipādaka tvena sāsnā ādi śabdam artha pratipādanāya śaknoti kartā uccārayitum
translated: And one cannot make or utter a word like 'dewlap' as a means of conveying a meaning, when its meaning is not well-known.

analyzed: tathā hasta saṃjñā ādayaḥ api
translated: Similarly, words like 'hand' also.

original: pratipādakatvāsiddheḥ ////🔽nanvevamaprasiddhasaṃbandhasya kathamanapyanupapannam yadyapi hi tadā vaktuḥ prasiddhasaṃbandhatvātsaṃbandhakathanāya
analyzed: pratipādaka tva asiddheḥ  nanu evam aprasiddha saṃbandhasya katham an apyanupapannam yadi api hi tadā vaktuḥ prasiddha saṃbandha tvāt saṃbandha kathanāya
translated: Because their ability to convey meaning is not established.

original: vākyoccāraṇaṃ saṃbhavati tathāpi śrotāro 'prasiddhasamastapadārthā bālāḥ kathaṃ vākyena🔽saṃbadhaṃ pratipadyeran /
analyzed: vākya uccāraṇam saṃbhavati tathā api prasiddha samasta padārthāḥ bālāḥ katham vākyena  pratipadyeran
translated: If it is so, how can the relation of a word with its meaning be established at all? Although at that time, the speaker, being one who has a well-known relation, may utter a sentence to explain the relation, still the listeners, being children with all the meanings of the words unknown to them, how can they understand the relation through the sentence?

analyzed: tasmāt karaṇavat kathanam api anupapannam
translated: Therefore, like the act of making, the act of telling is also impossible.

analyzed: na eṣa doṣaḥ
translated: This is not a fault.

analyzed: kathayituḥ tāvat na kartuḥ iva aśaktiḥ upāya saṃbhavāt
translated: For the teller, there is no inability like that of the maker, because a means is possible.

analyzed: pratipattāraḥ tu upāya abhāvāt na pratipadyante iti dṛṣṭa viruddham
translated: But it is contrary to what is seen that the listeners, due to the absence of a means, do not understand.

original: dṛśyante hyaprasiddhasamastaśabdārthā bālā vṛddhebhyaḥ saṃbandhaṃ pratipadyamānāḥ ////
analyzed: dṛśyante hi aprasiddha samasta śabda arthāḥ bālāḥ vṛddhebhyaḥ saṃbandham pratipadyamānāḥ
translated: For children, who are seen to have all the meanings of the words unknown to them, are seen to understand the relation from the elders.

original: kiñcāstyupāyo bālānāṃ nāvaśyaṃ saṃbandhakathanāvākyenaiva vṛddhebhyo bālāḥ saṃbandhaṃ pratipadyante /
analyzed: kiñca asti upāyaḥ bālānām na avaśyam saṃbandha kathanā vākyena eva vṛddhebhyaḥ bālāḥ saṃbandham pratipadyante
translated: Moreover, there is a means for the young to understand the relation. Not necessarily by the statement of the relation itself, the young understand the relation from the elders through the sentence itself.

original: kintu yadā vṛddhāḥ prasiddhasaṃbandhāḥ svakāryārthena vyavaharanti tadā teṣāmupaśṛṇvanto bālāḥ saṃbandhaṃ pratipadyante /
analyzed: kintu yadā vṛddhāḥ prasiddha saṃbandhāḥ sva kārya arthena vyavaharanti tadā teṣām upaśṛṇvantaḥ bālāḥ saṃbandham pratipadyante
translated: But when the elders, who know the well-known relation, use it for their own purpose, then the young who listen to them understand the relation.

original: yadā hi kenacidgāmānayetyuktaḥ kaścitsāsnādimantamānayati tadā samīpastho bālo 'vagacchati🔽yasmādayametadvākyaśravaṇānantaramasminnarthe pravartate tasmādasmādvākyādayamarthaḥ
analyzed: yadā hi kenacid gām ānaya iti uktaḥ kaścid sāsnādimantam ānayati tadā samīpa sthaḥ bālaḥ vagacchati  yasmāt ayam etad vākya śravaṇa anantaram asmin arthe pravartate tasmāt asmāt vākyāt ayam arthaḥ
translated: For when someone is told by someone else to bring the cow, and he brings one with a dewlap etc., then the young one nearby understands

original: pratyāyita ityevaṃ saṃmugdharūpeṇāvagataṃ pratyāyakatvaṃ paścādbahuṣu prayogeṣvanvayavyatirekābhyāṃ
analyzed: pratyāyitaḥ iti evam saṃmugdha rūpeṇa avagatam pratyāyaka tvam paścāt bahuṣu prayogeṣu anvaya vyatirekābhyām
translated: that since this person engages in that activity after hearing that sentence, therefore that meaning is conveyed by that sentence. Thus, the conveying nature, which is understood in a confused form, is later ascertained

original: vākyabhāgānāṃ padānāṃ padabhāgānāṃ ca prakṛtipratyayānāṃ vākyārthabhāgeṣu pādartheṣu vivacyate /
analyzed: vākya bhāgānām padānām pada bhāgānām ca prakṛti pratyayānām vākya artha bhāgeṣu pādartheṣu vivacyate
translated: through positive and negative concomitance in many usages of the parts of the sentence, the words, and the parts of the words, the roots and suffixes, in relation to the parts of the sentence meaning, the word meanings.

original: tasmānna pauruṣeyaḥ saṃbandha iti na tadvaśena puruṣāpekṣāstīti siddhamanapekṣaṃ vedānāṃ prāmāṇyam //
analyzed: tasmāt na pauruṣeyaḥ saṃbandhaḥ iti na tad vaśena puruṣa apekṣā asti iti siddham anapekṣam vedānām prāmāṇyam
translated: Therefore, the relation is not human-made. Hence, it is established that the Vedas are authoritative without depending on human beings.

analyzed: iti saṃbandha ākṣepa parihāraḥ
translated: Thus ends the discussion on the objection regarding the connection.

analyzed: yat ca anna antara phala anupalabdhyā citra ādīnām na paścādi phala tvam iti syāt evam
translated: And it might be argued that the variegated etc. do not have a subsequent fruit because the subsequent fruit is not perceived. This would be so,

original: yadi pratyakṣādipañcakameva pramāṇaṃ syāttadā hyanantaraphalopalambhādeva tatsādhanatvaṃ syāt nānyathā /
analyzed: yadi pratyakṣa ādi pañcakam eva pramāṇam syāt tadā hi anantara phala upalambhāt eva tad sādhanatvam syāt na anyathā
translated: if the five, perception etc., were the only means of knowledge. For then the instrumentality would be only from the perception of the subsequent fruit, not otherwise.

original: śabdasyāpi tu pramitijanakatayā pratyakṣādivatpramāṇatvāt tenaca citrādīnāṃ paśusādhanatvāvagamādasatyapyanantaropalambhe siddhyati tatsādhanatvam
analyzed: śabdasya api tu pramiti janaka tayā pratyakṣa ādi vat pramāṇa tvāt tena ca citra ādīnām paśu sādhanatva avagamāt asati api anantara upalambhe siddhi ati tad sādhanatvam
translated: But because sound also is a means of knowledge like perception etc. by generating cognition, and because the variegated etc. are understood to be the means of obtaining cattle by that [sound], instrumentality is established even without the perception of the subsequent [fruit].

analyzed: citra ādi viṣayaka ākṣepa parihārāḥ
translated: The objections and answers regarding the variegated etc. as the object.

analyzed: nanu pramāṇa antara virodhāt apramāṇyam iti uktam na
translated: But it was said that [the Vedic injunctions] are not a means of knowledge because they are contradicted by another means of knowledge. No,

analyzed: tad abhāvāt
translated: because that [contradiction] does not exist.

original: nahi śabdo 'nantarameva citrāphalasādhanamiti brūte yena virodhaḥ syāt /
analyzed: nahi śabdaḥ nantaram eva citrā phala sādhanam iti brūte yena virodhaḥ syāt
translated: For the word does not say that the variegated etc. are the means of obtaining the fruit immediately, by which there would be contradiction.

analyzed: sādhana tvam eva pratipannam tanmātra vacanāt
translated: Only the instrumentality is understood, because it is stated in that [word] alone.

analyzed: tasya ca apūrva dvāreṇa kāla antare pi taila pāna ādi vat phala sādhanatva upapatteḥ
translated: And that is logically possible as the means of obtaining the fruit even at a later time through the unseen force, like the drinking of oil etc.

analyzed: yat tu prāk anuṣṭhānāt śāstra artha avadhāraṇa velāyām na apūrvam antar bhāvitām iti uktam
translated: As for what was said that before performance, at the time of ascertaining the meaning of the scripture, the unseen effect is not included,

original: yadyapyevaṃ tathāpi paścādevamavagacchati sādhanatvamātre 'pi śabdenokte bhrāntyā mayā sākṣātsādhanatvameva pratipannaṃ taccedānīmanyathā
analyzed: yadi api evam tathā api paścāt evam avagacchati sādhanatva mātre śabdena ukte bhrāntyā mayā sākṣāt sādhanatvam eva pratipannam tat ca idānīm anyathā
translated: even if it is so, still he understands later in this way: When the mere instrumentality was stated by the word, I mistakenly understood the direct instrumentality, and that is now otherwise.

original: ato nūnamasya kenāpi dvāreṇa kālāntare phalamiti ////
analyzed: atas nūnam asya kena api dvāreṇa kāla antare phalam iti
translated: Therefore, it is certain that its effect will be at some time in the future by some means.

original: prāgapi ca śakyamevāpūrvamavagantum anekeṣāmaṅgapradhānakarmaṇāṃ kṣaṇikānāmapūrvamantareṇa yaugapadyāsaṃbhavāt /
analyzed: prāk api ca śakyam eva apūrvam avagantum anekeṣām aṅga pradhāna karmaṇām kṣaṇikānām apūrvam antareṇa yaugapadya asaṃbhavāt
translated: And even before, it is possible to understand the unseen effect, because many subsidiary and primary actions, which are momentary, cannot occur simultaneously without the unseen effect.

analyzed: paśu ādīnām ca dṛṣṭa kāraṇa apekṣa tvāt na kṣaṇa mātreṇa utpattiḥ saṃbhavati iti avaśyaṃbhāvya pūrvam
translated: And because animals etc. depend on seen causes, their production is not possible in a mere moment, so the unseen effect must necessarily exist.

original: na ca paścādyutpattimātraṃ phalam upabhogasya tu cirakālatvāt yāvadupabhogamavasthāsyamānena kenacidbhavitavyam /
analyzed: na ca paścādi utpatti mātram phalam upabhogasya tu cira kāla tvāt yāvat upabhogam avasthāsyamānena kenacid bhavitavyam
translated: And the mere production later is not the fruit, but because of the enjoyment lasting for a long time, something must exist by someone who will remain until the enjoyment.

analyzed: na ca kriyāyāḥ tāvankālam avasthānam saṃbhavati iti apūrvam aṅgīkartavyam iti tad dvāreṇa
translated: And the action cannot remain for so long, therefore the unseen effect must be accepted. By that means,

original: yuktaṃ karma kālāntare phaladamiti nānantarānupalabdhyā śāstrasya bādhaḥ //
analyzed: yuktam karma kāla antare phala dam iti na anantara anupalabdhyā śāstrasya bādhaḥ
translated: It is proper that an action should bear fruit at a later time. So the Veda is not contradicted by the non-apprehension of an immediate result.

analyzed: iti citra ākṣepa parihāraḥ
translated: Thus ends the discussion on the figurative meaning of the word 'citra'.

analyzed: ātmavāda ārambhaḥ
translated: The beginning of the doctrine of the self.

original: yattu pratyakṣaviruddhaṃ vacanamupanyastaṃ sa eṣa yajñāyudhī yajamāno 'ñjasā svargaṃ lokaṃ yātītyetacchabdena pratyakṣaṃ śarīraṃ yajñāyudhasaṃyuktamupadiśatīti
analyzed: yat tu pratyakṣa viruddham vacanam upanyastam saḥ eṣa yajñāyudhī yajamānaḥ ñjasā svargam lokam yāti iti etad śabdena pratyakṣam śarīram yajñāyudha saṃyuktam upadiśati iti
translated: But the statement that contradicts perception, that this sacrificer who is equipped with sacrificial implements goes directly to heaven, that statement points out by the word 'this' the body equipped with sacrificial implements.

analyzed: tat abhidhīyate artha vāda tvāt asya anya para tvāt na svārthe pramāṇa antara virodhaḥ doṣaḥ
translated: To that it is said: Because this is a commendatory statement, it has a different meaning. So the contradiction with another means of knowledge in its own meaning is not a fault.

analyzed: na ca virodhaḥ vidyate
translated: And there is no contradiction either.

analyzed: na hi anena śarīrasya svarga gamanam ucyate kin tarhi ātmanaḥ yasya etat śarīram
translated: For this does not state the going to heaven of the body, but rather of the self whose body this is.

original: so 'pi hi śarīraśarīriṇorabhedopacāreṇa śarīrasthena yajñāyudhitvena pratyakṣatvena ca vyapidiśyate /
analyzed: saḥ u pi hi śarīra śarīriṇoḥ abheda upacāreṇa śarīra sthena yajñāyudhi tvena pratyakṣa tvena ca vyapidiśyate
translated: And that self is also indicated by the figurative identification of the body and the self, by the possession of sacrificial implements in the body, and by the direct perception.

original: ātmano vā svargagamanaṃ śarīre upacaryata iti nāsti virodhaḥ ////
analyzed: ātmanaḥ vā svarga gamanam śarīre upacaryate iti na asti virodhaḥ
translated: Or the going to heaven of the self is figuratively ascribed to the body. So there is no contradiction.

analyzed: yajamāna śabdaḥ api tasya eva yāga svāmi tvāt kartṛ tvāt ca vācakaḥ
translated: The word 'sacrificer' also denotes him, because he is the owner of the sacrifice and the agent.

original: na ca śakyate tasya kāpilavadakartṛtvaṃ vaktuṃ śrutivirodhāt /
analyzed: na ca śakyate tasya kāpila vat akartṛ tvam vaktum śruti virodhāt
translated: And it cannot be said that it is not the agent, like Kapila, because that would contradict the scriptures.

analyzed: sarvatra hi kartṛ bhoktṛ śabdayoḥ sāmānādhikaraṇyam dṛśyate
translated: For everywhere the words 'agent' and 'enjoyer' are seen to be in apposition.

original: yathātraiva yajamānaḥ svargaṃ lokaṃ yātīti /🔽tathā ya evaṃ vidvānagniṃ cinute ṛdhnotyeva ya evaṃ vidvāndvirātreṇa yajate svargakāmeva saṃkalpaṃ prati kartṛtvamuktam ////
analyzed: yathā atra eva yajamānaḥ svargam lokam yāti iti  tathā yaḥ evam vidvān agnim cinute ṛdhnoti eva yaḥ evam vidvān dvirātreṇa yajate svarga kāmā iva saṃkalpam prati kartṛ tvam uktam
translated: Just as here itself, the sacrificer goes to heaven.🔽Similarly, it is said that the agent is in relation to the resolve for one who desires heaven through the two-day sacrifice, knowing thus.

original: saṃbhavati ca svargagatasyāpyātmano yāgajñānaprayatnasaṃkalpādiṣu sākṣādeva kartṛtvaṃ /
analyzed: saṃbhavati ca svarga gatasya api ātmanaḥ yāga jñāna prayatna saṃkalpa ādiṣu sākṣāt eva kartṛ tvam
translated: And it is possible for the self, even when in heaven, to be the agent directly in sacrifice, knowledge, effort, resolve, and so on.

original: na hi vayaṃ spandameva kriyāmupagacchāmo vaiśeṣikavat /
analyzed: na hi vayam spandam eva kriyām upagacchāmaḥ vaiśeṣika vat
translated: We do not accept mere vibration to be action, like the Vaisheshikas,

analyzed: yena ātmanaḥ kartṛ tvam na syāt
translated: by which the self would not be the agent.

analyzed: dhātvartha mātrasya kriyā tvāt  spandeṣu api prayojaka tvena asya eṣa kartṛ tvam saṃbhavati
translated: Because the mere meaning of the root is action.🔽Even in vibrations, this is possible for it to be the agent by being the instigator.

analyzed: prayatnena hi asau śarīram spande prayojayati
translated: For by effort, it instigates the body to vibrate.

analyzed: sākṣāt tu na saṃbhavati
translated: But directly, it is not possible.

analyzed: sarvagate spandasya asaṃbhavāt iti anena abhiprāyeṇa purāṇeṣu upaniṣatsu ca akartṛ tva vādāḥ
translated: With this intention, the Upanishads and Puranas declare the Self to be without an agent.

analyzed: śarīra a kirikta ātma sādhanam
translated: Proof of the existence of the Self distinct from the body.

original: kiṃpunaḥ śarīravyatiriktātmasadbhāve pramāṇaṃ prāṇanādiliṅgaṃ sukhādayaśca prāṇanādiśabdena
analyzed: kim punar śarīra vyatirikta ātma sadbhāve pramāṇam prāṇana ādi liṅgam sukha ādayaḥ ca prāṇana ādi śabdena
translated: What, then, is the proof of the existence of the Self distinct from the body? The signs such as breathing, etc., and pleasure, etc.

analyzed: koṣṭhyasya vāyoḥ ūrdhva adhas gamana vṛtti viśeṣasya prāṇana ādi śabda vācyasya hetu bhūtaḥ prayatna
translated: The effort which is the cause of the special function of the upward and downward movement of the vital air in the chest,

original: ucyate saca sukhādayaśca na śarīradharmāḥ saṃbhavanti /
analyzed: ucyate sa ca sukha ādayaḥ ca na śarīra dharmāḥ saṃbhavanti
translated: is said to be the cause of breathing, etc. And that, and pleasure, etc., cannot be the qualities of the body.

analyzed: a yāvat śarīra bhāvi tvāt
translated: Because they do not exist as long as the body does.

original: ye hi kāryadravyavartino viśeṣaguṇā rūpādayaste virodhiguṇāntarādvā dravyavināśādvā vinaśyanti /
analyzed: ye hi kārya dravya vartinaḥ viśeṣa guṇāḥ rūpa ādayaḥ te virodhi guṇa antarāt vā dravya vināśāt vā vinaśyanti
translated: Those special qualities such as color, etc., which reside in the effect substance, are destroyed either by the presence of an opposing quality or by the destruction of the substance.

original: prāṇanādayastu tadbhāvepi naśyanti mṛtāvasthāyāmiti na śarīraguṇāḥ /
analyzed: prāṇana ādayaḥ tu tad bhāve pi naśyanti mṛta avasthāyām iti na śarīra guṇāḥ
translated: But breathing, etc., are destroyed even when that [body] exists, in the state of death. Therefore, they are not the qualities of the body.

analyzed: tathā jñānam api ayāvat śarīra bhāvi tvāt eva na śarīra dharmaḥ
translated: Similarly, knowledge, because it does not exist as long as the body does, is not the quality of the body.

original: tathā ye pratyakṣiviṣayāḥ na śarīraguṇaste svayamiva parairapi yathā gṛhyante yatha rūpādayaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ye pratyakṣi viṣayāḥ na śarīra guṇaḥ te svayam iva paraiḥ api yathā gṛhyante rūpa ādayaḥ
translated: Similarly, those which are the objects of direct perception, like color, etc., are apprehended by others as well as by themselves, being not the qualities of the body.

original: sukhādayastu pratyakṣā api santo na parapratyakṣagrāhyāḥ tasmānna śarīraguṇāḥ /
analyzed: sukha ādayaḥ tu pratyakṣāḥ api santaḥ na para pratyakṣa grāhyāḥ tasmāt na śarīra guṇāḥ
translated: But pleasure, etc., though perceptible, are not perceptible to others. Therefore they are not qualities of the body.

original: tadidamapi dvayaṃ sukhādīnāṃ śarīraguṇatvaṃ nivārayadanyaguṇatāṃ sūcayati /
analyzed: tat idam api dvayam sukha ādīnām śarīra guṇa tvam nivārayat anya guṇatām sūcayati
translated: This pair also, while precluding the quality of pleasure, etc., in the body, indicates their quality in something else.

analyzed: yaḥ saḥ anyaḥ saḥ ātmā
translated: And that which is other is the Self.

original: kiñca sarvaṃ eva viśeṣaguṇāḥ karaṇe 'pi vartamānā eva kāryadravyaguṇatāṃ bhajante /
analyzed: kiñca sarvam eva viśeṣa guṇāḥ karaṇe vartamānāḥ eva kārya dravya guṇa tām bhajante
translated: Moreover, all specific qualities, even when present in the sense organ, become the qualities of the effect substance.

original: na ca śarīrakāraṇabhūteṣu pārthivaparamāṇuṣu caitanyamastīti kathaṃ śarīraguṇatā caitanyasya syāt /
analyzed: na ca śarīra kāraṇa bhūteṣu pārthiva paramāṇuṣu caitanyam asti iti katham śarīra guṇa tā caitanyasya syāt
translated: And since sentience does not exist in the earth atoms that are the cause of the body, how can sentience be a quality of the body?

analyzed: tasmāt anyaḥ cetanaḥ
translated: Therefore, the sentient one is different.
Proof of the Self as different from the body.

original: kaścitpunarāha sarvathā vittiṣu tāvadvettāvabhāsate anyathā svaparavedyayoranatiśayaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: kaścid punar āha sarvathā vittiṣu tāvat vettā avabhāsate anyathā sva para vedyayoḥ anatiśaya prasaṅgāt
translated: But someone else says: In all cases, the knower appears in the cognitions. Otherwise, there would be no difference between one's own and others' cognitions.

analyzed: na ca śarīrasya kara caraṇa ādi avayava saṃniveśa viśiṣṭasya asti tathā avabhāsaḥ
translated: And the body, distinguished by the arrangement of hands, feet, etc., does not appear in that way.

analyzed: atas nyaḥ śarīrāt ātmā iti
translated: Therefore, the Self is different from the body.

analyzed: tattva yuktam saṃniveśa pratibhāse pi śarīra pratibhāsa saṃbhavāt
translated: That is not correct, because even in the appearance of the arrangement, the appearance of the body is possible.

analyzed: nahi saṃniveśe eva śarīram
translated: For the arrangement is not the body itself.

original: śarīradharmo hi saṃniveśaḥ saṃbhavati ca dharmāpratibhāso 'pi dharmiṇaḥ pratibhāsaḥ /
analyzed: śarīra dharmaḥ hi saṃniveśaḥ saṃbhavati ca dharma apratibhāsaḥ pi dharmiṇaḥ pratibhāsaḥ
translated: For a configuration is a property of a body, and the appearance of a property is possible even when the possessor of the property does not appear.

original: anyathā ātmanopi pratibhāso na syāt taddharmāṇāṃ sarvagatatvādīnāmarthavittiṣvapratibhānāt /
analyzed: anyathā ātmanaḥ api pratibhāsaḥ na syāt tad dharmāṇām sarvagata tva ādīnām artha vittiṣu apratibhānāt
translated: Otherwise, the appearance of the self also would not be there, because its properties such as omnipresence etc. do not appear in the cognition of objects.

analyzed: na ca aikāntikam artha vittiṣu vettṛ bhānam
translated: And the appearance of the cognizer in the cognition of objects is not absolute.

original: artha eva hi tadā bhāsate na vettā ////🔽na ca svaparavedyayoranatiśayaḥ /
analyzed: arthaḥ eva hi tadā bhāsate na vettā  na ca sva para vedyayoḥ anatiśayaḥ
translated: For then only the object appears, not the cognizer.🔽And there is no difference between what is known to oneself and to others.

original: na hi vedittṛbhāsanakṛto 'yamatiśayaḥ kintu kasyacideva kiñcidābhāsate nānyasya ityetāvānatiśayo nānyaḥ /
analyzed: na hi vedittṛ bhāsana kṛtaḥ yam atiśayaḥ kintu kasyacid eva kiñcid ābhāsate na anyasya iti etāvān atiśayaḥ na anyaḥ
translated: For this difference is not due to the appearance of the cognizer, but rather that something appears to someone, not to another. This is the only difference, not another.

analyzed: tasmāt na jñātṛ pratibhāsena śarīra viveka siddhiḥ
translated: Therefore, the establishment of the distinction of the body is not by the appearance of the cognizer.

original: kintu pūrvoktādeva kāraṇāt jñānasukhādīnāṃ śarīraguṇatvāsaṃbhavāt tato 'nya
analyzed: kintu pūrva uktāt eva kāraṇāt jñāna sukha ādīnām śarīra guṇa tva asaṃbhavāt tatas nya
translated: But rather, for the very reasons stated earlier, the impossibility of knowledge, pleasure etc. being properties of the body, they are

analyzed: eteṣām āśrayaḥ saḥ eva ātmā
translated: the substratum of these, and that very self.

analyzed: bauddha matena vijñāna ātma vādaḥ
translated: The doctrine of the self as consciousness according to the Buddhist view.

analyzed: saugatāḥ tu āhuḥ siddhe jñāna sukha ādīnām guṇa tve guṇa kalpanā
translated: The Buddhists say: When the quality-ness of knowledge, pleasure etc. is established, there is the postulation of a substratum.

analyzed: na tu tat siddham asmākam tāvat mātra upapattitaḥ
translated: But that is not established for us, merely because of the possibility of that.

original: nahyāśrayamantareṇa jñānamātramanupapannaṃ svatantrameva jñānaṃ kiṃ neṣyate sukhādayo 'pi jñānaviṣayāḥ svatantrā eva anyasyāśrayasyānupalabdheḥ
analyzed: nahi āśrayam antareṇa jñāna mātram anupapannam svatantram eva jñānam kim nā iṣyate sukha ādayaḥ pi jñāna viṣayāḥ svatantrāḥ eva anyasya āśrayasya anupalabdheḥ
translated: For knowledge alone, without a substratum, is not possible; why is not knowledge itself, independent, admitted? Pleasure, etc. also are objects of knowledge, independent themselves; because no other substratum is perceived.

original: jñānameva ca nīlamahaṃ jānāmīti jñātṛtvena viparyāsitadarśanairadhyavasīyate nānyaḥ pramāṇābhāvāt ////
analyzed: jñānam eva ca nīlam aham jānāmi iti jñātṛ tvena viparyāsita darśanaiḥ adhyavasīyate na anyaḥ pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: And knowledge itself is ascertained by those whose vision is perverted as the knower, in the thought, 'I know the blue'; because there is no other [knower], in the absence of any proof [of its existence].

original: nanu jñānasyāpi kṣaṇikatvātkathaṃ pūrvedyurupalabdhe paredyuḥsmaraṇamicchā pratyabhijñā ca /
