analyzed: nanu jñānasya api kṣaṇika tvāt katham pūrvedyus upalabdhe paredyus smaraṇam icchā pratyabhijñā ca
translated: But since knowledge also is momentary, how is it that what is perceived on one day is remembered on another day, and recognized?

original: nahi svayamanupalabdhe tāni saṃbhavanti nahi devadattenopalabdher'the yajñadattasya smaraṇādīni saṃbhavanti /
analyzed: nahi svayam anupalabdhe tāni saṃbhavanti nahi devadattena upalabdha ṛthe yajñadattasya smaraṇa ādīni saṃbhavanti
translated: For these [functions] are not possible if [the knower] is not perceived by himself. The memory, etc. of Yajnadatta are not possible when the object is perceived by Devadatta.

original: satyam na saṃbhavanti saṃtānabhede samānāyāṃ tu saṃtatāvekenopalabdhe 'nyasya smaraṇādyupapannaṃ dṛṣṭatvāt /
analyzed: satyam na saṃbhavanti saṃtāna bhede samānāyām tu saṃtatau ekena upalabdhe nyasya smaraṇa ādi upapannam dṛṣṭa tvāt
translated: True, they are not possible. But when there is identity of the continuum, memory, etc. are possible for one when something is perceived by another, because it is seen [to happen].

analyzed: nahi upalabdhuḥ smartuḥ ca eka tvam kvacid api dṛṣṭam
translated: For the identity of the perceiver and the rememberer is not seen anywhere.

analyzed: ekasya sthāsnoḥ puruṣasya kvacid api anupalabdha tvāt
translated: Because for a single, enduring person, there is no perception anywhere.

analyzed: tasmāt jñānam eva jñātṛ na anyaḥ jñātā asti iti
translated: Therefore, knowledge alone is the knower, there is no other knower.

analyzed: atrā ucyate pratyabhijñāyate kartā yaḥ pūrva apara kālayoḥ
translated: To this it is said: The agent is recognized as the same in the past and future.

analyzed: tasya sthāsnoḥ bhedaḥ vijñānāt kṣaṇa bhaṅgurāt
translated: His permanence is different from consciousness, which is momentary.

analyzed: viṣaya pratyabhijñāna anupapatteḥ jñātuḥ eka tva kalpanāyām syāt api etat uttaram saṃtāna ekatvāt eva upapadyate iti
translated: Since the recognition of the object is not possible, if the unity of the knower is imagined, this could be explained by the unity of the series itself.

original: yadā tu jñātaivaikaḥ pūrvāparakālayoḥ pratyabhijñāyate yo 'haṃ pūrvamadrākṣaṃ sa evāhamanupaśyāmīti tadā pratyabhijñayaiva jñāturekatvāvagamāt /
analyzed: yadā tu jñātā eva ekaḥ pūrva apara kālayoḥ pratyabhijñāyate yaḥ ham pūrvam adrākṣam saḥ eva aham anupaśyāmi iti tadā pratyabhijñayā eva jñātuḥ eka tva avagamāt
translated: But when the very same knower is recognized in the past and future, as I who saw before, he alone I see now, then by recognition itself the unity of the knower is understood.

original: vijñānasya ca kṣaṇikatvāttato 'nyo jñātā siddho bhavatīti ////
analyzed: vijñānasya ca kṣaṇika tvāt tatas nyaḥ jñātā siddhaḥ bhavati iti
translated: And since consciousness is momentary, the knower who is different from that is established.

analyzed: kim aham pratyaya gocaraḥ jñātā syāt
translated: Should the knower be the object of the notion of I?

original: tathā sati śarīrameva jānāmi kṛśo 'haṃ gacchāmyahamiti kārśyādibuddhisāmānādhikaraṇyādahaṃbuddhergocaraḥ /
analyzed: tathā sati śarīram eva jānāmi kṛśaḥ ham gacchāmi aham iti kārśya ādi buddhi sāmānādhikaraṇyāt aham buddheḥ gocaraḥ
translated: If so, then the body itself is known, as in the thoughts I am thin, I am going, due to the co-reference of the thoughts of thinness etc. with the thought of I.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ ca sarvagatasya kārśya ādi anupapatteḥ
translated: And since the self is all-pervading, thinness etc. are not possible for it.

analyzed: ucyate jñātṛ viśayaḥ tāvat ahaṃpratyayaḥ iti avivādam
translated: It is said that there is no dispute that the notion of I has the knower as its object.

original: yo hi parāmṛśati sa svātmānamahamiti parāmṛśati parānidamiti /
analyzed: yaḥ hi parāmṛśati sa sva ātmānam aham iti parāmṛśati parān idam iti
translated: For he who reflects, reflects on his own self as 'I', and on others as 'this'.

original: tena niḥsaṃśayamasya jñātṛgocaratvaṃ śarīrasya ca jñātṛtvaṃ nirākṛtaṃ /
analyzed: tena niḥsaṃśayam asya jñātṛ gocara tvam śarīrasya ca jñātṛ tvam nirākṛtam
translated: Therefore, beyond doubt, the body is the object of the knower, and the knowership of the body is refuted.

analyzed: tyanta saṃsṛṣṭayoḥ ekatva bhrāntyā sāmānādhikaraṇya pratītiḥ uṣṇa toya pratīti vat bhāsvara ayaḥ piṇḍa pratīti vat ca
translated: Hence, the cognition of identity in the case of the two absolutely mixed [self and body] is due to the illusion of oneness, like the cognition of hot water, or like the cognition of a glowing lump of iron.

analyzed: śarīra ātmanoḥ bheda upapādanam
translated: The establishment of the difference between the body and the self.

original: tathā vyatirkabuddhirapi dṛśyate mamedaṃ śarīraṃ kṛśamiti ṣaṣṭhyāsmadarthasya śarīravyatirekāt /
analyzed: tathā vyatirka buddhiḥ api dṛśyate mama idam śarīram kṛśam iti ṣaṣṭhyā asmadarthasya śarīra vyatirekāt
translated: Similarly, the cognition of distinction is also seen, as in 'this body of mine is emaciated', because the sixth case ending 'of mine' is distinct from the body.

analyzed: śarīrasya ca para viṣaya idaṅkāra āspada tvāt
translated: And because the body is the basis of the reflection 'I' in relation to others.

analyzed: tatas smāt viveka avabhāsāt pūrva ukta nyāyena ca śarīrasya ajñātṛ tvāt
translated: Therefore, due to the manifestation of this distinction from it [the self], and due to the body not being the knower by the reasoning stated earlier,

analyzed: abheda avagamasya ca saṃsarga doṣa vaśena bhrāntyā api upapatteḥ
translated: and because the cognition of non-difference can also be explained by illusion due to the fault of association,

analyzed: pūrva abhyasta smṛti anubandhena ca vinā jātasya harṣa bhaya śoka pratipatti anupapatteḥ
translated: and because the experience of joy, fear, and sorrow is not possible without the connection of memory of what was previously practiced by one who is born.

original: jātismarāśca kecidadyatve 'pi dehāntararahovṛttaṃ vṛttāntaṃ saṃbodhayanta upalabhyanta ityupalabdhisiddhaḥ śarīrātmanabhedaḥ /
analyzed: jātismarāḥ ca kecid adya tve pi deha antara rahaḥ vṛttam vṛttāntam saṃbodhayantaḥ upalabhyante iti upalabdhi siddhaḥ śarīra ātmana bhedaḥ
translated: And some, even in the present life, are found to remember the events of their previous births, and to describe the secret occurrences of their previous lives. Thus the non-difference of the body and the self is established by perception.

original: yadyapi cānena prakāreṇa śarīrātmanorvispaṣṭo bhedo na siddhyet tathāpi tāvadabhedo 'pi na vispaṣṭaḥ mama śarīramiti vivekasyāpi pratibhāsāt
analyzed: yadi api ca anena prakāreṇa śarīra ātmanoḥ vispaṣṭaḥ bhedaḥ na siddhyet tathā api na vispaṣṭaḥ mama śarīram iti vivekasya api pratibhāsāt
translated: And even if the clear difference between the body and the self were not established in this way, still the non-difference is not clear, because the distinction my body is also perceived.

original: tatra saṃmugdhe tattve śrutārthāpattyā sākṣācchrutyā vā nirṇayaḥ /
analyzed: tatra saṃmugdhe tattve śruta arthāpattyā sākṣāt śrutyā vā nirṇayaḥ
translated: There, when the truth is confused, the determination is by the presumption based on the heard text, or directly by the heard text itself.

analyzed: svarga kāma ādi śrutayaḥ hi śarīra atiriktam para loka phala upabhoga yogyam kartāram antareṇa anupapadyamānāḥ tam ākṣipanti
translated: For the heard texts about one who desires heaven, etc., being unintelligible without an agent capable of enjoying the fruits in the next world other than the body, imply that agent.

original: tābhiścākṣiptaṃ sākṣādevopaniṣadaḥ samarthayanti avanāśi vā are 'yamātmā ityevamādaya
analyzed: tābhiḥ ca ākṣiptam sākṣāt eva upaniṣadaḥ samarthayanti avanāśi vai are yam ātmā iti evamādaya
translated: And the Upaniṣads directly confirm what is implied by those [texts], with statements such as This self, O dear one, is not perishable.

analyzed: iti siddhaḥ śarīra atiriktaḥ mānasa pratyakṣa rūpaḥ haṃ pratyaya gamyaḥ jñātā
translated: Thus the knower, who is beyond the body and is known by the I-notion in the form of mental perception, is established.

analyzed: katham punar jñātuḥ jñeya tvam
translated: But how can the knower be known?

original: nahyekasya kartṛtvaṃ karmatvaṃ ca svātmani kriyāvirodhātsaṃbhavaci /
analyzed: nahi ekasya kartṛ tvam karma tvam ca svātmani kriyā virodhāt saṃbhava ci
translated: For it is not possible for one and the same thing to be both the agent and the object of an action on itself, because of the contradiction of action [with itself].

analyzed: tasmāt na ahaṃvittiḥ nāma ghaṭa ādi vitti vyatirekeṇa kācid asti
translated: Therefore, there is no such thing as the cognition of the self apart from the cognition of pots and so on.

analyzed: ghaṭa ādi vittau eva tu viṣaya vat ātmā bhāsate iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that in the cognition of pots and so on, the self appears as if it were the object.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ mānasa ahaṃpratyaya gamya tvam
translated: The self is known through mental cognition of the word 'I'.

original: kaḥ punarayaṃ svātmani kriyāvirodho nāma /🔽yasyāṃ kriyāyāṃ yaḥ kartā na sā tasminneva svaphalaṃ
analyzed: kaḥ punar ayam sva ātmani kriyā virodhaḥ nāma  yasyām kriyāyām yaḥ kartā na sā tasmin eva sva phalam
translated: What is this so-called contradiction of action with respect to the self?

analyzed: janayati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in whatever action the agent is not, that does not produce its own fruit in that very [self].

analyzed: kim punar saṃvitti kriyāyāḥ phalam
translated: Moreover, what is the fruit of the action of cognition?

analyzed: bhāsanam
translated: Illumination.

analyzed: kim idam kartari na bhavati
translated: But how is it that it does not occur in the agent?

analyzed: om iti ced katham tarhi asau bhāsate
translated: If it is said 'om', then how does it illuminate?

original: nahyasati bhāsate bhāsata iti śakyate vaktuṃ /
analyzed: na hi asati bhāsate bhāsate iti śakyate vaktum
translated: For it cannot be said that what does not exist illuminates.

original: tasmādarthavittiṣvapyātmano bhāsanābhyupagame 'pi svātmani kriyāvirodhastulya eva /🔽vyavahārayogyatāmātraṃ saṃvitte palaṃ nānyaditicet bhavatvevam /
analyzed: tasmāt artha vittiṣu api ātmanaḥ bhāsana abhyupagame svātmani kriyā virodhaḥ tulyaḥ eva  vyavahāra yogya tā mātram saṃvitte palam na anyat iti ced bhavatu evam
translated: Therefore, even if the illumination of the self in the cognitions of objects is accepted, the contradiction of action with respect to the self is the same.🔽If it is said that the fruit of cognition is merely the suitability for practical usage, let it be so.

analyzed: asti tāvat phalam
translated: But there is a fruit.

original: tacca viṣayeṣvivātmanyapi saṃvittito jāyata ityaṅgīkṛtaṃ bhavadbhiḥ /
analyzed: tat ca viṣayeṣu iva ātmani api saṃvittitaḥ jāyate iti aṅgīkṛtam bhavadbhiḥ
translated: And it is accepted by you that it arises from cognition in the self just as in objects.

analyzed: atas tulyaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: Therefore, the contradiction is the same.

analyzed: yadi paramārtha virodham udbhāvya sati api ātmanaḥ kriyā janya phala bhāgi tve karma saṃjñā
translated: If it is said that even though the Self is entitled to the fruits produced by its own actions, the designation of action

original: karmavibhaktiṃśca na bhavatītyucyate parasamavāyikriyāphalabhāgitvaṃ karmatvam ityabhidhānāt taccāyuktam /
analyzed: karma vibhaktin ca na bhavati iti ucyate para samavāyi kriyā phala bhāgi tvam karmatvam iti abhidhānāt tat ca ayuktam
translated: and the case endings of action do not apply to it, because it is said that the nature of an object of action is to be entitled to the fruits of an action that is dependent on another, that is incorrect.

analyzed: śabda sādhu tvam hi prayogataḥ vagantavyam
translated: For the correctness of a word must be understood from usage.

original: asti cātmanaḥ svakartṛkāyāmeva kriyāyāṃ karmavyavahāro loke vede ca yadhā tāvadbhāṣya
analyzed: asti ca ātmanaḥ sva kartṛkāyām eva kriyāyām karma vyavahāraḥ loke vede ca yadhā tāvat bhāṣya
translated: And in the world and in the Veda, there is the usage of an object of action with regard to the Self's own action, as follows.

original: eva svasaṃvedyaḥ saṃbhavatīti karmavācī kṛtyapratyayaprayogaḥ vedepi ātmānamupāsīta
analyzed: eva sva saṃvedyaḥ saṃbhavati iti karma vācī kṛtya pratyaya prayogaḥ vede api ātmānam upāsīta
translated: The usage of the verbal suffix denoting an object of action is possible only with regard to the Self, which is to be known by oneself. In the Veda also, there are many usages such as One should meditate on the Self,

original: ātmānaṃ veda ātmā jñātavyaḥ ityanekaśaḥ prayogaḥ //
analyzed: ātmānam veda ātmā jñātavyaḥ iti anekaśas prayogaḥ
translated: One should know the Self, The Self should be known.

original: na ca ganturgamane karmatvaṃ prayogābhāvāt śabdasādhutve hi prayogaparavaśā vayaṃ na svayamīśmahe /
analyzed: na ca gantuḥ gamane karma tvam prayoga abhāvāt śabda sādhu tve hi prayoga paravaśāḥ vayam na svayam īśmahe
translated: And the object of action is not the agent of going, because of the absence of usage. For when it comes to the correctness of a word, we are not independent but dependent on usage.

original: yathāhi calanārthatve samāne gacchatiḥ sakarmakaḥ calatiścākarmakaḥ prayogasya tathā darśanāt /
analyzed: yathā hi calana artha tve samāne gacchatiḥ sakarmakaḥ calatiḥ ca akarmakaḥ prayogasya tathā darśanāt
translated: Just as the verb gacchati (goes) is transitive and calati (moves) is intransitive when they have the same meaning of motion, because usage shows it to be so.

analyzed: eva jñātuḥ karma tvam gantuḥ ca a karma tvam bhaviṣyati
translated: In the same way, the nature of an object of knowledge will belong to the knower and the nature of an object of action will not belong to the agent of going.

analyzed: tasmāt mānasa ahaṃpratyaya gamyaḥ ātmā
translated: Therefore, the self is known by the mental cognition of 'I'.

original: tathā ca śrutiḥ sa mānasīna ātmā janānām / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ sa mānasīnaḥ ātmā janānām iti
translated: And thus the Śruti says: That is the mental self of people.

analyzed: tena yadi api viṣaya vitti velāyām eva ātma avabhāsaḥ tathā api na viṣaya vitti kartṛ tayā avabhāsaḥ tathā api
translated: Therefore, although the self is manifested at the time of the cognition of an object, it is not manifested as the agent of the cognition of the object, but

original: na viṣayavittikartṛtayāvabhāsaḥ kintu mānasāhaṃpratyayakarmatayāvabhāso na tadvittikarmatayāvyāpteḥ /
analyzed: na viṣaya vitti kartṛ tayā avabhāsaḥ kintu mānasa ahaṃpratyaya karma tayā avabhāsaḥ na tad vitti karma tayā avyāpteḥ
translated: it is manifested as the object of the mental cognition of 'I', not as the object of that cognition, because it is not pervaded by that.

analyzed: nanu śarīra vat ātmani api aham abhimānaḥ bhrāntar eva na
translated: But the notion of 'I' with regard to the self, like the body, is indeed an error. No.

analyzed: bādhā abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no contradiction.

analyzed: yoginām asti bādhaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that there is contradiction for the yogis,

analyzed: na pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: it is not so, because there is no valid means of knowledge.

original: tathā ca yo 'pi yogasya parāṃ kāṣṭhāmupagatāḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca yogasya parām kāṣṭhām upagatāḥ
translated: And thus, even those who have attained the highest stage of yoga,

analyzed: yoga īśvarāḥ te kurvanti ātmani ahaṃmatīm
translated: even those lords of yoga have the notion of 'I' with regard to the self.

analyzed: aham kṛtsnasya jagataḥ prabhavaḥ pralayaḥ tathā
translated: I am the origin and dissolution of this entire universe.

original: tānyahaṃ veda sarvāṇi na tvaṃ vettha parantapa /
analyzed: tāni aham veda sarvāṇi na tvam vettha parantapa
translated: I know all those, O scorcher of enemies, you do not know.

analyzed: yasmāt kṣaram atītaḥ ham akṣarāt api ca uttamaḥ
translated: Because I am beyond the perishable and also superior to the imperishable,

analyzed: evamādau aham śabdaḥ parasmin puṃsi hi dhruvam
translated: Thus, the word 'I' is certainly used with reference to the supreme Self.

analyzed: na hi mahat vikāraḥ haṅkāraḥ kṛtsnasya prabhavaḥ
translated: For the great modification, egoism, is not the origin of the whole.

analyzed: na api kṣara akṣarābhyām uttamaḥ
translated: Nor is it superior to the perishable and imperishable.

analyzed: na api brahma śabda vācye pradhāne garbham dadhāti
translated: Nor does it contain the embryo in the pradhāna denoted by the word Brahman.

analyzed: puruṣa saṃparka kṛta tvāt prakṛti kṣobhasya
translated: Because the disturbance of prakriti is due to contact with the puruṣa.

original: tathopaniṣatsvapi brahma vā idamagra āsīt tadātmānamevāvedahaṃ brahmāsmi iti mantravarṇopi ahaṃ manurabhavaṃ sūryaśca iti /
analyzed: tathā upaniṣatsu api brahma vai idam agre āsīt tat ātmānam eva avet aham brahma asmi iti mantravarṇaḥ api aham manuḥ abhavam sūryaḥ ca iti
translated: So also in the Upaniṣads, This world was Brahman in the beginning. It knew itself as 'I am Brahman.'  The mantra also says, I became Manu, and the sun.

analyzed: tasmāt ahaṃpratyaya gamya tvām ātmanaḥ śruti virodhāt eva upekṣaṇīyāḥ
translated: Therefore, because of contradicting the Vedas, the arguments that the self is known by the notion of I should be disregarded.

original: yattu nirmuktāhaṅkāramamakāravacanaṃ tadapi paurvāparyeṇa parāmṛṣyamāṇaṃ nāhaṅkārasvarūpaniṣedhārtha bhavati /
analyzed: yat tu nirmukta ahaṅkāra mamakāra vacanam tat api paurvāparyeṇa parāmṛṣyamāṇam na ahaṅkāra svarūpa niṣedha artha bhavati
translated: As for the statement free from egoism and possessiveness, that also, when considered in sequence, does not serve the purpose of denying the nature of egoism.

original: evaṃ hi tadvacanaṃ nāsya kaścinnāyaṃ kasyacit nirmuktāhaṅkāramamakāra evāyamiti /🔽tadayamarthaḥ yasmānnāsya kaścittasmānnirmuktamamakāraḥ /
analyzed: evam hi tat vacanam na asya kaścid na ayam kasyacid nirmukta ahaṅkāra mamakāraḥ eva ayam iti  tat ayam arthaḥ yasmāt na asya kaścid tasmāt nirmukta mamakāraḥ
translated: For the statement is thus: No one belongs to this, nor does this belong to anyone. It is free from egoism and possessiveness.🔽The meaning is this: Since no one belongs to this, therefore it is free from possessiveness.

analyzed: yasmāt na ayam kasyacid tasmāt nirmukta ahaṅkāraḥ iti
translated: Since this does not belong to anyone, therefore it is free from egoism.

analyzed: yadi ahaṅkāra svarūpa niṣedhaḥ syāt
translated: If it were a denial of the nature of egoism,

original: na pūrveṇa saṃbadhyeta yasmānnāyaṃ kasyacittasmādasminnahaṃbhāvo bhrāntiriti kiṃ kena saṃgatam /
analyzed: na pūrveṇa saṃbadhyeta yasmāt na ayam kasyacid tasmāt asmin ahaṃbhāvaḥ bhrāntiḥ iti kim kena saṃgatam
translated: It cannot be connected with the preceding, since this [soul] is not anyone's. Therefore, how can the notion of 'I' in this [soul] be a delusion? What is connected with what?

original: tasmānnāyamahantāsvarūpaniṣedhaḥ kiṃ tarhi janmaṃsaṃbandhitayātmanyahaṃmatiḥ ahamasya pitāhamasya putra ityādiḥ sa bhrama ityevaṃ saṃgataṃ
analyzed: tasmāt na ayam ahantā svarūpa niṣedhaḥ kim tarhi janmam saṃbandhi tayā ātmani ahaṃmatiḥ aham asya pitā aham asya putraḥ ityādiḥ sa bhramaḥ iti evam saṃgatam
translated: Therefore, this is not a negation of the nature of the notion of 'I'. Rather, the notion of 'I' in the self in relation to birth, such as 'I am his father, I am his son', etc., that is a delusion. Thus it is connected.

analyzed: ayam ātmā na kasyacid api putra ādi rūpeṇa saṃbandhī
translated: This self is not related to anyone in the form of a son, etc.

analyzed: janya janaka bhāvasya śarīra viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because the relation of producer and produced pertains only to the body.

analyzed: śarīram hi śarīrāt jāyate na tvā ātmā ātma antarāt
translated: For the body is born from the body, not the self from another self.

analyzed: tasmāt anya saṃbane adhitayā ātmani ahaṃmatiḥ kṛśa ādi mati śarīrāt vivekam a budhyamānānām bhrāntiḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the notion of 'I' in the self in relation to something else, for those who are ignorant of the distinction between the body and the notion of 'I' in the body, etc., is a delusion.

analyzed: tat idam asya anya saṃbandhi niṣedhena putra ādi viṣaya sneha nivartanena vairāgya janana artham ucyate
translated: This is said for the purpose of generating detachment by negating the affection towards a son, etc., through negating its relation to something else.

original: nāhaṅkārasvarūpasyāyaṃ niṣedho 'nupayogādasaṃgatatvāt pramāṇāntaravirodhāt ahaṃ brahmāsti iti vacanavirodhācca /
analyzed: na ahaṅkāra svarūpasya ayam niṣedhaḥ n upayogāt asaṃgata tvāt pramāṇa antara virodhāt aham brahma asti iti vacana virodhāt ca
translated: This is not a negation of the nature of the notion of 'I', because it is useless, unconnected, contradicts other means of knowledge, and contradicts the statement 'I am Brahman'.

analyzed: tasmāt ahaṃpratyaya gamyaḥ jñātā śarīra atiriktaḥ indriya vyatiriktaḥ ca
translated: Therefore, the knower is known by the cognition of the self, and is distinct from the body and the senses.

analyzed: indriya ātmanoḥ bhedaḥ
translated: The difference between the senses and the self.

analyzed: katham indriya bhedaḥ
translated: How is the difference between the senses known?

original: indriyābhāve 'pi jñāturekasya pratyabhijñānāt yo 'haṃ rūpamadrākṣaṃ so 'haṃ
analyzed: indriya abhāve jñātuḥ ekasya pratyabhijñānāt yaḥ ham rūpam adrākṣam saḥ ham
translated: Because of the recognition of the single knower even in the absence of the senses, as when one says I who saw the form, I touch it,

analyzed: spṛśāmi iti yaḥ ham agrahīṣam saḥ ham smarāmi iti
translated: I who perceived it, I remember it.

original: manastu pratyakṣasiddhasya jñātū rūpādijñāneṣu vyatiriktakaraṇādhīnatvāt sukhādijñāneṣu bhavitavyaṃ karaṇenetyevaṃ kalpyata iti nāsya jñātṛtvamāśaṅkanīyam
analyzed: manaḥ tu pratyakṣa siddhasya jñātuḥ rūpa ādi jñāneṣu vyatirikta karaṇa adhīna tvāt sukha ādi jñāneṣu bhavitavyam karaṇena iti evam kalpyate iti na asya jñātṛ tvam āśaṅkanīyam
translated: Since the mind, which is directly perceived, depends on a separate instrument in the cognition of form and other objects, it is imagined that there must be an instrument in the cognition of pleasure and other objects. Thus, its knowership should not be suspected.

analyzed: ye tu kartṛ tayā eva ātma siddhiḥ na sa karma tayā iti āhuḥ teṣām ātmani smaraṇa pratyabhijñāne na upapadyeyātām
translated: But those who say that the self is established only as an agent, not as an object, for them, memory and recognition of the self would not be possible.

analyzed: tatra api hi pūrva kāla saṃbandhi tvena ātmanaḥ pratibhāsaḥ ṅgīkaraṇīyaḥ
translated: For even there, the appearance of the self as connected with the past time must be accepted.

original: na ca sāṃparte smaraṇe pūrvakālasaṃbandhinaḥ kartṛtvaṃ saṃbhavatīti kathaṃ kartṛtayā siddhyet /
analyzed: na ca sāṃparte smaraṇe pūrva kāla saṃbandhinaḥ kartṛ tvam saṃbhavati iti katham kartṛtayā siddhyet
translated: And in the memory of what is related, the agency of what is connected with the past time is not possible. So how could it be established as an agent?

analyzed: tasmāt ahaṃpratyaya karma tayā eva ātmanaḥ siddhiḥ iti ramaṇīyam
translated: Therefore, it is delightful that the self is established only as the object of the notion of 'I'.

original: atha svaprakāśatvamātmanaḥ sukhādīnāṃ ca kiṃ neṣyate /
analyzed: atha sva prakāśa tvam ātmanaḥ sukha ādīnām ca kim nā iṣyate
translated: Now, why is self-luminosity not accepted for the self and pleasure etc.?

original: svaprakāśasya kasyacidapyadarśanāt sarvasyaiva hi vastunaḥ paraprakāśyatvaniyamāt /
analyzed: sva prakāśasya kasyacid api adarśanāt sarvasya eva hi vastunaḥ para prakāśya tva niyamāt
translated: Because no one is self-luminous, since all things are necessarily illuminated by something else.

analyzed: sva prakāśa tve ca ātmā suṣuptau api prakāśeta
translated: And if the self were self-luminous, it would shine even in deep sleep.

analyzed: na ca prakāśate
translated: But it does not shine.

analyzed: yathā uktam acetanayan eva suṣuptaḥ iti ucyate iti
translated: As it is said, one is said to be in deep sleep when the mind is inactive.

original: na tu suṣuptāvapi prakāśata evātmā svābhāvikaparamānandayuktaḥ /
analyzed: na tu suṣuptau api prakāśate eva ātmā svābhāvika parama ānanda yuktaḥ
translated: But the self, which is united with natural supreme bliss, does shine even in deep sleep.

original: anyathā katham sukhamahamasvāpsam iti prabodhe pratisaṃdhānaṃ syāt /
analyzed: anyathā katham sukham aham asvāpsam iti prabodhe pratisaṃdhānam syāt
translated: Otherwise, how could there be a recollection upon awakening, 'I slept happily'?

original: arthāntaraṃ tu na kiñciccharīramindriyamanyadvā vastu prakāśata ityetāvān svapradāgakābhyāṃ suṣupterbhedaḥ /
analyzed: artha antaram tu na kiñcid śarīram indriyam anyat vā vastu prakāśate iti etāvān sva pradāgakābhyām suṣupteḥ bhedaḥ
translated: But no other thing, whether the body, sense organ, or any other object, shines. This is the difference between deep sleep and self-luminosity.

analyzed: na etat evam saṃvid virodhāt
translated: This is not so, because of contradiction with experience.

original: na hi suptānāmātmā sukhaṃ vā prakāśate /
analyzed: na hi suptānām ātmā sukham vā prakāśate
translated: For the self or pleasure does not shine for those who are asleep.

analyzed: na hi abhāsamānam vyavahāra mātreṇa prakāśate iti śakyam aṅgīkartum
translated: For it is not possible to accept that what does not appear shines merely by convention.

original: ki ca suṣvāpādutthitāścaivaṃ nirvidyante hi kāmukāḥ /
analyzed: ki ca suṣvāpāt utthitāḥ ca evam nirvidyante hi kāmukāḥ
translated: And what? They sleep well and rise thus disgusted, for lustful people.

analyzed: vṛthā iyam antareṇa eva kāminīm yāminī gatā
translated: This night has passed in vain without the beloved woman.

analyzed: āśliṣṭām api a buddhvā enām nirvidyante mayā
translated: Even embracing her, I am disgusted without knowing her.

original: bhuktvā ca paramānandaṃ tasya ca smaraṇādayam /
analyzed: bhuktvā ca parama ānandam tasya ca smaraṇāt ayam
translated: Having enjoyed the highest bliss and remembering it,

analyzed: su alpa alpa sukha hānyā evam nirvedaḥ nā avakalpate
translated: this disgust is not possible for the loss of very little pleasure.

analyzed: tat sukham vismṛtam ced syāt sukham a svāpyam iti ayam
translated: If that bliss were forgotten, this usage I slept happily

analyzed: vyavahāraḥ na yujyeta
translated: would not be proper.

analyzed: duḥkha ananubhave tu iyam
translated: But in the non-experience of pain, this

analyzed: sukha vyavahṛtiḥ tasmāt guṇa vṛttyā iti niścayaḥ
translated: usage of happiness is therefore ascertained as a modification of the gunas.

original: prabuddhā hi suṣuptāvavagataṃ kicidapi duḥkhamasaṃsmarantaḥ smaraṇānutpattyaiva suṣuptyavasthāyāṃ
analyzed: prabuddhāḥ hi suṣuptau avagatam kicid api duḥkham a saṃsmarantaḥ smaraṇa anutpattyā eva suṣupti avasthāyām
translated: For when they wake up, not remembering any experienced pain in deep sleep, by the non-arising of memory, they understand in deep sleep

original: me na kiñcidapi duḥkhamāsīdityavagamya tatraiva sukhavyavahāraṃ guṇavṛttyā kurvanti /
analyzed: me na kiñcid api duḥkham āsīt iti avagamya tatra eva sukha vyavahāram guṇa vṛttyā kurvanti
translated: I had no pain at all. Understanding this, they make the usage of happiness there itself by a modification of the gunas.

original: tathā ca vyavaharanti etāvantaṃ kālamahamātmānamapyabuddhvā śayito 'smīti /
analyzed: tathā ca vyavaharanti etāvantam kālam aham ātmānam api a buddhvā smi iti
translated: And they conduct themselves thus: For so long a time I have slept without even knowing my own self.

analyzed: tasmāt suṣuptau aprakāśa ātmanaḥ sva prakāśa tvam
translated: Therefore, in deep sleep, the self is self-luminous, though of an unmanifest nature.

analyzed: atas mānasa pratyakṣa gamyaḥ eva ayam iti sthitam
translated: Therefore, it is established that this [soul] is indeed perceptible only by mental perception.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ vyāpaka tvam
translated: The all-pervasiveness of the soul.

original: sa punarayamātmā aṇuḥ śarīraparamāṇo vibhurveti cintanīyam /
analyzed: sa punar ayam ātmā aṇuḥ śarīra paramāṇaḥ vibhuḥ vā iti cintanīyam
translated: Moreover, this soul should be considered whether it is atomic, the size of the body, or all-pervading.

analyzed: tatra aṇu parimāṇa tve yugapad śiraḥ pādayoḥ vedanā anupapattiḥ  ayaugapadye pi atiśaighyyāt yaugapadya avagatiḥ iti ced
translated: If it has atomic size, the simultaneous sensation in the head and feet is not possible.

analyzed: syāt evam yadi aṇu tvam kutaścid siddham syāt
translated: If it is not simultaneous, but due to extreme speed, there is the understanding of simultaneity, it may be so, if atomic size were established from somewhere.

analyzed: tad asiddhau dṛṣṭa anusārāt anaṇu tvam eva yuktam
translated: If that is not established, due to conformity with what is seen, non-atomicity is indeed proper.

analyzed: tatra śarīra parimāṇa tve sa avayavaḥ syāt
translated: There, if it is the size of the body, it would have parts.

original: tatra dvividhameva hi niravayavadravyam aṇu vibhu vā /
analyzed: tatra dvividham eva hi niravayava dravyam aṇu vibhu vā
translated: For, a partless substance is of two kinds only: atomic or all-pervading.

analyzed: tat asau śarīra saṃmitaḥ san sa avayavaḥ syāt
translated: That [soul], being the size of the body, would have parts.

original: tatra bahvavayavakalpanā tāvatāṃ cānyūnanadhikānāmavayavānāṃ puttikāhastidehayoratisaṃkocavistārakalpanaṃ nātīva hṛdayamanurañjayati /
analyzed: tatra bahu avayava kalpanā tāvatām ca anyūna anadhikānām avayavānām puttikā hasti dehayoḥ ati saṃkoca vistāra kalpanam na atīva hṛdayam anurañjayati
translated: There, the postulation of many parts, and the postulation of those parts as neither less nor more, in the case of the body of an ant and an elephant, does not greatly delight the heart.

analyzed: tasmāt vibhu tvam eva yuktam
translated: Therefore, all-pervasiveness alone is proper.

analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ anantam apāram iti
translated: And thus the Śruti says: Infinite, boundless.

original: bhagavadgītāsu ca vacanam nityaḥ sarvagataḥ sthāṇuracalo 'yaṃ sanātanaḥ iti /
analyzed: bhagavadgītāsu ca vacanam nityaḥ sarva gataḥ sthāṇuḥ acalaḥ yam sanātanaḥ iti
translated: And in the Bhagavadgītā there is the text, “He is eternal, all-pervading, the supporter, the immovable, the ancient.”

original: ye copaniṣatsvaṇutvavādāḥ purāṇeṣu ca aṅguṣṭhamātraṃ puruṣam ityādayaste sūkṣmagrahaṇagocaratvābhiprāyāḥ ////
analyzed: ye ca upaniṣatsu aṇu tva vādāḥ purāṇeṣu ca aṅguṣṭha mātram puruṣam ityādayaḥ te sūkṣma grahaṇa gocara tva abhiprāyāḥ
translated: And those statements about the smallness of the Self in the Upaniṣads and the Purāṇas, such as “the person of the size of a thumb,” are intended to refer to the state of being the object of subtle perception.

original: nanu vibhutve sarvaśarīreṣveka evātmāstu kiṃ nānātmabhirabhyupagataiḥ /
analyzed: nanu vibhu tve sarva śarīreṣu ekaḥ evā ātmā astu kim nānā ātmabhiḥ abhyupagataiḥ
translated: But if the Self is all-pervading, let there be only one Self in all bodies. Why admit many Selves?

original: naivam ekatve sati yathā paraṇabhede 'pi karturekatvāccakṣuṣā dṛṣṭamarthaṃ yajñadattaḥ pratyabhijānāti yamahamadarśaṃ tamahaṃ spṛśāmīti /
analyzed: na evam ekatve sati yathā paraṇa bhede pi kartuḥ ekatvāt cakṣuṣā dṛṣṭam artham yajñadattaḥ pratyabhijānāti yam aham adarśam tam aham spṛśāmi iti
translated: Not so. If there were only one, then just as in the case of difference of action, Yajñadatta recognizes the object seen by Devadatta as “I saw that, I touch that,”

analyzed: tathā devadatta śarīra sthena ātmanā dṛṣṭam artham yajñadattaḥ pratyabhijānīyāt  śarīra bhede pi ātmanasaḥ
translated: in the same way, Yajñadatta would recognize the object seen by the Self residing in Devadatta’s body.🔽Even in the case of difference of bodies, the Self is one.

analyzed: śarīra bhede pi ātmanaḥ pratyabhijñātuḥ eka tvāt
translated: Even in the case of difference of bodies, the Self is one, being the recognizer.

analyzed: kartuḥ eka tve pi manaḥ bhedāt vyavasthā iti ced na
translated: If it be said that the arrangement is due to the difference of mind, even in the case of one agent, not so.

analyzed: karaṇa tvāt manasaḥ
translated: Because the mind is an instrument.

analyzed: karaṇa bhedasya cakṣuḥ ādeḥ bheda vyavasthāpaka tva ayogāt iti uktam
translated: And it has been said that the difference of the instrument, such as the eye, cannot serve to establish difference.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ ādi karaṇānām avyavasthāpaka tve pi manaḥ karaṇam
translated: Even though the eye and other sense organs are not the determiners, the mind is the instrument.

analyzed: vyavasthāpakam iti ced na
translated: If it be said that, even though the eye and other organs are not determiners, the mind is the organ which is the determiner, [we say no].

analyzed: karaṇa tva aviśeṣāt
translated: [No, because] there is no difference in their being organs.

original: syādapyeṣā kalpanā yadyekātmatve dṛḍhaṃ pramāmaṃ syāt /
analyzed: syāt api eṣā kalpanā yadi eka ātma tve dṛḍham syāt
translated: This supposition might hold if there were a firm conviction of the unity of the self.

analyzed: na tu tat asti
translated: But that does not exist.

original: yetvātmaikatvavādāḥ śrutiṣu smṛtiṣu purāṇeṣu vā te nirañjanaḥ paramaṃ sāmyamupaiti
analyzed: ye tu ātma eka tva vādāḥ śrutiṣu smṛtiṣu purāṇeṣu vā te nirañjanaḥ paramam sāmyam upaiti
translated: Those doctrines of the unity of the self in the Upaniṣads, Smṛtis, and Purāṇas, such as The stainless one attains the highest unity,

original: mama sādharmyamāgatāḥ uttamaḥ puruṣastvanyaḥ ityādibhirātmabedavacanaiḥ pratyakṣādibhiśca🔽virodhānnaikāntataḥ śaknuvantyātmaikatvaṃ niścāyayitum // //
analyzed: mama sādharmyam āgatāḥ uttamaḥ puruṣaḥ tu anyaḥ ityādibhiḥ ātma beda vacanaiḥ pratyakṣa ādibhiḥ ca  virodhāt na ekāntataḥ śaknuvanti ātma ekatvam niścāyayitum
translated: Those who have come to be like me, But there is another supreme person, etc., and by perception etc., are contradicted by the statements of the difference of the self, and therefore cannot conclusively establish the unity of the self.

original: vacanānāṃ hi mitho virodhe siddhavastuviṣayatvena ca vikalpāsaṃbhave pramāṇāntarānnirṇayaḥ syāt /
analyzed: vacanānām hi mithas virodhe siddha vastu viṣaya tvena ca vikalpa asaṃbhave pramāṇa antarāt nirṇayaḥ syāt
translated: For when there is a mutual contradiction among statements, and the impossibility of option due to their being about an established thing, the determination should be by another means of knowledge.

analyzed: tat ca pramāṇa antaram bhede eva samartham iti aikātmya vādānām availakṣaṇya para tvam pūrvokta nyāyena avagantavyam
translated: And that other means of knowledge is capable of establishing difference itself. Therefore, the purport of the statements of the unity of the self should be understood as being non-difference, as explained before.

analyzed: vispaṣṭam ca etat vāyu dṛṣṭānta upādānāt veṇu randhra ādi bhedena bhedaḥ ṣaṣ jāti saṃjñitaḥ
translated: And this is clearly stated by the use of the example of the wind: The difference designated as the six notes is due to the difference of the holes of the flute, etc.

analyzed: abheda vyāpinaḥ vāyoḥ tathā tasya mahātmanaḥ iti
translated: Of the all-pervading wind, and likewise of that great Self.

original: na hi vāyudravyaṃ sarvatraikaṃ vyaktibhedasya spaṣṭatvāt /
analyzed: na hi vāyu dravyam sarvatra ekam vyakti bhedasya spaṣṭa tvāt
translated: For the substance of wind is not one everywhere, because the difference of individuals is clear.

analyzed: a vilakṣaṇa svabhāvasya tu vāyoḥ veṇu randhrākṛtam ṣaḍja ādi vailakṣaṇyam
translated: But the difference of the notes ṣaḍja etc. of wind is due to the shape of the holes in the flute, of the nature of wind which is not different.

analyzed: eva ātmanaḥ pi paśu manuṣya ādi vailakṣaṇyam deha saṃbandha kṛtam na svābhāvikam iti ayam eva arthaḥ
translated: In the same way, the difference of the Self in animals, humans etc. is due to the connection with the body, not natural. This is the very meaning.

analyzed: vāyoḥ iti tasya iti ca ekavacanam sāmānya abhiprāyam
translated: The singular number in of wind and of that is intended to refer to the general.

original: tasmātpratiśarīraṃ bhinnā evātmānaḥ nityāḥ sarvagatā evaṃ ca baddhamuktādivyavasthāpi yuktatarā bhavati //
analyzed: tasmāt pratiśarīram bhinnāḥ eva ātmānaḥ nityāḥ sarva gatāḥ evam ca baddha mukta ādi vyavasthā api yuktatarā bhavati
translated: Therefore, the selves are different in each body, eternal, and all-pervading. And thus the arrangement of the bound, the liberated, etc. becomes more reasonable.

analyzed: iti ātma vādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the doctrine of the Self.

analyzed: mokṣa vāda ārambhaḥ
translated: The beginning of the doctrine of liberation.

analyzed: kaḥ punar ayam mokṣaḥ nāma
translated: But what is this so-called liberation?

original: vicitravāsanāvaśena vicitranīlapītādirūpeṇa pravahato jñānasaṃtānasya niḥśeṣavāsanocchedānnīlapītādivaicitryaṃ hitvā kevalaṃ saṃvinmātreṇāvasthānamiti 🔽kecit /
analyzed: vicitra vāsanā vaśena vicitra nīla pīta ādi rūpeṇa pravahataḥ jñāna saṃtānasya niḥśeṣa vāsanā ucchedāt nīla pīta ādi vaicitryam hitvā kevalam saṃvid mātreṇa avasthānam iti  kecid
translated: Some say it is the state of the stream of consciousness, flowing in various forms such as blue, yellow etc. due to various latent impressions, remaining only in the mere consciousness by abandoning the variety of blue, yellow etc. due to the complete removal of latent impressions.

analyzed: apare tu dīpa saṃtānasya iva jñāna saṃtāpanasya uparamam
translated: But others say it is the cessation of the stream of consciousness, like the cessation of a stream of lamps.

analyzed: ubhayam api etat bāhya artha abhāva mūlam iti tad sadbhāva pratipādanena eva nirākṛtam
translated: Both of these are rooted in the non-existence of external objects, so they are refuted by the very establishment of their existence.

analyzed: apare tu prapañca vilayam apavargam āhuḥ
translated: Others, however, say that the dissolution of the world is liberation.

original: avidyānirmito hi prapañcaḥ svapnaprapañcavat prabodhenaiva brahmavidyayā avidyāyāṃ vilīnāyāṃ svayameva vilīyate /
analyzed: avidyā nirmitaḥ hi prapañcaḥ svapna prapañca vat prabodhena eva brahma vidyayā avidyāyām vilīnāyām svayam eva vilīyate
translated: For the world, which is created by ignorance, dissolves by itself alone, like a dream-world, by the knowledge of Brahman itself, when ignorance has dissolved.

original: tathāhi śrutiḥ yatra hi dvaitamiva bhavati taditara itaraṃ paśyati yatra tvasya sarvāmātmaivābhūttatkena kaṃ paśyet🔽iti ////
analyzed: tathā hi śrutiḥ yatra hi dvaitam iva bhavati tat itaraḥ itaram paśyati yatra tu asya sarvām ātmā eva abhūt tat kena kam paśyet  iti
translated: Thus, the scripture says: Where there is duality as it were, then one sees the other; but when the Self alone has become all this, then how should he see another?

original: tadidamapi prapañcasyāvidyānirmitatvanirāraṇena paramārthatvapratipādanānnirastameveti ātmaivedaṃ sarvamiti sarvasyātmā bhoktetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tat idam api prapañcasya avidyā nirmita tva nirāraṇena paramārtha tva pratipādanāt nirastam eva iti ātmā eva idam sarvam iti sarvasya ātmā bhoktā iti arthaḥ
translated: This too is refuted by the establishment of the ultimate reality of the world through the examination of its being created by ignorance. Thus, the Self is all this means that the Self is the enjoyer of all.

original: yathā yaḥ kāmayeta rāṣṭraṃ syāmiti rāṣṭrasya bhoktetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yathā yaḥ kāmayeta rāṣṭram syām iti rāṣṭrasya bhoktā iti arthaḥ
translated: Just as one who desires may I be a king means may I be the enjoyer of the kingdom.

original: yathā kāmayeta sarvamidaṃ bhaveyamiti sarvasya bhoktā bhaveyamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: yathā kāmayeta sarvam idam bhaveyam iti sarvasya bhoktā bhaveyam iti arthaḥ
translated: Just as one desires may all this be mine means may I be the enjoyer of all.

analyzed: tathā ātmā sarvam iti sarvasya ātmā bhoktā iti arthaḥ
translated: Similarly, the Self is all means that the Self is the enjoyer of all.

original: yattu yatra hi dvaitamiva bhavatīti dvaitabhāvasya bhrāntitvavacanaṃ tadaupacārikam
analyzed: yat tu yatra hi dvaitam iva bhavati iti dvaita bhāvasya bhrānti tva vacanam tat aupacārikam
translated: But the statement that the appearance of duality is illusory, as in the passage, Where there is duality as it were, is figurative.

analyzed: yathā khalu svapna prapañca indrajāla mṛgatoya ādiḥ kiyantañcid kālam dṛṣṭi patham āpannaḥ
translated: For just as the manifold of dreams, magic tricks, mirages, etc., which has come within the range of vision for some time,

analyzed: paścāt vilīnaḥ bhogya tām ativartate tathā ayam śarīra indriya viṣaya rūpa prapañcaḥ pyasya ātmanaḥ
translated: afterwards disappears and transcends the state of being an object of experience, in the same way this manifold of body, sense, and object, which is the appearance of the Self,

analyzed: kiyantañcid kālam upabhogyaḥ san paścāt vināśāt anupabhogyaḥ bhavati iti anena sādṛśyena
translated: having been an object of experience for some time, becomes not an object of experience after destruction. By this similarity,

analyzed: bhrāntiḥ iti upacāreṇa ucyate puruṣāṇām viṣaya bhogeṣu āsthā nivartanena muktau abhirucim janayitum
translated: it is said figuratively to be an illusion, in order to generate a liking for liberation by turning away the minds of men from attachment to the enjoyment of objects.

original: yadapi yatra tvasya sarvamātmaivābhūditi muktāvātmano 'dvitīyatvacanaṃ tadapi na prapañcasvarūpaniṣedhārthaṃ kitu sata eva prapañcasyātmasaṃbandhaniṣedhārthaṃ /
analyzed: yat api yatra tu asya sarvam ātmā eva abhūt iti muktau ātmanaḥ dvitīya tva canam tat api na prapañca svarūpa niṣedha artham kitu sataḥ eva prapañcasya ātma saṃbandha niṣedha artham
translated: And the statement in the passage on liberation, Wherein all this has become just the Self, that the Self is without a second, is also not for the purpose of denying the nature of the manifold, but for the purpose of denying the relation of the manifold to the Self, which exists.

analyzed: asya itivacanāt
translated: Because of the word asya, of this.

analyzed: na hi atra etāvat ucyate yatra sarvam ātmā eva abhūt iti
translated: For here it is not said only that where all this has become just the Self.

analyzed: kim tarhi
translated: What then?

analyzed: yatra tu asya sarvam ātmā eva iti
translated: Wherein all this is just the Self of this.

analyzed: tena asya ayam arthaḥ yatra yasyām avasthāyām muktau iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, this is the meaning: in which state, meaning in the state of liberation.

original: asya ātmano dṛśyatvena darśanasādhanatvena darśanāyatanatvena vā na kiñcidanyasaṃbandhi vidyate kintvātmaivāsya sarvaṃ nānyakiñcit tadā kena
analyzed: asya ātmanaḥ dṛśya tvena darśana sādhana tvena darśana āyatana tvena vā na kiñcid anya saṃbandhi vidyate kintu ātmā eva asya sarvam na anya kiñcid tadā kena
translated: Therefore, this is the meaning: in that state, in the state of liberation, this Self has nothing else related to it, either as the object of vision, or as the means of vision, or as the abode of vision. But the Self itself is all of this, not anything else. Then by what

analyzed: kam paśyet iti
translated: would one see whom?

original: yathā loke yasya na kiñcidapi bāndhavo vittaṃ vāsti sa evaṃ vadati na me kañcidasti ahameva sarvaṃ tatra saṃbandhyantaraṃ na kiñcidastītyetāvadvivakṣitam /
analyzed: yathā loke yasya na kiñcid api bāndhavaḥ vittam vā asti saḥ evam vadati na me kañcid asti aham eva sarvam tatra saṃbandhi antaram na kiñcid asti iti etāvat vivakṣitam
translated: Just as in the world, one whose relatives and wealth are all gone, speaks thus: I have no one at all. I myself am all there. There is no other relative at all. This much is intended.

original: evaṃ muktāvātmaivātmanaḥ sarvamiti saṃbandhyantarābhāvamātraṃ vivakṣitaṃ na prapañcasvarūpabhāvaḥ /
analyzed: evam muktau ātmā eva ātmanaḥ sarvam iti saṃbandhi antara abhāva mātram vivakṣitam na prapañca svarūpa bhāvaḥ
translated: Similarly, in liberation, the Self itself is all of the Self. Only the absence of any other related thing is intended, not the existence of the nature of the universe.

analyzed: tasmāt na prapañca vilayaḥ mokṣaḥ kintu prapañca saṃbandha vilayaḥ
translated: Therefore, liberation is not the dissolution of the universe, but the dissolution of the relation with the universe.

original: tredhā hi prapañcaḥ puruṣaṃ badhnāti bhogāyatanaṃ śarīraṃ bhogasādhanānīndriyāṇi bhogyāḥ śabdādayo viṣayāḥ /
analyzed: tredhā hi prapañcaḥ puruṣam badhnāti bhoga āyatanam śarīram bhoga sādhanāni indriyāṇi bhogyāḥ śabda ādayaḥ viṣayāḥ
translated: For the universe binds the soul in three ways: the body, which is the abode of experience; the senses, which are the means of experience; and sound and other objects, which are to be experienced.

analyzed: bhogaḥ iti ca parokṣa anubhava
translated: And experience refers to the non-apparent perception of pleasure and pain.

original: ucyate tadasya trividhasyāpi bandhasyātyantiko vilayo mokṣaḥ ////
analyzed: ucyate tat asya trividhasya api bandhasya ātyantikaḥ vilayaḥ mokṣaḥ
translated: It is said that the absolute destruction of this threefold bondage is liberation.

analyzed: kim idam ātyantika tvam pūrva utpannānām śarīra indriya viṣayāṇām vināśaḥ
translated: What is this absolute nature? The destruction of the previously arisen body, senses, and objects.

analyzed: anutpannānām ca ātyantikaḥ nutpādaḥ
translated: And the absolute non-arising of those that have not yet arisen.

analyzed: katham atyanta anutpattiḥ
translated: How is there absolute non-arising?

analyzed: utpādakayoḥ dharma adharmayoḥ niḥśeṣayoḥ parikṣāyāt
translated: From the complete destruction of both virtue and vice, which are the causes of arising.

analyzed: saḥ yam prapañca saṃbandhaḥ bandhasya dvi mokṣaḥ ca mokṣaḥ
translated: This is the bondage of the connection with the world, and liberation is the liberation from that bondage.

analyzed: ānanda mokṣa vādaḥ
translated: The doctrine of liberation as bliss.

analyzed: nanu evam aśeṣa dharma kṣayāt muktasya na kicid sukham syāt
translated: If it is so, then for one liberated through the destruction of all virtues, there would be no happiness at all.

original: tataścāpuruṣārtho mokṣaḥ syāt /🔽naiṣa doṣaḥ na hi dharmajanyo muktasyātmanaḥ tathā satyutpattimattvāt vināśī syāt tatrāpunarāvṛttiśrutervirodhaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tatas ca apuruṣa arthaḥ mokṣaḥ syāt  na eṣa doṣaḥ na hi dharma janyaḥ muktasya ātmanaḥ tathā sati utpattimat tvāt vināśī syāt tatra apunarāvṛtti śruteḥ virodhaḥ syāt
translated: And therefore liberation would not be the goal of man.

original: svābhāvikastvātmānandaḥ saṃsāreṇābhibhūtaḥ san nirmuktasaṃsārasyābhivyaktau bhogyo bhavati svābhāvikatve cānandasya ānandaṃ brahme tyādiśrutisahasraṃ
analyzed: svābhāvikaḥ tu ātma ānandaḥ saṃsāreṇa abhibhūtaḥ san nirmukta saṃsārasya abhivyaktau bhogyaḥ bhavati svābhāvika tve ca ānandasya ānandam brahma ityādi śruti sahasram
translated: This is not a fault. For the self liberated is not produced from virtue. If it were so, then being produced, it would perish. There would be a contradiction with the teaching of non-return there. But the bliss of the self is natural. Being overwhelmed by worldly existence, it becomes enjoyable when worldly existence is completely liberated. And in the case of the naturalness of bliss, the thousands of scriptures such as Brahman is bliss

analyzed: pramāṇam
translated: are the means of valid knowledge.

original: nanu sukhābhāve 'pi śrutirasti aśarīraṃ vāva santaṃ na priyāpriye spṛśataḥ iti /
analyzed: nanu sukha abhāve pi śrutiḥ asti aśarīram vāva santam na priya apriye spṛśataḥ iti
translated: But there is a Vedic text to the effect that there is no happiness, (viz.,) 'When he is bodiless, then neither pleasure nor pain touches him.'

analyzed: satyam viṣaya sukha abhiprāyam tu evañjātīyakam
translated: True; but such texts as this are meant to refer to the happiness of objects.

analyzed: anyathā ānanda śruti virodhāt
translated: Otherwise there would be a contradiction with the text about bliss.

original: atha sukhābhāvavacanabalenānandavacanameva duḥkhābhāvābhiprāyaṃ kimiti na vyākhyāyate sukhābhāvavacanānāmatyalpatvātteṣāmevānyathākaraṇaṃ yuktaṃ
analyzed: atha sukha abhāva vacana balena ānanda vacanam eva duḥkha abhāva abhiprāyam kim iti na vyākhyāyate sukha abhāva vacanānām ati alpa tvāt teṣām eva anyathā karaṇam yuktam
translated: Now, why is it not explained that the text about bliss is meant to refer to the absence of pain, on the strength of the texts about the absence of happiness? Because the texts about the absence of happiness are very few, it is proper to explain them in some other way,

analyzed: na bhūyasām ānanda vacanānām
translated: and not the many texts about bliss.

analyzed: kiñca ānanda śabdasya duḥkha abhāva para tve tyanta svārtha hāniḥ syāt
translated: Moreover, if the word 'bliss' referred to the absence of pain, there would be a great loss of the meaning of the word.

original: sukhaśabdasya tu sāmānyavacanasya viśeṣe 'pi vyākhyāne nātīva svārthahāniriti tadeva yuktam ////
analyzed: sukha śabdasya tu sāmānya vacanasya viśeṣe vyākhyāne na atīva svārtha hāniḥ iti tat eva yuktam
translated: But if the word 'happiness,' which is a general term, is explained even in a particular sense, there is not a very great loss of its meaning. Therefore that (explanation) alone is proper.

analyzed: nanu vidyamānaḥ pi ānandaḥ kiñcitkaraḥ eva
translated: But even if bliss exists, if it is not experienced, it is of no use at all.

analyzed: na ca muktasya sarva karaṇa hīnasya ānanda anubhavaḥ saṃbhavati
translated: And the experience of bliss is not possible for one who is liberated and devoid of all organs.

analyzed: sva prakāśa yam ānandaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it be said that bliss is self-luminous, (we say) no;

analyzed: saṃsāra avasthāyām aprakāśāt
translated: because it is not luminous in the state of transmigration.

original: nanu tatrāpyānandasvabhāvaḥ puruṣaḥ prakāśata eva ātmani premotpatteḥ /
analyzed: nanu tatra api ānanda svabhāvaḥ puruṣaḥ prakāśate eva ātmani prema utpatteḥ
translated: But there also the soul, which is of the nature of bliss, is manifested, because love arises in the soul.

analyzed: satyam iti bruvāṇasya ati sāhasikasya na uttaram vācyam
translated: To one who says True, and is very bold, no reply can be given.

original: yadi saṃsāriṇo 'pi paramānandamanubhaveyustato muktasya na kaścidatiśaya iti tadevāpuruṣārthatvaṃ mokṣasyāpadyeta /
analyzed: yadi paramānandam anubhaveyuḥ tatas muktasya na kaścid atiśayaḥ iti tat eva a puruṣa artha tvam mokṣasya āpadyeta
translated: If even the transmigrating souls were to experience the highest bliss, then there would be no difference between the liberated and the unliberated, and liberation would again become not a human goal.

analyzed: atas balāt asukha rūpasya ayam abhibhūtaḥ na prakāśate
translated: Therefore, this [bliss] of the nature of unhappiness, being overpowered, does not manifest.

analyzed: kaḥ yam prakāśamānasya abhibhavaḥ nāma
translated: What is this so-called over-powering of what is being manifested?

analyzed: prakāśa nivāraṇam hi abhibhavaḥ
translated: For over-powering is the prevention of manifestation.

analyzed: na ca prakāśamānasya aprakāśanam saṃbhavati
translated: And the non-manifestation of what is being manifested is not possible.

original: yadi tu naiva prakāśate saṃsārāvasthāyāṃ tasyāmavasthāyāmasataḥ prakāśasya muktāvasthāyāmutpadyamānasya kāraṇaṃ vaktavyam /
analyzed: yadi tu nā eva prakāśate saṃsāra avasthāyām tasyām avasthāyām asataḥ prakāśasya mukta avasthāyām utpadyamānasya kāraṇam vaktavyam
translated: But if it is not manifested at all in the state of transmigration, then in that state, the cause of the manifestation of the non-existent light in the state of liberation must be stated.

original: vijñānameva ca prakāśākhyasya phalasya kāraṇaṃ taccendriyādhīnam /
analyzed: vijñānam eva ca prakāśa ākhyasya phalasya kāraṇam tat ca indriya adhīnam
translated: And consciousness alone is the cause of the fruit called light, and that depends on the senses.

original: na ca muktasyendriyāṇi saṃbhavantīti kathamānandānubhavaḥ syāt ////
analyzed: na ca muktasya indriyāṇi saṃbhavanti iti katham ānanda anubhavaḥ syāt
translated: And since the senses are not possible for the liberated one, how could there be the experience of bliss?

original: ucyate bāhyendriyāṇyeva muktasya nivartante manastu tasyāmavasthāyāmanuvartate ityānandaśrutibalādevādhyavasīyate /
analyzed: ucyate bāhya indriyāṇi eva muktasya nivartante manaḥ tu tasyām avasthāyām anuvartate iti ānanda śruti balāt eva adhyavasīyate
translated: It is said that the external senses of the liberated one cease, but the mind continues in that state. This is ascertained by the power of the scripture speaking of bliss.

original: evaṃ jñānaṃ ca na hi vijñāturvijñāterviparilopo vidyate iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: evam jñānam ca na hi vijñātuḥ vijñāteḥ viparilopaḥ vidyate iti śruteḥ
translated: Similarly, knowledge is not destroyed, as stated in the scripture For the knower of the known, there is no destruction.

analyzed: vijñāna ghana śruteḥ ca
translated: And because of the scripture speaking of the mass of consciousness.

analyzed: tasmāt mukta avasthāyām mānasa pratyakṣeṇa parama ānandam anubhavan ātmā avatiṣṭhate
translated: Therefore, in the state of liberation, the self abides experiencing supreme bliss through mental perception.

analyzed: tat uktam nijam yat tu ātma caitanyam ānandaḥ ca iṣyate ca yaḥ
translated: That is said: But one's own self-consciousness and the bliss that is accepted,

original: yacca nityavibhutvādi tairātmā naiva mucyate iti /
analyzed: yat ca nitya vibhu tva ādi taiḥ ātmā nā eva mucyate iti
translated: And what is eternal, all-pervading, etc., by those the self is not liberated at all.

analyzed: yat tu tasmāt karmam akṣayāt eva hetu abhāvena mucyate
translated: But it is liberated from that by the absence of the cause itself, due to the imperishability of karma.

analyzed: na hi abhāva ātmakam muktvā mokṣa nitya tva kāraṇam
translated: For, apart from the state of non-existence, there is no cause for the eternality of liberation.

analyzed: iti vārtikam tat para matam iti evam ānanda mokṣa vādinaḥ matam
translated: This is the commentary. Thus, this is the view of those who speak of bliss and liberation.

original: apare tvāhuḥ abhāvātmakatvavacanameva svamatamupapattyabhidhānāt ānandavacanaṃ tūpanyāsamātratvā paramatam /
analyzed: apare tu āhuḥ abhāva ātmaka tva vacanam eva sva matam upapatti abhidhānāt ānanda vacanam tu upanyāsa mātra tvā para matam
translated: Others, however, say that the statement about the nature of non-existence itself is their own view, because it is stated with reasoning. But the statement about bliss is merely a presentation, the view of others.

analyzed: na hi muktasya ānanda anubhavaḥ saṃbhavati karaṇa abhāvāt
translated: For the experience of bliss is not possible for one who is liberated, because of the absence of sense organs.

analyzed: manaḥ syāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the mind would be there, it is not so.

analyzed: amanaska tva śruteḥ amanaḥ ṣaṣ avāc iti
translated: Because of the Vedic text stating the absence of mind, without mind, without speech.
Establishing the absence of knowledge in the state of liberation.

original: yattu na hi vijñāturvijñāterviparilopo vidyate iti tajjñānaśaktyabhiprāyam /🔽anyathā hi suṣuptāvapi jñānānuvṛttiruktā
analyzed: yat tu na hi vijñātuḥ vijñāteḥ viparilopaḥ vidyate iti tat jñāna śakti abhiprāyam  anyathā hi suṣuptau api jñāna anuvṛttiḥ uktā
translated: As for the statement there is no cessation of the knower's knowledge, that refers to the potentiality of knowledge.🔽Otherwise, it would be said that knowledge continues even in deep sleep.

analyzed: syāt sā ca saṃvid hi ruddhā iti uktam
translated: And that consciousness is obstructed - this has been stated.

analyzed: vispaṣṭam ca asya śakti abhiprāya tvam
translated: And this clearly refers to potentiality.

original: evaṃ hi śrūyate yadvai tanna paśyati paśyanvai tanna paśyati /
analyzed: evam hi śrūyate yat vai tat na paśyati paśyan vai tat na paśyati
translated: For it is heard thus: What it does not see, indeed, seeing it does not see.

original: na hi draṣṭurdṛṣṭerviparilopo vidyate /🔽avināśitvāt na tu taddvitīyamasti tato 'nyadvibhaktaṃ yatpaśyet evamanyānyapi vākyāni jighranvai
analyzed: na hi draṣṭuḥ dṛṣṭeḥ viparilopaḥ vidyate  avināśi tvāt na tu tat dvitīyam asti tatas yat paśyet evam anyāni api vākyāni jighran vai
translated: For there is no cessation of the seer's seeing.

original: tanna jighrati na hi ghrātughrāterviparilopo vidyate /
analyzed: tat na jighrati na hi ghrātu ghrāteḥ viparilopaḥ vidyate
translated: Because of its imperishability. But there is no second thing separate from it which it could see. Similarly, the other statements are: Smelling it, indeed, it does not smell. For there is no cessation of the smell's smelling.

analyzed: na śrotuḥ śruteḥ viparilopaḥ vidyate
translated: For there is no cessation of the hearer's hearing.

analyzed: na spraṣṭuḥ spṛṣṭeḥ viparilopaḥ vidyate
translated: For there is no cessation of the toucher's touch.🔽For there is no cessation of the knower's knowledge.

analyzed: na jñātuḥ jñāteḥ viparilopaḥ vidyate tatra tatra dṛṣṭi ghrāti śruti spṛṣṭi śabdāḥ cakṣuḥ ghrāṇa śrotra tvac indriya janyānām
translated: There is no destruction of the knower, the known, or the knowledge. The words 'seeing', 'smelling', 'hearing', 'touching', and 'sound' denote the objects of form, smell, sound, and touch produced by the eye, nose, ear, and skin sense organs,

analyzed: rūpa gandha śabda sparśa viṣayāṇām vācakāḥ na artha antara viṣayāṇām na api vijñāna sāmānyasya
translated: not objects of a different nature, nor of the general consciousness.

original: nacaiṣāṃ jñānaviśeṣāṇāṃ vācakāḥ nārthāntaraviṣayāṇāṃ nāpi vijñānasāmānyasya /
analyzed: na ca eṣām jñāna viśeṣāṇām vācakāḥ na artha antara viṣayāṇām na api vijñāna sāmānyasya
translated: And they are not denotative of these specific cognitions, nor of objects of a different nature, nor of the general consciousness.

original: nacaiṣāṃ jñānaviśeṣāṇāṃ suṣuptau muktau vā kathañcidapyaparilopaḥ saṃbhavati /
analyzed: na ca eṣām jñāna viśeṣāṇām suṣuptau muktau vā kathañcid api aparilopaḥ saṃbhavati
translated: And there is no destruction at all of these specific cognitions in deep sleep or liberation.

original: nahi tadānīmindriyāṇi santi nāpi gandhādayo jñāyante tadubhayābhāve ca na śrutyādiśabdavācyajñānaviśeṣāḥ saṃbhavanti ////
analyzed: nahi tadānīm indriyāṇi santi nā api gandha ādayaḥ jñāyante tad ubhaya abhāve ca na śruti ādi śabda vācya jñāna viśeṣāḥ saṃbhavanti
translated: For at that time there are no sense organs, nor are smells etc. known. And in the absence of both of them, the specific cognitions denoted by the words 'seeing', 'smelling', 'hearing' etc. are not possible.

original: nanu yathā prakāśyāsannidhāvapi savituḥ prakāśakatvaṃ nityam /
analyzed: nanu yathā prakāśya asannidhau api savituḥ prakāśaka tvam nityam
translated: But just as the sun's illuminating nature is always present even in the absence of something to be illuminated,

analyzed: evam indriya abhāve pi nityā eva dṛṣṭiḥ iti ced
translated: in the same way, seeing is always present even in the absence of the sense organs, if it is argued.

original: sayādevam yadi jñānamātraṃ dṛṣṭyādiśabdānāṃ vācyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yadi jñāna mātram dṛṣṭi ādi śabdānām vācyam syāt
translated: This may be so if the word 'seeing' etc. denoted mere knowledge.

analyzed: na tu tathā asti
translated: But it is not so.

analyzed: loka prasiddhi abhāvāt
translated: Because it is not well-known in the world.

original: yathā lokaṃ ca śabdārthāvadhāraṇaṃ na yatheccham /
analyzed: yathā lokam ca śabda artha avadhāraṇam na yatheccham
translated: As the determination of the meaning of a word in the world is not according to one's wish.

analyzed: na hi loke gandhāt anyat ghrāṇam jighrati iti ucyate
translated: For in the world, it is not said that the nose smells something other than smell.

original: gandhamapi yadā ghrāṇādanyenānumānādinā jānāti tadā na jighratītyucyate /
analyzed: gandham api yadā ghrāṇāt anyena anumāna ādinā jānāti tadā na jighrati iti ucyate
translated: When one knows smell even by inference etc. other than the nose, then it is said that it does not smell.

analyzed: tasmāt ghrāṇa ādīya janya gandha ādi viṣaya jñāna viśeṣa vācinaḥ ghrāti ādi śabdāḥ
translated: Therefore, the words smelled etc. denote the special knowledge of smell etc. which is produced by the nose etc.

original: na ca teṣāṃ suṣuptau muktau vā saṃbhavatyaparilopaḥ /
analyzed: na ca teṣām suṣuptau muktau vā saṃbhavati aparilopaḥ
translated: And their non-cessation does not occur in deep sleep or in liberation.

analyzed: tasmāt ghrāṇa ādi śaktau eva prarocana artham ghrāṇa ādi upacāraḥ
translated: Therefore, the figurative use of nose etc. is for the purpose of delighting in the capacity of the nose etc.

original: yathā tema hyannaṃ kriyate iti śaktivartamānatvena prarocanārthaṃ kriyate iti vartamānatvopacāraḥ /
analyzed: yathā hi annam kriyate iti śakti vartamāna tvena prarocana artham kriyate iti vartamāna tva upacāraḥ
translated: Just as in food is prepared, the use of the present tense is for the purpose of delighting in the presentness of the capacity.

original: tasmāt na jñātujñāterviparilopo vidyata ityedapi śaktyabhiprāyameva ////
analyzed: tasmāt na jñātu jñāteḥ viparilopaḥ vidyate śakti abhiprāyam eva
translated: Therefore, this statement there is no cessation of the knower and the known is also intended to refer to the capacity.

analyzed: yat tu āditya prakāśaka tva vat iti
translated: As for the statement like the illuminating of light,

analyzed: kim tasya prakāśaka tvam abhipretam
translated: what is meant by its illuminating?

analyzed: yadi timira utsāraṇam
translated: If it is the dispelling of darkness,

analyzed: tat nityam asya iva sarvadā hi asau avyavahiteṣu deśeṣu timiram utsādayati eva
translated: that is always present in it, for it always dispels darkness in unobstructed regions.

analyzed: nanu evam ātmā sarvadā śṛṇoti suṣupta avaśravaṇāt
translated: But in that case, the soul would always hear, because there is no hearing in deep sleep.

analyzed: atha jñāna janaka tvam āditya deśeṣu timiram utsādayati eva
translated: Or if the sun, by producing knowledge, removes darkness in its own place,

analyzed: na tu evam ātmā sarvadā śṛṇoti suṣupta avaśravaṇāt
translated: in the same way, the soul would always hear, because there is no hearing in deep sleep.

analyzed: atha jñāna janaka tvam ādityasya prakāśaka tvam na tat nityam
translated: Or if the sun's illuminating is its knowledge-producing nature, that is not eternal.

analyzed: tasmāt sāmarthyam eva tatra api nityam
translated: Therefore, the capacity alone is eternal even there.

analyzed: tasmāt jñānaśakti abhiprāyam idam nitya tva abhidhānam
translated: Therefore, this statement of eternality is intended to convey the power of knowledge.

original: eṣā hyatra vacanavyaktiḥ yadetatsuṣuptau muktau vātmā na paśyati paśyanneva draṣṭuṃ śaknuvanneva na paśyati /
analyzed: eṣā hi atra vacana vyaktiḥ yat etat suṣuptau muktau vā ātmā na paśyati paśyan eva draṣṭum śaknuvan eva na paśyati
translated: For this is the meaning of the statement here: That the soul, in deep sleep or in liberation, does not see, although able to see as a seer.

original: na hi draṣcurātmano yā darśanaśaktistasyāḥ kadācidapi lopo vidyate sāhyavināśinīti
analyzed: na hi draṣcuḥ ātmanaḥ yā darśana śaktiḥ tasyāḥ kadācid api lopaḥ vidyate sā ahyavināśinī iti
translated: For the power of seeing of the soul, the seer, is never lost at any time, since it is indestructible.

original: na draṣṭurdvitīyamanyaddarśanasādhanaṃ cakṣurvyāpārarūpaṃ dṛśyaṃ vā tasyāmavasthāyāsamasti yato darśanaṃ syāt /
analyzed: na draṣṭuḥ dvitīyam anyat darśana sādhanam cakṣuḥ vyāpāra rūpam dṛśyam vā tasyām avasthāyāsam asti yatas darśanam syāt
translated: And there is no second means of seeing for the seer, in the form of the function of the eye or the seen, from which there would be seeing, in that state.

original: yadyapi dṛśyaṃ rūpādikaṃ svarūpatastasyāmavasthāyāmasti tathāpi dṛśyatā darśanayogyatā tasyāmavasthāyāṃ nāstīti tena rūpeṇābhāvāddṛśyaṃ nāstītyucyate /
analyzed: yadi api dṛśyam rūpa ādikam svarūpataḥ tasyām avasthāyām asti tathā api dṛśya tā darśana yogya tā tasyām avasthāyām na asti iti tena rūpeṇa abhāvāt dṛśyam na asti iti ucyate
translated: Although the visible form, etc. exist in their own nature in that state, still the visibility, the suitability for being seen, does not exist in that state. Therefore, it is said that the visible does not exist because of non-existence in that form.

analyzed: tasmāt sādhana antara vaikalyāt tasyām avasthāyām na paśyati na śakti vaikalyāt
translated: Therefore, he does not see in that state due to the deficiency of other means, not due to the deficiency of power.

analyzed: śaktiḥ tu na kadācid api lupyate iti
translated: But the power is never lost at all.

analyzed: evam anyeṣām api vākyānām yojanā
translated: The arrangement of the other statements is also like this.

analyzed: tathā jñāna śakti aparilopaḥ eva ucyate
translated: Similarly, the non-loss of the power of knowledge is said to be the non-loss of the knower.

analyzed: jñāti śabdaḥ ca atra anumāna ādi jñāna paraḥ cakṣuḥ ādi jñānānām sva śabdaiḥ ukta tvāt
translated: And the word knower here refers to the knowledge of inference, etc., because the knowledge of the eye, etc. is stated by their own words.

original: evaṃ vijñānaṃ brahma vijñānaghana ityādīnāmapi śaktiparatvaṃ veditavyam /
analyzed: evam vijñānam brahma vijñāna ghanaḥ ityādīnām api śakti para tvam veditavyam
translated: Thus, it should be understood that even the statements Brahman is knowledge, Brahman is a mass of knowledge, etc. refer to power.

original: svayameva śrutyā śaktiparatvaṃ vyākhyātaṃ vijñānaghana evaitebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāyatānyevānu vinaśyatīti bhūtendriyanāśādātmāpi pramāṇāgocaratvamāpanno
analyzed: svayam eva śrutyā śakti paratvam vyākhyātam vijñāna ghanaḥ eva etebhyaḥ bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāyata ani eva anu vinaśyati iti bhūta indriya nāśāt ātmā api pramāṇa agocara tvam āpannaḥ
translated: The Shruti itself explains that they refer to power: Having arisen from these elements, it perishes along with them. Thus, the self also becomes the object of valid cognition due to the destruction of the elements and senses,

analyzed: vinaṣṭaḥ iva bhavati iti
translated: and becomes as if destroyed.

analyzed: na tasya itas pretasya muktasya saṃjñā asti iti
translated: For that departed one, who is liberated, there is no consciousness.

original: evaṃ yājñavalkyemanokte maitreyī codayatisma atraiva ṅagavān /
analyzed: evam maitreyī codayati sma atra eva ṅagavān
translated: Thus, when this was spoken by Yajnavalkya, Maitreyi raised the objection right there:

original: māmohitavān vijñānaghana iti na cāsti saṃjñeti viruddhābhidhānāt iti /
analyzed: māmohitavān vijñāna ghanaḥ iti na ca asti saṃjñā iti viruddha abhidhānāt iti
translated: You have deluded me, O Yajnavalkya, by saying 'the mass of consciousness' and 'there is no consciousness,' which are contradictory statements.

analyzed: ṣaṣṭha adhyāye tu vināśa avināśa virodhaḥ codayiṣyate iti vivekaḥ
translated: But in the sixth chapter, the contradiction of destruction and non-destruction will be raised - this is the distinction.

original: evaṃ codito yājñavalkyaḥ parihāramāha na vā are ahaṃmoha parasparaviruddhaṃ bravīmi /
analyzed: evam coditaḥ yājñavalkyaḥ parihāram āha na vai are aham moha paraspara viruddham bravīmi
translated: Thus questioned, Yajnavalkya gave the answer: O dear one, I do not speak what is mutually contradictory, namely 'I am deluded' and 'there is no consciousness.'

original: alaṃ vā are idaṃ vijñānāya atrātmatattvaṃ sarvāsvavasthāsu vijñānāya samarthamityarthastena vijñānaghanatvābhidhānaṃ sāmarthyābhiprāyamiti
analyzed: alam vai are idam vijñānāya atra ātma tattvam sarvāsu avasthāsu vijñānāya samartham iti arthaḥ tena vijñāna ghana tva abhidhānam sāmarthya abhiprāyam iti
translated: O dear one, this truth of the Self is capable of being known in all states. The meaning is that it is capable of being known. Therefore, the statement about being a mass of consciousness is explained as being intended to convey capability.

analyzed: vyākhyātam bhavati
translated: It becomes explained.

original: saṃbhavati ca śaktasyāpi jñānābhāva iti nāsti virodha ityabhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: saṃbhavati ca śaktasya api jñāna abhāvaḥ iti nā asti virodhaḥ iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: And the absence of knowledge is possible even for one who is capable. Thus there is no contradiction - this is the idea.

original: anayā ca śrutyā sarvavijñānaśrutayaḥ śaktyabhiprāyā vyākhyātāḥ ////
analyzed: anayā ca śrutyā sarva vijñāna śrutayaḥ śakti abhiprāyāḥ vyākhyātāḥ
translated: And by this scripture, all the statements about knowing everything are explained as being intended to convey capability.

original: yadi śaktirasti tatastasyāvasthāyāṃ tataḥ kena jñānānutpattiḥ jñānasādhanānāmindriyāṇāṃ jñeyānāṃ ca viṣayāṇāmabhāvāt /
analyzed: yadi śaktiḥ asti tatas tasya avasthāyām tatas kena jñāna anutpattiḥ jñāna sādhanānām indriyāṇām jñeyānām ca viṣayāṇām abhāvāt
translated: If there is power, then in that state, by what is knowledge not produced? Because of the absence of the sense organs which are the means of knowledge, and of the objects which are to be known.

original: tadāha yatra hi dvaitamiva bhavati taditara itaraṃ paśyati /
analyzed: tat āha yatra hi dvaitam iva bhavati tat itaraḥ itaram paśyati
translated: He says this: Where there is duality as it were, then one sees the other.

original: yatra tvasya sarvamātmaivābhūttatkena kaṃ paśyet ityādi /
analyzed: yatra tu asya sarvam ātmā eva abhūt tat kena kam paśyet ityādi
translated: But when everything has become the Self alone, by what and whom should one see? and so on.

analyzed: tat etat prāk eva vyākhyātam
translated: This has been explained earlier itself.

original: evamarthāntarajñāne sādhanābhāvānnirākṛte sati ātmānameva muktāvasthāyāṃ jānātvityāśaṅkyāha
analyzed: evam artha antara jñāne sādhana abhāvāt nirākṛte sati ātmānam eva mukta avasthāyām jānātu iti āśaṅkya āha
translated: Thus, when the means of knowledge have been refuted due to the absence of means in the knowledge of different objects, the doubt arises that the Self should be known in the liberated state. To this he says:

original: vijñātāramare kena vijānīyāt iti nahyātmāpi vināsādhanena jñātuṃ śakyate manasā khalvasau
analyzed: vijñātāram are kena vijānīyāt iti na hi ātmā api vinā a sādhanena jñātum śakyate manasā khalu asau
translated: By what can one know the knower? For the Self also cannot be known without means. Indeed, it is known by the mind

original: saṃsārāvasthāyāṃ jñāyate na ca muktasya manaḥsaṃbangho 'sti ataḥ kenātmānaṃ jānātviti
analyzed: saṃsāra avasthāyām jñāyate na ca muktasya manaḥ saṃbanghaḥ sti atas kena ātmānam jānātu iti
translated: in the state of worldly existence. And the liberated one has no connection with the mind. Therefore, by what should one know the Self?

original: vyakta eva muktasyātmajñānasyābhāve jñānaśaktimātrasyāvasthānaṃ śrutyā darśitaṃ /
analyzed: vyakte eva muktasya ātma jñānasya abhāve jñānaśakti mātrasya avasthānam śrutyā darśitam
translated: In the absence of the knowledge of the Self of the liberated one, the mere remaining of the power of knowledge is shown by the scripture itself.

analyzed: tasmāt niḥsaṃbandhaḥ nirānandaḥ ca mokṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, liberation is devoid of connection and devoid of bliss.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ jñāna ānanda svarūpa tvasya khaṇḍanam
translated: Refutation of the Self being of the nature of knowledge and bliss.

original: nanu nātmano 'nyadvijñānamānando vā kintvātmaiva jñānamānandaśca vijñānaṃ brahma ānandaṃ brahma iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: nanu na ātmanaḥ nyat vijñānam ānandaḥ vā kintu ātmā eva jñānam ānandaḥ ca vijñānam brahma ānandam brahma iti śruteḥ
translated: Is not the Self itself the knowledge and bliss, and not anything different from the Self? The Self is knowledge and bliss, as is declared in the Vedic texts, ‘Brahman is knowledge, bliss’ (Br. 4.5.15).

original: ātmā ca suṣuptiturīyayorapi bhavatīti kathaṃ vijñānasya cānandasya cābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: ātmā ca suṣupti turīyayoḥ api bhavati iti katham vijñānasya ca ānandasya ca abhāvaḥ
translated: But, it may be said, consciousness and bliss are not different from the Self; on the contrary, the Self is itself consciousness and bliss, as is declared by the texts, ‘Brahman is knowledge, bliss’ (Br. 4.3.31), ‘Brahman is knowledge, bliss’ (Br. 4.5.6). And the Self exists in the states of deep sleep and the fourth also; how then can consciousness and bliss be absent?

analyzed: na etat evam
translated: This is not so.

original: yaddhi vastvantaraprakāśajananasvabhāvaṃ vastu yasminsati kimapyarthāntaraṃ prakāśata eva talloke vijñānaśabdenocyate /
analyzed: yat hi vastu antara prakāśa janana svabhāvam vastu yasmin sati kim api artha antaram prakāśate eva tat loke vijñāna śabdena ucyate
translated: That object which has the nature of producing the light of another object, and in the presence of which some other object is indeed illuminated, is called consciousness in the world.

analyzed: na ca ātmani sati kiñcid anyat prakāśate eva
translated: And in the presence of the Self, nothing else is indeed illuminated.

analyzed: vidyamāne pi
translated: Even though it exists,

analyzed: tasmin suṣupti avasthāyām artha antarasya kasyacid api adarśanāt atas na jñānam ātmā
translated: in the state of deep sleep, no other object is seen at all; therefore the Self is not knowledge.

analyzed: nanu prakāśa janana svabhāvaḥ sahakāri vaikalyāt na janayet
translated: But even an object which has the nature of producing light may not produce it, due to the absence of cooperating factors.

analyzed: satyam na janayati
translated: It is true that it does not produce it.

original: yasmiṃstu sahakārisaṃnidhāne tatkṛte vānyasminnāgantuke sati niyamena prakāśata evārthāntaraṃ tajjñānaśabdavācyam /
analyzed: yasmin tu sahakāri saṃnidhāne tad kṛte vā anyasmin āgantuke sati niyamena prakāśate eva artha antaram tat jñāna śabda vācyam
translated: But that in the presence of which, or in the presence of some other adventitious thing brought about by the presence of cooperating factors, another object is indeed always illuminated, that is denoted by the word knowledge.

analyzed: tathā gīti śravaṇa priya āliṅgana candra darśana madhura āsvāda surabhi ghrāṇa ādi janyam āhlādam ānanda sukha śabdau abhidadhāte
translated: Similarly, the words 'bliss', 'joy', and 'happiness' denote the delight produced by hearing music, embracing a beloved, seeing the moon, tasting sweet things, smelling fragrances, and so on.

analyzed: na ca evaṃrūpa tvam ātmānaḥ sti
translated: But the self does not have such a nature.

original: yathā hyanyasukheṣu sukharūpaṃ pratyabhijñāyate naivamātmani pratyabhijānīmo yenānandamiti ca saṃjñetyucyate na sā laukikī nāpi vaidikī /
analyzed: yathā hi anya sukheṣu sukha rūpam pratyabhijñāyate na evam ātmani pratyabhijānīmaḥ yena ānandam iti ca saṃjñā iti ucyate na sā laukikī na api vaidikī
translated: Just as the nature of happiness is recognized in other pleasures, so we do not recognize it in the self, by which it is said to be called 'bliss'. It is neither worldly nor Vedic.

analyzed: yadi param vṛddhi ādi vat paribhāṣyeta tat astu yathākāmam
translated: If it is to be defined like 'other' (para), 'increase' (vṛddhi), etc., let it be as one wishes.

original: yattu vijñānaṃ brahma ānandaṃ brahma iti ca sāmānādhikaraṇyaṃ taddharmamātravacanatvena vartante /
analyzed: yat tu vijñānam brahma ānandam brahma iti ca sāmānādhikaraṇyam tad dharma mātra vacana tvena vartante
translated: But the identity of cognition with Brahman and bliss with Brahman is used in the sense of stating only the attributes of Brahman.

analyzed: satyam
translated: This is true.

analyzed: na bāhulyena vartante
translated: But it is not used in the sense of plurality.

original: kadācittu guṇamātravacanānāmapi guṇini prayogo bhavati yathā śīto madhuro rasaḥ snigdho guruśceti rasaśabdo dravye prayujyate /
analyzed: kadācid tu guṇa mātra vacanānām api guṇini prayogaḥ bhavati yathā śītaḥ madhuraḥ rasaḥ snigdhaḥ guruḥ ca iti rasa śabdaḥ dravye prayujyate
translated: Sometimes, however, even words denoting only qualities are used for the possessor of qualities, just as the word 'taste' is used for a substance in 'the taste is cold, sweet, unctuous, and heavy'.

analyzed: anyathā śīta ādi śabda sāmānādhikaraṇya ayogāt
translated: Otherwise, the co-reference of 'cold' and so on would be impossible.

analyzed: kim ca rasam hi eva ayam vidvān
translated: Moreover, this wise one indeed knows the taste.

analyzed: saḥ ekaḥ brahmaṇaḥ ānanda
translated: That is the one bliss of Brahman.

analyzed: iti ṣaṣṭhī ānandāt brahma vyatiricyate
translated: Thus, by the genitive case, Brahman is distinguished from bliss.

original: kiṃ ca na me sāṃprataṃ kiñcidapi sukhaṃ duḥkhameva tu sarvātmanā mameti sukhābhāve duḥkhānubhave cānusaṃdhīyamānasyātmanaḥ kathamānandarūpatā 🔽syāt /
analyzed: kim ca na me sāṃpratam kiñcid api sukham duḥkham eva tu sarva ātmanā mama iti sukha abhāve duḥkha anubhave ca anusaṃdhīyamānasya ātmanaḥ katham ānanda rūpa tā  / syāt
translated: Moreover, if I have no pleasure at all now, but only pain in every way, and if the self is experienced in the absence of pleasure and the experience of pain, how can it have the nature of bliss?

analyzed: kim ca sva prakāśa ānanda rūpam ātmānam abhyupagacchatām asmākam ca etāvat avivādam suṣupti tulyā muktiḥ iti
translated: And what is more, for us who accept the self to be of the nature of self-luminous bliss, there is no dispute that liberation is like deep sleep.

analyzed: saṃsāra anuvṛtti anuvṛtti mātram bhidyate anyat sarvam tulyam
translated: Only the continuation or non-continuation of worldly existence is different. Everything else is the same.

original: tathā ca śrutirapi tā etāḥ prajā aharaharbrahmalokaṃ yanti /
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ api tāḥ etāḥ prajāḥ ahar ahar brahma lokam yanti
translated: And thus the scripture also says: These beings go to the world of Brahman day after day.

original: aharaharāgacchanti iti suṣuptiṃ brahmalokaśabdena vadantī tulyatvametayordarśayati /
analyzed: ahar ahar āgacchanti iti suṣuptim brahma loka śabdena vadantī tulya tvam etayoḥ darśayati
translated: They come back day after day. By calling deep sleep the world of Brahman with the word world of Brahman, it shows the similarity of these two.

original: suṣuptiścāsmākamapi gocaro na ca tatrānandānubhavo 'stīti vyaktametat /
analyzed: suṣuptiḥ ca asmākam api gocaraḥ na ca tatra ānanda anubhavaḥ sti iti vyaktam etat
