translated: And it is clear to us that deep sleep is within our experience, and there is no experience of bliss there.

analyzed: tasmāt nirānandaḥ mokṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, liberation is without bliss.

analyzed: duḥkha parilopāt ca puruṣa arthantvam
translated: And because of the cessation of pain, it is the human goal.

original: sukhalopādapuruṣārthatvamapīticet naivamalpaṃ hi saṃsāre sukhaṃ tadapi sūrayaḥ //
analyzed: sukha lopāt apuruṣa artha tvam api iti ced nā evam alpam hi saṃsāre sukham tat api sūrayaḥ
translated: If it be said that the absence of pain is not the human goal, we reply that it is not so, for in this world of transmigration there is but little happiness, and that also the wise men acknowledge to be pain,

analyzed: bahu prayāsa sādhya tvāt duḥkham eva anujānate
translated: because it is to be attained by much effort.

analyzed: janma mṛtyu jarā vyādhi duḥkhāni anudinam
translated: Birth, death, old age, disease, and pain, every day fall upon men

analyzed: svayam eva vinā ayatnāt nipatanti sahasradhā
translated: of themselves, without effort, in a thousand ways.

analyzed: vihita akaraṇāt nityam pratiṣiddha niṣevaṇāt  mahat āmuṣmikam duḥkham yatnaiḥ na ava gamyate
translated: From the omission of what is enjoined and the performance of what is forbidden,🔽great misery in the next world is to be inferred by every means.

analyzed: bahu duḥkha pariṣviktam yat nāma khalpakam sukham
translated: That little happiness which is surrounded by much misery,

analyzed: surā pāna ādi sukha vat varjanīyam vivikinām
translated: is to be avoided by the wise, as the happiness of drinking wine, and so on.

analyzed: evaṃbhūte saṃsāre ye raktāḥ sukha tṛṣṇayā
translated: Those who are attached in this world of transmigration to happiness by the thirst for pleasure,

analyzed: na teṣām adhikāraḥ sti mukti śāstre kathañcana
translated: have no right in any way to the scriptures on liberation.

analyzed: ye dṛṣṭa loka parāvarāḥ
translated: Only they who are freed from the world, who have seen the highest and the next world,

original: ta eva khalu mucyante na tu yaḥ prākṛto janaḥ //🔽teṣāmevāpargākhyaḥ puruṣārtho mahātmanām //
analyzed: te eva khalu mucyante na tu yaḥ prākṛtaḥ janaḥ  teṣām eva aparga ākhyaḥ puruṣa arthaḥ mahātmanām
translated: are indeed liberated, not the common people.🔽To them alone, the great souls, is the human goal called final emancipation.

analyzed: teṣām eva adhikāraḥ ca muktiṣāśtre manīṣiṇām
translated: To them alone, the wise, is the right to the scriptures on liberation.

analyzed: tena abhāva ātmaka tve pi mukteḥ nā a puruṣa artha tā
translated: Therefore, even though liberation is of the nature of non-existence, it is not devoid of human purpose.

analyzed: sukha duḥkha upabhogaḥ hi saṃsāraḥ iti śabdyate
translated: For the enjoyment of pleasure and pain is said to be transmigration.

analyzed: tayoḥ anupabhogam tu mokṣam mokṣa vidaḥ viduḥ
translated: But the knowers of liberation know liberation to be the non-experience of those two.

original: śrutirapyetamevāha bhedaṃ saṃsāramokṣayoḥ //🔽na ha vai saśarīrasya priyāpriyavihīnatā //
analyzed: śrutiḥ api etam eva āha bhedam saṃsāra mokṣayoḥ  na ha vai sa śarīrasya priya apriya vihīna tā
translated: The Veda also speaks of this very distinction between transmigration and liberation.🔽For one who has a body, there is no absence of what is pleasant and unpleasant.

original: aśarīraṃ vā vasantaṃ smapṛśato na priyāpriye //
analyzed: aśarīram vā vasantam sma pṛśataḥ na priya apriye
translated: Or one who is bodiless and abides in bliss, for him there are no pleasant and unpleasant things.

analyzed: ānanda ātmakam ātmānam ye vadanti sva prabham
translated: Those who say that the Self is of the nature of bliss and is self-luminous,

analyzed: tad mate ca saṃsārāt mukteḥ etāvatī bhidā
translated: even according to their view, there is this much distinction between liberation and transmigration.

analyzed: ātmā hi ānanda rūpaḥ sau saṃsāre pi prakāśate
translated: For the Self, which is of the nature of bliss, shines even in transmigration.

original: tāveva / sa mokṣe 'pi nādhikyaṃ tasya kiñcana //🔽atha saṃsāravelāyāmānando na prakāśate //
analyzed: tau eva sa mokṣe na ādhikyam tasya kiñcana  atha saṃsāra velāyām ānandaḥ na prakāśate
translated: And even in liberation, there is no addition to it at all.🔽But if bliss does not shine at the time of transmigration,

analyzed: na hi aprakāśanam yuktam sva prakāśasya vastunaḥ
translated: then it is not proper for a self-luminous entity to be unmanifest.

analyzed: yadi asau na prakāśeta kin tarhi anyat prakāśate
translated: If it does not shine, then what else shines?

analyzed: ātma svarūpam iti ced nanu ca ānandaḥ eva tat
translated: If it is said to be the form of the Self, then indeed bliss is that.

analyzed: tat ced prakāśate nūnam ānandaḥ pi prakāśate
translated: If that shines, then bliss also certainly shines.

analyzed: tena śabda ādi viṣaya janyayoḥ sukha duḥkhayoḥ
translated: Therefore, the pleasure and pain arising from objects like sound etc.,

original: nivṛttireva saṃsārādapavarga itīryate /🔽tataśca sukhalopena mukterna puruṣārthatā //
analyzed: nivṛttiḥ eva saṃsārāt apavargaḥ iti īryate  tatas ca sukha lopena mukteḥ na puruṣa artha tā
translated: Cessation itself from worldly existence is called liberation.

analyzed: yadi asmākam puruṣa artha tā
translated: And therefore, liberation being the cessation of pleasure, it is not the human goal.🔽If it were our human goal,

analyzed: yadi asmākam bhavet tarhi tulyā eṣā bhavatām api
translated: then this would be the same for you also.

analyzed: sukha duḥkha hānim asataḥ tasya bhūyas duḥkha vivarjanāt
translated: Because of the removal of both pleasure and pain, and the avoidance of further suffering,

analyzed: mokṣasya puruṣa artha tvam āvayoḥ ubhayoḥ samam  sukha duḥkha vihīnaḥ muktaḥ svasthaḥ avatiṣṭhate  iti
translated: the human goal of liberation is the same for both of us.

analyzed: mukti svarūpa kathanam  kim idam svasthaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the liberated one, free from pleasure and pain, remains in his own natural state, which is knowledge, power, existence, substantiality, etc.,

original: ye hyāgamamāpāyino dharmā buddhisukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnadharmāgharmāsaṃskārastānapahāya yadasya svaṃ naijaṃ jñānaśaktisattādravyatvādi
analyzed: ye hi āgamam āpāyinaḥ dharmāḥ buddhi sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatna dharma a gharma a saṃskāraḥ tān apahāya yat asya svam naijam jñāna śakti sattā dravya tva ādi
translated: having abandoned those qualities that are adventitious to him, such as intelligence, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, effort, virtue, and vice, and the impressions.

analyzed: tasmin avatiṣṭhate iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

original: yadi tu saṃsārāvasthāyāmavidyamāno 'pyānando muktāvasthāyāṃ janyata ityucyate tato janimattvādanityo mokṣaḥ syāt /
analyzed: yadi tu saṃsāra avasthāyām avidyamānaḥ pi ānandaḥ mukta avasthāyām janyate iti ucyate tatas janimat tvāt anityaḥ mokṣaḥ syāt
translated: If, however, it is said that bliss, which does not exist in the state of worldly existence, is produced in the state of liberation, then liberation would be impermanent due to having production.

analyzed: kena ca asau anubhāvyaḥ
translated: And by whom is it to be experienced?

analyzed: na hi sva prakāśa tvam kasyacid saṃbhavi iti uktam
translated: For it has been said that self-luminousness is not possible for anything.

original: na ca manasānubhavaḥ saṃbhavatīti muktasya manaso 'bhāvāt amanalaskatvaśruterityuktam /
analyzed: na ca manasā anubhavaḥ saṃbhavati iti muktasya manasaḥ bhāvāt a manalaska tva śruteḥ iti uktam
translated: And it has been said that the experience by the mind is not possible, because of the absence of the liberated mind, and because of the Vedic text declaring the state of being without mind.

original: ata eva nityo 'pyānandaḥ saṃsāradaśāyāmabibhūtatvādanubhūtopi muktāvabhibhave nivṛtte manasānubhūyate ityedapi nirastam ////
analyzed: atas eva nityaḥ pi ānandaḥ saṃsāra daśāyām a bibhūta tvāt anubhūtaḥ api muktau abhibhave nivṛtte manasā anubhūyate nirastam
translated: For this very reason, it is also refuted that bliss, though eternal, is not experienced in the state of worldly existence, though experienced, because of the absence of submergence, it is experienced by the mind when submergence ceases.

original: kiṃ ca sukhaviśiṣcātmānubhavaḥ puruṣārtho na sukhamātrānubhavaḥ /
analyzed: kim ca sukha viśiṣca ātma anubhavaḥ puruṣa arthaḥ na sukha mātra anubhavaḥ
translated: Moreover, the experience of the self qualified by bliss is the human goal, not the mere experience of bliss.

original: na ca muktāvātmānubhavaḥ saṃbhavati vijñātāramare kena vijānīyāt iti kaṇṭhenaiva
analyzed: na ca muktau ātma anubhavaḥ saṃbhavati vijñātāram are kena vijānīyāt iti kaṇṭhena eva
translated: And the experience of the self is not possible in liberation, because it is directly denied by the Vedic text By what could one know the knower?

original: śrutyā niṣiddhatvāt alaṃ vā are idaṃ vijñānāya iti ca śrutyā vijñānaśabdasya muktasya
analyzed: śrutyāḥ niṣiddha tvāt alam vai are idam vijñānāya iti ca śrutyāḥ vijñāna śabdasya muktasya
translated: And because the word knowledge in the Vedic text Enough, O dear one, for this to be known

analyzed: vijñānam aśakyam abhyupagantum
translated: cannot be accepted as referring to the liberated one's knowledge.

original: nahyasyāḥ śruteḥ priyāpriyāsparśaśruteśca tattvakathanaṃ muktvā kathañcidanyaparatvaṃ saṃbhavati /
analyzed: na hi asyāḥ śruteḥ priya apriya asparśa śruteḥ ca tattva kathanam muktvā kathañcid anya para tvam saṃbhavati
translated: For this Vedic text and the Vedic text about the non-contact with the agreeable and disagreeable cannot be interpreted in any other way than as stating the truth.

analyzed: vijñāna āśrutayaḥ tu śaktau eva vijñāna upacāram kurvanti prarocana artha tayā iti upapannam
translated: But the passages speaking of consciousness, in order to encourage, apply the term consciousness to the power of action. This is reasonable.

analyzed: evam ānanda śrutayaḥ pi puruṣa artha tva sāmānyāt sukha tva upacāreṇa prarocana artha tayā pravṛttāḥ
translated: In the same way, the passages speaking of bliss, by the commonality of being the human goal, apply the term bliss to happiness, in order to encourage.

analyzed: yuktam ca etat vacanayoḥ virodhe nyatas nirṇayaḥ iti
translated: And this is proper, for when there is a contradiction between two statements, the matter should be decided from another source.

analyzed: virodhaḥ ca atra ānanda priya abhāva vacanayoḥ
translated: And here there is a contradiction between the statement of the absence of bliss and the statement of the absence of the beloved.

analyzed: na ca abhāva vacanam vaiṣayika abhiprāyam
translated: And it cannot be said that the statement of absence is meant to refer to sensual pleasures,

analyzed: itarat tu svābhāvika abhiprāyam iti śakyam vaktum
translated: while the other is meant to refer to the natural state.

analyzed: ubhayatra api sāmānya upādānāt atyanta samāna viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because in both cases a general term is used, and the subject matter is exactly the same.

analyzed: atas pramāṇa antara vaśāt ānanda vacanam duḥkha abhāva param
translated: Therefore, by the power of another means of knowledge, the statement about bliss refers to the absence of suffering.

analyzed: itarat tu yathāśrutam iti nyāyyam
translated: But the other statement should be taken literally. This is proper.

analyzed: tasmāt sukha duḥkha ādi samasta vaiśeṣika ātma guṇa ucchedaḥ mokṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, liberation is the cessation of all the qualities of the self such as pleasure and pain, which belong to the Vaiśeṣika school.

analyzed: sukha duḥkha ucchedaḥ ca dharma adharmayoḥ ucchedāt
translated: And the cessation of pleasure and pain is due to the cessation of dharma and adharma.

analyzed: dharma adharmayoḥ ucchedaḥ ca utpannānām dharma adharmāṇām upabhogena nitya naimittika karma anuṣṭhānena ātma jñānena ca virodhāt
translated: And it is opposed to the destruction of Dharma and Adharma, because it is opposed to the enjoyment of the Dharma and Adharma that have arisen, to the performance of obligatory and occasional rites, and to the knowledge of the self.

analyzed: utpādyānām ca kāmya anuṣṭhāna nimittānām dharmāṇām tad anuṣṭhānena anutpādāt
translated: And because the Dharma that is to be produced, which is the cause of the performance of the desirable, is not produced by the performance of that.

original: vihitākaraṇapratiṣiddhānuṣṭhānanimittānāṃ cādharmāṇāṃ vihitānuṣṭhānena pratiṣiddhākaraṇena ca parihārāt /
analyzed: vihita akaraṇa pratiṣiddha anuṣṭhāna nimittānām ca adharmāṇām vihita anuṣṭhānena pratiṣiddha akaraṇena ca parihārāt
translated: And because the Adharma that is to be produced, which is the cause of the performance of what is prohibited and the non-performance of what is enjoined, is avoided by the performance of what is enjoined and the non-performance of what is prohibited.

original: asati śarīrārambhe pūrvaśarīranipāte cāśarīro 'vasthito mukto bhavati //
analyzed: asati śarīra ārambhe pūrva śarīra nipāte ca aśarīraḥ vasthitaḥ muktaḥ bhavati
translated: And when there is no beginning of a body and the falling away of the previous body, he becomes liberated while abiding without a body.

analyzed: ātma jñānasya kratu mokṣa ubhaya upayogi tvam
translated: The usefulness of the knowledge of the self for both sacrifice and liberation.

analyzed: nanu ātma jñānam kratu artham
translated: But is the knowledge of the self for the sake of the sacrifice?

analyzed: satyam
translated: True,

analyzed: puruṣa artham api ca tat saṃyoga bhedāt
translated: but it is also for the sake of the person, due to the difference in the connection.

analyzed: yat tāvat avināśī vai are yama ātmā ityādinā śarīrāt vyatirikta nitya ātma svarūpa sadbhāva jñānam
translated: As for the knowledge of the existence of the eternal self's nature as separate from the body, which begins with This self, O dear one, is indeed imperishable,

analyzed: tat pāralaukika phala karma anuṣṭhāna aupayika tvāt karma jñāna vat eva sāmarthyataḥ kratu saṃyogāt kratu artham
translated: that, being conducive to the performance of actions that have results in the next world, is for the sake of the sacrifice by implication from its connection with the sacrifice, just like the knowledge of action.

analyzed: yathā hi jyotiṣṭoma udi vākya adhyayanam dṛṣṭena eva anuṣṭhāna aupayika tvam jñānam janayati iti
translated: For just as the study of the sentences of the Jyotiṣṭoma produces the knowledge that is useful for the performance by means of what is seen,

original: tadarthatayādhyayanavidhinā vidhīyate tathā avināśī vā areyamātmā ityādivākyānāmapyadhyayanavidhireva
analyzed: tad artha tayā adhyayana vidhinā vidhīyate tathā avināśī vai are yam ātmā ityādi vākyānām api adhyayana vidhiḥ eva
translated: so the injunction to study by the injunction to study enjoins the sentences beginning with This Self is indestructible, O Gautama

analyzed: karma anuṣṭhāna upayogi ātma jñāna artha tām vidhatte
translated: the injunction to study enjoins the purpose of the knowledge of the Self that is useful for the performance of the ritual.

original: tadyadi pramāṇāntareṇātmanaḥ śarīrādiviveko naikāntataḥ siddhyati tato dṛḍhavivekapratipādakānāmupaniṣadvākyānāṃ vispaṣṭameva phalam /
analyzed: tat yadi pramāṇa antareṇa ātmanaḥ śarīra ādi vivekaḥ na ekāntataḥ siddhi ati tatas dṛḍha viveka pratipādakānām upaniṣad vākyānām vispaṣṭam eva phalam
translated: If the distinction of the Self from the body etc. is not established conclusively by other means of knowledge, then the sentences of the Upaniṣads, which teach a firm distinction, have a clearly evident result.

analyzed: yathā uktam iti āha nāstikya nirākariṣṇuḥ ātma astitām bhāṣyakṛt atra yuktyā
translated: As it is said: The author of the Bhāṣya, who is averse to atheism, speaks here of the existence of the Self by reasoning.

analyzed: dṛḍha tvam etad viṣayaḥ prabodhaḥ prayāti vedānta niṣevaṇena iti
translated: This firm conviction regarding its object is attained by the study of the Vedānta.

analyzed: atha tu anyatas siddhi ati  tatas yathā eva anyathā api kratu jñāna saṃbhave dhyayana upātta veda vākya avagata karma rūpāṇām eva
translated: If, on the other hand, it is established by other means as well,🔽then just as, even when the knowledge of the ritual is possible in another way, only those who have understood the form of the ritual from the Vedic sentences included in the study are entitled🔽to the rituals, in the same way, only those who have understood the truth of the Self from the Upaniṣad sentences included in the study are entitled

analyzed: puṃsām karmasu adhikāraḥ tathā eva adhyāyana upātta upaniṣad vākya avagata ātma tattvānām eva adhikāra
translated: to the knowledge of the Self.

analyzed: iti adhyayana vidhi balāt eva kalpyate
translated: Thus, it is only by the force of the injunction of study that it is imagined.

original: yattvātmasadbhāvapratipādanopakrame vidhisarūpaṃ vākyam ātmā vā are draṣṭavyaḥ ityādi🔽tadvakṣyamāṇasyārthasyātigahanatvānmahopayogatvācca kathaṃ hi nāmālasyaṃ hitvā śraddhāviśeṣeṇa
analyzed: yat tu ātma sadbhāva pratipādana upakrame vidhi sarūpam vākyam ātmā vai are draṣṭavyaḥ ityādi  tat vakṣyamāṇasya arthasya ati gahana tvāt mahā upayoga tvāt ca katham hi nāma ālasyam hitvā śraddhā viśeṣeṇa
translated: As for the sentence which resembles an injunction at the beginning of the teaching of the existence of the self, The self is to be seen, to be heard, to be thought,

analyzed: vakṣyamāṇam artham pratipadyeta iti ā tāvat mātra artham
translated: that is only for the purpose of encouraging the listener to understand the meaning that is going to be stated, by setting aside laziness and with special faith, because the meaning to be stated is very profound and of great benefit.

analyzed: tasmāt etat jñānam dṛṣṭa upayogi tvāt kratu artham
translated: Therefore, this knowledge is for the purpose of the sacrifice because it is seen to be useful.

analyzed: yāni punar itikartavya tā viśeṣa yuktāni upāsana ātmakāni vidhīyante teṣām kratau dṛṣṭa upayoga abhāvāt adṛṣṭa phala tvam
translated: As for those meditations which are enjoined along with the details of performance, they have unseen results because they are not seen to be useful in the sacrifice.

original: adṛṣṭaṃ ca phalaṃ vākyaśeṣāddvividhaṃ abhyudayarūpaṃ niḥśreyasarūpaṃ ca /
analyzed: adṛṣṭam ca phalam vākyaśeṣāt dvividham abhyudaya rūpam niḥśreyasa rūpam ca
translated: And the unseen result is of two kinds - of the nature of prosperity and of the nature of highest good - as understood from the supplementary passages.

analyzed: sarvan kāmān āpnoti saḥ u śnute sarvān kāmān ityādi abhyudaya phalam
translated: He obtains all desires, he enjoys all desires, etc. are the results of prosperity.

original: na sa punarāvartate ityādi niḥśreyasaphalamiti vivekaḥ //
analyzed: na sa punar āvartate ityādi niḥśreyasa phalam iti vivekaḥ
translated: He does not return again, etc. are the results of highest good. This is the distinction.

analyzed: ātma nitya tvena adhikaraṇa upasaṃhāraḥ
translated: The conclusion of the section on the eternality of the self.

original: yattu vijñānaghana evaitebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya tānyevānuvinaśyati na pretya🔽saṃjñāsti ityanena brāhmaṇena bhūtacaitanyamuktamityāśaṅkyate tatsvayameva brāhmaṇenātreva
analyzed: yat tu vijñāna ghane eva etebhyaḥ bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya tāni eva anuvinaśyati na pretya  saṃjñā asti iti anena brāhmaṇena bhūta caitanyam uktam iti āśaṅkyate tat svayam eva brāhmaṇena atra eva
translated: But it is suspected that the doctrine of the sentience of elements is stated by the Brāhmaṇa passage, This [soul] rises from these elements as a mass of pure consciousness, and after dissolving them perishes not,

analyzed: mā bhagavat moha antam prāpitavān pūrvam ajara amṛtvam abhidhāya adhunā vināśi iti abhidhānāt iti
translated: but after death there is no consciousness, so that [the soul] is not eternal.

analyzed: pūrvapakṣam codya ākhyam uktvā siddhānta parihāraḥ uktaḥ
translated: This prima facie view is stated as the objection, and the final conclusion is stated as the answer.

original: avināśī vā are 'yamātmānucchittidharmā ityuktvā kathaṃ tarhi vināśavacanamityāśaṅkya mātrāsaṃsargatvasya bhavatītyuktam /
analyzed: avināśī vai are yam ātmā an ucchitti dharmā iti uktvā katham tarhi vināśa vacanam iti āśaṅkya mātrā saṃsarga tvasya bhavati iti uktam
translated: This soul, O dear one, is imperishable, having the nature of not being cut off. Having said this, how then is the statement of perishing? Anticipating this doubt, it is said by contact with the parts.

original: mātrāśabdena bhūtendriyāṇi dharmādharmau ca vikāraśabdavācyā ucyante ////
analyzed: mātrā śabdena bhūta indriyāṇi dharma adharmau ca vikāra śabda vācyāḥ ucyante
translated: By the word parts, the elements, senses, dharma and adharma, which are denoted by the word modification, are meant.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati vijñāna ghana śabdena jñāna śakti svabhāvasya ātmanaḥ bhidhānam
translated: This is what is said: By the word mass of pure consciousness, the nature of the soul, which is the power of knowledge, is denoted.

original: sa hyetebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya mukto bhūtvā tānyevānuvinaśyati bhūtavināśātso 'pi vinaṣṭa iva bhavatīti /
analyzed: sa hi etebhyaḥ bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya muktaḥ bhūtvā tāni eva anuvinaśyati bhūta vināśāt saḥ u pi vinaṣṭaḥ iva bhavati iti
translated: That [soul], having risen from these elements, becomes liberated, and after dissolving them perishes, and by the destruction of the elements, it becomes as if destroyed.

original: bhūtastho hyasau svayaṃ pratyakṣeṇa vinaśyatītyucyate /🔽tadanena prakāreṇa mātrāṇāmeva vināśa ityucyate nātmana ityavirodhaḥṣa /🔽taduktam avināśī svarūpeṇa puruṣo yā tu nāśitā //
analyzed: bhūta sthaḥ hi asau svayam pratyakṣeṇa vinaśyati iti ucyate  tat anena prakāreṇa mātrāṇām eva vināśaḥ iti ucyate na ātmanaḥ iti avirodhaḥ  tat uktam avināśī sva rūpeṇa puruṣaḥ yā tu nāśitā
translated: He who is in the elements is said to be destroyed by direct perception himself.🔽In this way, it is said that only the constituents are destroyed, not the self. Thus there is no contradiction.

analyzed: mātrāṇām sa adhikārāṇām bhūta ādīnām asaṃjñitāḥ iti
translated: This is said: The self is indestructible by nature, but the destructibility of the constituents, the elements and so on, which have jurisdiction, is not recognized.

analyzed: kim idam bhūta ādīnām asaṃjñitā iti
translated: What is this not recognized of the elements and so on?

original: yadi tāvat na pretya saṃjñāstītyasya vyākhyānaṃ /
analyzed: yadi tāvat na pretya saṃjñā asti iti asya vyākhyānam
translated: If this is an explanation of after death there is no recognition,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: that is not correct.

original: na hi na pretya saṃjñāstītyanena bhūtādīnāmasaṃjñitvamucyate /
analyzed: na hi na pretya saṃjñā asti iti anena bhūta ādīnām asaṃjñi tvam ucyate
translated: For by after death there is no recognition, the non-recognition of the elements and so on is not stated.

analyzed: kin tarhi ātmanaḥ eva muktasya saṃjñā bhāvaḥ nena ucyate
translated: Rather, by this [verse], the absence of recognition of the self alone when liberated is stated.

original: tasyaivopāyābhāvena tatkena kaṃ paśyedityādinā vijñānāramare kena vijānīyādityantena vijñānābhāvopapādanāt /
analyzed: tasya eva upāya abhāvena tat kena kam paśyet ityādinā kena vijānīyāt iti antena vijñāna abhāva upapādanāt
translated: For by that [verse], the absence of consciousness is established, from By what would he see whom? and so on, up to By what would he cognize?

analyzed: satyam
translated: This is true.

analyzed: na idam asya vyākhyānam
translated: This is not an explanation of that [verse].

original: prakaraṇārthopasaṃhārastvayaṃ yata evaṃ pūrvoktena nyāyena bhūtacaitanyaṃ na saṃbhavati brāhmaṇenāpi tathaivoktam /
analyzed: prakaraṇa artha upasaṃhāraḥ tu ayam yatas evam pūrva uktena nyāyena bhūta caitanyam na saṃbhavati brāhmaṇena api tathā eva uktam
translated: But this is a summary of the topic of the section: since the consciousness of the elements is not possible in the way stated by the reasoning stated earlier, it is said by the Brahmana in the same way.

analyzed: tasmāt bhūta indriyāṇām asaṃjñi tvam acaitanyam
translated: Therefore, the elements and senses are insentient.

original: anyastu nityaścetanaḥ tasya svargagamanasaṃbhavavānna svargaṃ lokaṃ yātītyasya pratyakṣavirodhaḥ //
analyzed: anyaḥ tu nityaḥ cetanaḥ tasya svarga gamana saṃbhavavān na svargam lokam yāti iti asya pratyakṣa virodhaḥ
translated: But another is eternal and sentient. It is not possible for him to go to heaven, so there is a contradiction with perception.

analyzed: śabda anitya tā adhikaraṇam
translated: The section on the impermanence of sound.

analyzed: karma eke tatra darśanāt
translated: Some say it is karma, because it is seen there.

analyzed: asthānāt
translated: Because it is impossible.

analyzed: karoti śabdāt
translated: Because of the word.

analyzed: sattva antare ca yaugapadyāt  prakṛti vikṛtyoḥ ca
translated: And because of simultaneity in another being.🔽And because of the original and modified forms.

analyzed: vṛddhiḥ ca kartṛ bhūmnā asya
translated: And because of the increase of the agent.

analyzed: samam tu tatra darśanam
translated: But the view there is the same.

analyzed: sataḥ parama darśanam viṣaya anāgamāt
translated: The highest perception of the existent is because of the non-arrival of objects.

analyzed: prayogasya param
translated: The highest of the application.

analyzed: āditya vat yaugapadyam  varṇa antaram avikāraḥ
translated: Simultaneity like the sun.🔽The other letter is without modification.

analyzed: nāda vṛddhi parā
translated: The highest of the increase of sound.

analyzed: nityaḥ tu syāt darśanasya parārtha tvāt
translated: But it should be eternal, because the perception is for the sake of another.

analyzed: sarvatra yaugapadyāt  saṃkhyā bhāvāt
translated: Because of simultaneity everywhere.

analyzed: an apekṣa tvāt
translated: Because of the absence of number.🔽Because of independence.

analyzed: prakhyā bhāvāt ca yogasya  liṅga darśanāt ca
translated: And because of the absence of manifestation of yoga.🔽And because of the perception of the mark.

analyzed: liṅga darśanāt ca
translated: And because of the perception of the mark.

original: śabdasyārthapratyāyayakatvaṃ svābhāvikamiti yadaktaṃ tadākṣipyate śabdasyānityatvāt /🔽na hyabhinavasya śabdasya
analyzed: śabdasya artha pratyāyayaka tvam svābhāvikam iti yat aktam tat ākṣipyate śabdasya anitya tvāt  na hi abhinavasya śabdasya
translated: The naturalness of the word in conveying the meaning is now refuted. The word is non-eternal.

analyzed: vṛddha vyavahāra paramparayā svābhāvikam pratyāyaka tvam śakyate gṛhītum
translated: The naturalness of the word in conveying the meaning cannot be grasped in the case of a new word.

analyzed: agṛhītam api ced svabhāvataḥ cakṣuḥ ādi vat pratyāyayet prathama śravaṇe pi pratyāyayet
translated: Even if it is not grasped, it would convey the meaning naturally like the eye etc. It would convey the meaning even on the first hearing.

analyzed: tasmāt anitya tve śabdasya devadatta ādi śabda vat puruṣa kṛtam eva pratyāyaka tvam āpadyate
translated: Therefore, in the non-eternality of the word, the conveying of the meaning becomes like the word 'Devadatta' etc., created by man.

analyzed: katham punar itya tvam śabdasya
translated: How then is the word non-eternal?

analyzed: prayatna anabhivyaṅgya tve sati tad anantaram upalabdheḥ ghaṭa ādi vat tad janya tvam adhyavasīyate
translated: When it is not manifested by effort, its being produced by that is ascertained from its being perceived immediately after, like a pot etc.

analyzed: anyathā kim iti tat anantaram eva upalabhyate na pūrvam
translated: Otherwise, why is it perceived immediately after that and not before?

analyzed: upalabdhasya ca drāk eva tirobhāvāt vināśi tvam adhyavasīyate īṣa na ca asiddham anabhivyaṅgya tvam
translated: And from the sudden disappearance of what is perceived, its being destroyed is ascertained. And the non-manifestation is not unestablished.

analyzed: abhivyakti ayogāt
translated: Because of the impossibility of manifestation.

original: sā hi pratibandhakanirāsena vā saṃskāraviśeṣānena vā /
analyzed: sā hi pratibandhaka nirāsena vā vā
translated: For that is either by the removal of the obstruction or by the special impression.

original: na tāvatpratibandhanirāsaḥ pratibandhakānupalabdheḥ /🔽stimitā vāyavaḥ śrotramācchādyāvasthitāḥ śabdopalabdhiṃ pratibadhnanti /
analyzed: na tāvat pratibandha nirāsaḥ pratibandhaka anupalabdheḥ  stimitāḥ vāyavaḥ śrotram ācchādya avasthitāḥ śabda upalabdhim pratibadhnanti
translated: Not the removal of obstruction, because of the non-apprehension of the obstruction.🔽The still air covers the ear and obstructs the apprehension of sound.

original: teṣu prayatnotthāpitaiḥ kauṣṭhyairvāyubhirutsāriteṣūpalabhyate śabda iti cet /
analyzed: teṣu prayatna utthāpitaiḥ kauṣṭhyaiḥ vāyubhiḥ utsāriteṣu upalabhyate śabdaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that when they are driven away by the internal air currents raised by effort, sound is apprehended,

original: evaṃ tarhi sarve śabdāḥ śrotraṃ prāpyāvasthitāḥ pratibandhakeṣūtsariteṣu yugapacchrūyeran ////
analyzed: evam tarhi sarve śabdāḥ śrotram prāpya avasthitāḥ pratibandhakeṣu utsariteṣu yugapad śrūyeran
translated: then all sounds reaching the ear and remaining there would be heard simultaneously when the obstructions are removed.

original: atha saṃskārādhānaṃ tatrāpi traividhyaṃ śabdasya vā saṃskāramādadhyuḥ kauṣṭhyā vāyavaḥ śrotrasya vā ubhayorvā /
analyzed: atha saṃskāra ādhānam tatra api traividhyam śabdasya vā saṃskāram ādadhyuḥ kauṣṭhyāḥ vāyavaḥ śrotrasya vā ubhayoḥ vā
translated: If it is said that the impression is produced there, then also there are three alternatives - the internal air currents may produce the impression in the sound, in the ear, or in both.

original: śabdasya cet tasyaikatvātsarvagatatvādanavayavasaṃskārāyogāt srudhnasthairvāyubhiḥ saṃskṛtaḥ śabdaḥ pāṭaliputrepyupalabhyeta /
analyzed: śabdasya ced tasya eka tvāt sarva gata tvāt an avayava saṃskāra ayogāt srudhna sthaiḥ vāyubhiḥ saṃskṛtaḥ śabdaḥ pāṭaliputre pi upalabhyeta
translated: If in the sound, then due to its unity and omnipresence, it cannot be logically produced in parts. Therefore, the sound modified by the air currents located in Srughna would be apprehended even in Pataliputra.

analyzed: tat idam uktam tatra sarvaiḥ pratīyeta ityādinā
translated: This is what is stated by the phrase it would be apprehended by all there and so on.

analyzed: śrotra saṃskāra pakṣe pi ayam eva doṣaḥ
translated: In the case of the modification of the ear also, this same fault arises.

analyzed: yadi kāṇāda kāpila vaidika matena ākāśam ahaṅkāraḥ diś vā śrotram tasya eka tvāt sarva gata tvāt anavayava tvāt ca
translated: If space, ego, or direction is the ear, according to the views of Kanada, Kapila, and the Vedas, then since it is one, all-pervading, and partless,

original: sarvapaṃsāmekameva śrotraṃ syāttaccaikadeśasthairapi dhvānābhiḥ saṃskatamiti kaḥ
analyzed: sarva paṃsām ekam eva śrotram syāt tat ca eka deśa sthaiḥ api dhvānābhiḥ saṃskatam iti kaḥ
translated: the ear would be one for all. And if it is modified by the sounds present in one place,

analyzed: sarveṣām śabda upalabdhim vārayet
translated: who can prevent the perception of sound for all?

analyzed: tat idam śrotra ādeḥ iyam eva diś iti antena darśitam
translated: This is shown in the section beginning with And in the view that space is the ear and ending with this is the only direction for the ear.

original: asmiṃśca pakṣe śrotrasya sarvaśabdasādharaṇatvādekaśabdopalabdhyarthamapi saṃskṛtaṃ śrotraṃ prasaṅgātsarvānśabdānghaṭārthonmīlitamiva netraṃ
analyzed: asmin ca pakṣe śrotrasya sarva śabda sādharaṇa tvāt eka śabda upalabdhi artham api saṃskṛtam śrotram prasaṅgāt sarvān śabdān ghaṭa artha unmīlitam iva netram
translated: And in this view, since the ear is common to all sounds, the ear modified even for the purpose of perceiving one sound would, by implication, perceive all sounds, just as an eye opened to see a pot

analyzed: samāna deśa sthān paṭa ādīn avabodhayet
translated: would perceive other things like cloth present in the same place.

analyzed: tat idam sakṛt ca saṃskṛtam śrotram ityādinā darśitam
translated: This is shown in the section beginning with And this ear, once modified and so on.

original: ayaṃ ca doṣaḥ pūrvopakṣipte 'pi śabdasaṃskārapakṣe darśayitavyaḥ sarve hi śabdāḥ śrotradeśe 'vasthitāstatraikasminsaṃkriyamāṇe balādanyeṣāmapi
analyzed: ayam ca doṣaḥ pūrva upakṣipte śabda saṃskāra pakṣe darśayitavyaḥ sarve hi śabdāḥ śrotra deśe vasthitāḥ tatra ekasmin saṃkriyamāṇe balāt anyeṣām api
translated: This fault should also be shown in the view proposed earlier that sound is modified, because all sounds are present in the region of the ear. If one is modified there, by force the modification of the others

analyzed: saṃskāraḥ syāt eva
translated: would occur as well.

original: na hi samānadeśānāṃ samānendriyagrāhyāṇāṃ kasyacitsaṃskāraḥ kasyaciccāsaṃskāra iti vyavasthā saṃbhavati ghaṭādāvadarśanāt /
analyzed: na hi samāna deśānām samāna indriya grāhyāṇām kasyacid saṃskāraḥ kasyacid ca asaṃskāraḥ iti vyavasthā saṃbhavati ghaṭa ādau adarśanāt
translated: For it is not possible to establish that some things having the same place and being apprehended by the same sense organ have modification, while some others do not have modification, because it is not seen in the case of a pot, etc.

analyzed: tat idam uktam etat eva prasaṃktavyam ityādinā
translated: This is what is meant by the statement beginning with This very thing is to be discussed, etc.

analyzed: ubhaya saṃskāra pakṣe tu ubhaye doṣāḥ samuccitya darśayitavyāḥ
translated: But in the case of modification of both, the faults of both should be shown combined.

original: tathā sati hi kaiścideva kaścideva śabdaḥ śrūyata ityupapadyate /
analyzed: tathā sati hi kaiścid eva kaścid eva śabdaḥ śrūyate iti upapadyate
translated: For in that case, it is possible that some sound is heard by some only.

analyzed: anyathā śrotra vyavasthā ca ubhayam api na syāt
translated: Otherwise, neither the restriction of the auditory organ nor both would be possible.

original: kica nānādeśasthaiśca vaktṛbhiruccāritaḥ śabdo yugapannānādeśeṣūpalabhyate tadekasya nityasyānupapannamiti bhāṣyam /
analyzed: kica nānā deśa sthaiḥ ca vaktṛbhiḥ uccāritaḥ śabdaḥ yugapad nānā deśeṣu upalabhyate tat ekasya nityasya anupapannam iti śā bhāṣyam
translated: Moreover, the commentary states that it is not possible for a single eternal sound to be perceived simultaneously in different places, when uttered by speakers located in different places.

analyzed: tatra nityasya anupapannam iti pratijñā
translated: There, it is not possible for an eternal [sound] is the proposition.

analyzed: ekasya iti hetuḥ
translated: Of a single [sound] is the reason.

analyzed: nityaḥ hi asevakaḥ syāt ekasya anupapannam nānā deśeṣu upalambhanam iti
translated: For an eternal [sound] would be without a cause. It is not possible for a single [sound] to be perceived in different places.

analyzed: nanu nā avaśya tvam nitya tve sati ekatvam bhavati
translated: But it is not necessarily the case that if something is eternal, it must be one.

original: anekānyeva hi gakārādīni nityāni bhavantvityata āha asati viśeṣe nityasya nānekatvamśābhā iti /
analyzed: anekāni eva hi gakāra ādīni nityāni bhavantu iti atas āha asati viśeṣe nityasya na aneka tvam śābhāḥ iti
translated: There are many G's, etc., which are eternal. To this he says: In the absence of distinction, the eternal cannot be manifold.

analyzed: etat uktam bhavati pratyabhijñā ākhya viśeṣya pratyaya balena hi astana adyatana gakārayoḥ eka tva avagamāt nitya tvam āśrīyate
translated: This is what is meant: The eternality of the G's of yesterday and today is assumed on the basis of the cognition of their identity, called recognition.

original: asticāsāvaviśeṣapratyayo yugapannānāvaktṛbhiruccārite 'pi gakāre nahi tatrāpi pratyayaviśeṣo 'sti /
analyzed: asti ca asau aviśeṣa pratyayaḥ yugapad nānā vaktṛbhiḥ uccārite gakāre nahi tatra api pratyaya viśeṣaḥ sti
translated: And this non-distinct cognition exists even when the G is uttered simultaneously by many speakers. For there too there is no distinct cognition.

original: asati ca viśeṣe nityasya nānekatvaṃ saṃbhavati /
analyzed: asati ca viśeṣe nityasya na aneka tvam saṃbhavati
translated: And in the absence of distinction, the eternal cannot be manifold.

original: anekatve hi pratyabhijñāyā aprāmāṇyamasmākamiva bhavato 'pi syāt tadaprāmāṇyeca
analyzed: aneka tve hi pratyabhijñāyāḥ aprāmāṇyam asmākam iva syāt tad aprāmāṇye ca
translated: For if it were manifold, recognition would be invalid for you as for us. And if that were invalid,

analyzed: nitya tva anupapattiḥ
translated: eternality would be impossible.

analyzed: tasmāt nitya tve sati ekatvam aṅgīkartavyam
translated: Therefore, if it is eternal, oneness must be accepted.

original: ekasya cānupapannaṃ nānādeśopalambhanamiti ////🔽vārtike 'pi yaugapadyopalambhādvā bhedo bhedācca kāryateti dvayamupakṣipya yathāyaugapadyopalambhādbhedo
analyzed: ekasya ca anupapannam nānā deśa upalambhanam iti 🔽vārtike pi yaugapadya upalambhāt vā bhedaḥ bhedāt ca kārya tā iti dvayam upakṣipya yathā yaugapadya upalambhāt bhedaḥ
translated: And for the one, the apprehension in different places is impossible.

original: bhavati tathā darśitam avibhutve hi yugapadityādinā tathā darśitam nityatve tvekabuddhiḥ syāditi /
analyzed: bhavati tathā darśitam avibhu tve hi yugapad ityādinā tathā darśitam nitya tve tu eka buddhiḥ syāt iti
translated: This has been shown thus: 'If it were not all-pervading, there would be no simultaneous cognition, etc.' In the case of eternality, on the other hand, it has been shown thus: 'There would be a single cognition.'

analyzed: na hi nitya tva vādinā pratyabhijñāyāḥ bhrānti tvam iṣyate
translated: For one who asserts eternality does not accept that recognition is illusory.

original: tathā ca vakṣyate api caikarūpye sati deśabhedena kāmaṃ deśā eva bhinnāḥ syurnatu śabdaḥ iti /
analyzed: tathā ca vakṣyate api ca aikarūpye sati deśa bhedena kāmam deśāḥ eva bhinnāḥ syuḥ na tu śabdaḥ iti
translated: And it will be said thus: 'Moreover, if there is a single form, then indeed the places themselves may be different due to difference of place, but not the word.'

original: na hi tadaprāmāṇye nityatvaṃ siddhyati pramāṇāntarābhāvāt /
analyzed: na hi tad aprāmāṇye nitya tvam siddhi ati pramāṇa antara abhāvāt
translated: For if that [recognition] is not valid, eternality cannot be established due to the absence of other means of knowledge.

original: ato nityatve satyekatvaṃ syāttacca nānādeśopalambhena virudhyata iti /
analyzed: atas nitya tve sati ekatvam syāt tat ca nānā deśa upalambhena virudhyate iti
translated: Therefore, if it is eternal, there would be oneness, and that is contradicted by its being perceived in different places.

original: tataśca yaugapadyopalambhādbhedo bhede ca pratyabhijñāyā aprāmāṇyaṃ tadaprāmāṇye ca nityatvābhāvātkāryatvaṃ tadetadānupūrvyaṃ svatantrasiddham
analyzed: tatas ca yaugapadya upalambhāt bhedaḥ bhede ca pratyabhijñāyāḥ aprāmāṇyam tad aprāmāṇye ca nitya tva abhāvāt kārya tvam tat etat ānupūrvyam svatantra siddham
translated: And from that, due to the perception of simultaneity, there is difference. And in difference, recognition is not valid. And from the invalidity of that, there is non-eternality. From that, there is production. This sequence is established independently.

original: dṛḍhe cānityatve jīpavatsādṛśyātpratyabhijñā bhavati tasmādanityaḥ śabda iti prāpte //🔽śabdanityatvopapādam /
analyzed: dṛḍhe ca anitya tve jīpa vat sādṛśyāt pratyabhijñā bhavati tasmāt anityaḥ śabdaḥ iti prāpte  śabda nitya tva upapādam
translated: And when non-eternality is firmly established, recognition occurs due to similarity, like in the case of a cow. Therefore, sound is non-eternal. This being the conclusion,🔽The establishment of the eternality of sound is presented.

analyzed: abhidhīyate prayatna anantaram dṛṣṭaiḥ nā aikāntyāt kārya tā dhvaneḥ
translated: It is said: The sound is not necessarily a product because it is seen after effort.

analyzed: tad abhivyaṅgya pakṣe yujyate tatra darśanam
translated: Even in the case of being manifested, that [view] is appropriate there.

analyzed: yat tu katham abhivyaṅgya tvam iti
translated: But how is there manifestation?

analyzed: śrotra saṃskāreṇa iti brūmaḥ
translated: We say it is by the modification of the ear.

original: yattvākāśasyāhaṅkārasya vā śrotratve tatsaṃskāratve ca sarvatra puṃsāmupalabdhiḥ syādityuktaṃ tatra brūmaḥ yadi tayoḥ śrotratve bhavedayaṃ 🔽doṣaḥ /
analyzed: yat tu ākāśasya ahaṅkārasya vā śrotra tve tad saṃskāra tve ca sarvatra puṃsām upalabdhiḥ syāt iti uktam tatra brūmaḥ yadi tayoḥ śrotra tve bhavet ayam  doṣaḥ
translated: But it was said that if space or egoity were the ear and were modified, then everyone would perceive [sound]. To that we say: if that fault would occur if those [space or egoity] were the ear,

original: tatkarṇaśaṣkulībhavatu śrotraṃ sā ca pratipuruṣaṃ bhinneti nātiprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: tat karṇaśaṣkulībhavatu śrotram sā ca prati puruṣam bhinnā iti na ati prasaṅgaḥ
translated: let it be the ear in the form of the cavity of the ear, and that [cavity] is different for each person, so there is no over-extension.

original: yadyapi cākāśameva śrotraṃ tattu na sākṣātsaṃskriyate kintvadhiṣṭhānadvāreṇa /
analyzed: yadi api ca ākāśam eva śrotram tat tu na sākṣāt saṃskriyate kintu adhiṣṭhāna dvāreṇa
translated: And even if space itself is the ear, it is not directly modified, but rather through the medium of the [ear] organ.

original: tataśca yadyapi śrotraṃ sarveṣāmekaṃ tathāpyadhiṣṭhānaṃ bhinnatvātsaṃskāravyavasthayā śravaṇasya vyavasthā bhaviṣyati ////
analyzed: tatas ca yadi api śrotram sarveṣām ekam tathā api adhiṣṭhānam bhinna tvāt saṃskāra vyavasthayā śravaṇasya vyavasthā bhaviṣyati
translated: And therefore, even though the ear is the same for all, still, because the medium is different, there will be a restriction of hearing by the restriction of modification.

original: nanvekatvesatīndriyasya yadyapyadhiṣṭhānāni bhinnāni tathāpyekenāpyadhiṣṭhānena saṃskṛtenendriyasya saṃskṛtatvātsarvapuṃsāmindriyaṃ saṃskṛtamiti
analyzed: nanu eka tve sati indriyasya yadi api adhiṣṭhānāni bhinnāni tathā api ekena api adhiṣṭhānena saṃskṛtena indriyasya saṃskṛta tvāt sarva puṃsām indriyam saṃskṛtam iti
translated: But if the sense organ is one, even though the media are different, still, since the sense organ is modified by even one modified medium, the sense organ is modified for all people.

analyzed: sarveṣām upalabdhiḥ syāt eva
translated: The cognition of all would be the same.

analyzed: tat uktam nanu ekasmin adhiṣṭhāne labdha saṃskāram indriyam
translated: This is stated: Now, for one who advocates a single sense faculty, the sense faculty, having obtained modification in one substratum,

original: bodhakaṃ sarvahetuṣu syādekendriyavādinaḥ iti /🔽sarvadehavartināṃ puṃsāmityarthaḥ /🔽atrottaram puṃsāṃ dehapradeśeṣu syādekendriyavādinaḥ iti /
analyzed: bodhakam sarva hetuṣu syāt eka indriya vādinaḥ iti  sarva deha vartinām puṃsām iti arthaḥ  atra uttaram puṃsām deha pradeśeṣu syāt eka indriya vādinaḥ iti
translated: would be the revealer of all causes.

analyzed: sarva deha vartinām puṃsām iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: of all embodied souls.🔽Here is the reply: For one who advocates a single sense faculty, the arising of cognition

analyzed: atra uttaram puṃsām deha pradeśeṣu  vijñāna utpattiḥ iṣyate
translated: is accepted in the parts of the bodies of embodied souls.

original: tena pradhānavaideśyādviguṇā sā tu saṃskṛtiḥ iti /
analyzed: tena pradhāna vaideśyāt viguṇā sā tu saṃskṛtiḥ iti
translated: By that, the modification is twofold due to the difference in the principal [sense faculty].

original: ayamarthaḥ svaśarīra eva bhogyāyatane sarvapuṃsāmapi jñānamutpadyate nānyatra /
analyzed: ayam arthaḥ sva śarīre eva bhogya āyatane sarva puṃsām api jñānam utpadyate na anyatra
translated: The meaning is: for all embodied souls, cognition arises in their own bodies, which are the locus of enjoyment, not elsewhere.

analyzed: śabda jñāna aṅgam ca ayam adhiṣṭhāna saṃskāraḥ pradhāna samāna deśa tvam ca aṅgānām guṇaḥ tena
translated: And this modification of the substratum is a factor of the cognition of sound. And the factor of being in the same place as the principal [sense faculty] is a quality.

original: dehantaravartinaḥ puruṣasya yastvadehe niṣpādayitavyaṃ vijñānaṃ tasya taddehagata
analyzed: deha antara vartinaḥ puruṣasya yaḥ tu adehe niṣpādayitavyam vijñānam tasya tad deha gata
translated: Therefore, for a person residing in another body, the cognition that is to be produced in that body is produced

original: eva saṃskāro niṣpādako bhavati na dehāntaragataḥ /
analyzed: eva saṃskāraḥ niṣpādakaḥ bhavati na deha antara gataḥ
translated: by the modification residing in that body itself, not by that residing in another body.

analyzed: sā hi tad pradhāna bhūtena jñānena videśa tvāt viguṇaḥ
translated: For that [soul] is far away from the cognition which is the principal factor, and therefore it is a different substance.

analyzed: nanu saṃskāryasya eka tvāt tad dūra tvāt ca saṃskāra aṅga bhāvasya deśa bhedaḥ kiñcitkaraḥ eva
translated: But since the object to be modified is one, and since the state of being an accessory of the modification is far away, the difference of place is indeed useless.

original: yathā barhirekatvāttatsaṃskārāṇāmatithyākālānāmapyupasadagrīṣomīyāṅgātvaṃ na vihanyate tadvadatrāpi syāt / na /
analyzed: yathā barhiḥ ekatvāt tad saṃskārāṇām atithyā kālānām api upasad agrīṣomīya aṅgā tvam na vihanyate tadvat atra api syāt na
translated: Just as, because of the oneness of the sacrificial grass, the modifications of that, even though at different times, do not obstruct the state of being an accessory of the Upasads and the Agrayana, so it would be here too. Not so.

analyzed: a darśanāt
translated: Because of non-observation.

analyzed: na hi ekasmin adhiṣṭhāne sarveṣām jñānam upalabhyate
translated: For the cognition of all [modifications] is not observed in one substratum.

original: ataḥ sādhāraṇamapīndriyaṃ vijñānasamānadesasaṃskārasacivameva jñānamukatpādayati nānyatheti darśanabalādadhyavasīyate tato nātiprasaṅgaḥ ////🔽nacāvaśyamekamevendriyaṃ yadyapyākāśamekamanavayavaṃ ca tathāpi tasya prādeśikairghaṭādibhirye
analyzed: atas sādhāraṇam api indriyam vijñāna samāna desa saṃskāra sacivam eva jñānam ukatpādayati na anyathā iti darśana balāt adhyavasīyate tatas na atiprasaṅgaḥ  na ca avaśyam ekam eva indriyam yadi api ākāśam ekam anavayavam ca tathā api tasya prādeśikaiḥ ghaṭa ādibhiḥ ye
translated: Therefore, even though the sense organ is common, it produces cognition only when assisted by a modification in the same place as the cognition, not otherwise. This is ascertained by the force of observation. Hence there is no over-extension.

analyzed: saṃyogāḥ te pi prādeśikāḥ tatas ca karṇa śaṣkulī saṃyogānām prati puruṣam bhinna tvāt tad avacchinnasya
translated: And it is not necessarily only one sense organ. Even though space is one and partless, still its conjunctions with the limited pot and other [objects] are also limited. And from that, because the conjunctions with the ear-cavity are different for each person, the sense organ delimited by that

analyzed: ca ākāśasya śrotra tvāt sati api svarūpa ekatve vacchinna rūpāṇām śrotrāṇām bhedāt vyavasthā siddhiḥ
translated: And even though the nature of space is one, the distinction of the ears, which are limited in form, is established because of their difference.

analyzed: evam ahaṅkāra bhāge diś bhāge vā śrotre draṣṭavyam
translated: In the same way, the ears should be seen in the part of ego or in the part of space.

analyzed: yat tu sakṛt ca saṃskṛtam śrotram sarva śabdān prakāśayet iti uktam
translated: But it has been said that the ear, once modified, would manifest all sounds.

analyzed: tatra ucyate dhvanayaḥ hi tālu ādi sthāna viśeṣa saṃparkāt vijātīyāḥ vilakṣaṇa sāmarthyāt niṣpadyante
translated: To that it is said: Sounds are produced from the contact with different places such as the palate, by having a different, distinct potency.

original: tataśca kaścideva dhvaniḥ kasyacicchabdasyānuguṇaṃ saṃskāramādhatte na sarvasādhāraṇamityupalabdhivyavasthā kalpyate śabdasaṃskārapakṣe 'pi
analyzed: tatas ca kaścid eva dhvaniḥ kasyacid śabdasya anuguṇam saṃskāram ādhatte na sarva sādhāraṇam iti upalabdhi vyavasthā kalpyate śabda saṃskāra pakṣe pi
translated: And from that, some sound alone imparts a modification favorable to some sound, not common to all. Thus, even in the case of the modification of sound, the distinction of perception is imagined.

analyzed: kaścid eva dhvaniḥ kañcid śabdam
translated: Even in the case of the modification of sound, it is more reasonable to posit that some sound alone modifies some sound,

original: saṃskaroti na sarvaḥ sarvamiti yuktataraiva vyavasthā /
analyzed: saṃskaroti na sarvaḥ sarvam iti yuktatarā eva vyavasthā
translated: not that all modifies all.

original: dṛṣṭāca samānendriyagrāhyāṇāmapyabhivyañjakavyavasthā sāvitraṃ hi tejo ghaṭādīnāmevābhivyañjakaṃ na nakṣatrāṇāṃ /
analyzed: dṛṣṭā ca samāna indriya grāhyāṇām api abhivyañjaka vyavasthā sāvitram hi tejaḥ ghaṭa ādīnām eva abhivyañjakam na nakṣatrāṇām
translated: And the distinction of manifestors is seen even for those that are grasped by the same sense organ. For the light of the sun is the manifestor only of pots, etc., not of the stars.

analyzed: nimba tvac candana gandhasya eva abhivyañjikā na gandha antarāṇām
translated: The bark of the neem tree only manifests the smell of sandalwood, not other smells.

analyzed: tasmāt adoṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no fault.

original: na ca śabdasaṃskāre sarvapuṃsāmupalabdiprasaṅgaḥ dhvanīnāṃ prādeśikatvāttaddeśe śabdaḥ saṃskriyate na sarvatra /
analyzed: na ca śabda saṃskāre sarva puṃsām upalabdi prasaṅgaḥ dhvanīnām prādeśika tvāt tad deśe śabdaḥ saṃskriyate na sarvatra
translated: And there is no possibility of everyone perceiving the modification of sound, because the sounds are localized. The sound is modified in that place, not everywhere.

original: ataḥ saṃskṛtena śabdena yasyendriyaṃ saṃnikṛṣṭaṃ sa eva śṛṇoti nānya ityupapannam //
analyzed: atas saṃskṛtena śabdena yasya indriyam saṃnikṛṣṭam saḥ eva śṛṇoti na anyaḥ iti upapannam
translated: Therefore, it is reasonable that only the person whose sense organ is in close proximity to the modified sound hears it, not others.

analyzed: śabdasya aneka deśa upalambhaḥ
translated: The perception of sound in multiple locations.

analyzed: yugapad deśa bhedaḥ ca syāt ekasya sūrya vat
translated: And there would be simultaneous perception in different places, like the sun.

original: ye vindhyanilayā ye ca kāmarūpe vyavasthitāḥ //
analyzed: ye vindhya nilayāḥ ye ca kāmarūpe vyavasthitāḥ
translated: Those who reside in the Vindhya region and those who are situated in Kāmarūpa,

original: prāgbhāge hyātmanaḥ sarvairudyanbhāsvānnirīkṣyate //🔽pratyagbhāve tathāstaṃ yanmadhyāhne copari sthitaḥ //
analyzed: prāgbhāge hi ātmanaḥ sarvaiḥ udyan bhāsvān nirīkṣyate  pratyagbhāve tathā astam yat madhyāhne ca upari sthitaḥ
translated: all of them see the rising sun in the eastern direction of themselves.🔽And in the western direction, when it sets, and at midday, when it is overhead,

analyzed: bhinnāḥ ca teṣām prāgbhāgāḥ tathā pratyak tathā upari
translated: their eastern directions are different, as are their western and upper directions.

analyzed: teṣu asya dṛśyamānasya vispaṣṭā bhinna deśa tā
translated: For one who is seen in those [directions], the difference in location is clearly evident.

original: tathā yasminyāvaddūre deśe kaiścitsūryodayo dṛśyate taddeśavartino 'nyepi tataḥ parastāttāvati paśyanti tato 'pyasti bhedābhedaḥ /
analyzed: tathā yasmin yāvat dūre deśe kaiścid sūrya udayaḥ dṛśyate tad deśa vartinaḥ nye pi tatas parastāt tāvati paśyanti tatas u pi asti bheda abhedaḥ
translated: Similarly, in whatever distant place the rising of the sun is seen by some, others residing in that country see it beyond that, so there is difference and non-difference.

analyzed: na ca sūrya nānātvam āśaṅkanīyam
translated: And the plurality of the sun should not be suspected.

analyzed: na hi kecid bhinnam sūryam paśyanti
translated: For no one sees a different sun.

analyzed: ki punar eka deśa sthasya eva savituḥ nānā deśa upalambhe kāraṇam
translated: What then is the cause of the perception of the sun in different places while remaining in one place?

original: ucyate atidūravartino 'sya yathāvaddeśamajānantaḥ svasaṃnidhimadhyasyanto deśabhedaṃ manyante /
analyzed: ucyate yathāvat deśam a jānantaḥ sva saṃnidhim adhyasyantaḥ deśa bhedam manyante
translated: It is said: Those who are very far away, not knowing the place as it is, superimposing their proximity, think there is a difference of place.

analyzed: vispaṣṭam ca etat
translated: And this is clear.

original: tathāhi yo 'parāhne yasminyāvaddūre deśe sūryaṃ paśyati asminkṣetre 'sminparvate sūryaḥ iti /
analyzed: tathā hi parāhne yasmin yāvat dūre deśe sūryam paśyati asmin kṣetre smin parvate sūryaḥ iti
translated: For example, one who sees the sun in a distant place in the afternoon, in that field, on that mountain, the sun.

original: sa savitāramīkṣamāṇa eva taddeśe gatastataḥ parastāttathaiva taṃ paśyati tenāvagamyate sarveṣāṃ deśānāmagrataḥ sthito 'sau saṃnihitavadavabhāsata
analyzed: sa savitāram īkṣamāṇaḥ eva tad deśe gataḥ tatas parastāt tathā eva tam paśyati tena avagamyate sarveṣām deśānām agratas sthitaḥ u sau saṃnihita vat avabhāsata  /
translated: He, seeing the sun, having gone to that place, sees it in the same way beyond that. Therefore it is understood that he, standing in front of all places, appears as if present.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: ye cādityāpekṣayā stokadeśāḥ parvatāste 'pi dviyojanasthitānāṃ triyojanasthitānāṃ ca puruṣāṇāṃ tulyavadavabhāsante /
analyzed: ye ca āditya apekṣayā stoka deśāḥ parvatāḥ te dvi yojana sthitānām tri yojana sthitānām ca puruṣāṇām tulya vat avabhāsante
translated: And the mountains that are a small part in relation to the sun appear equally to people standing two yojanas away and three yojanas away.

analyzed: tasmāt eka tve pi saṃbhavati nānā deśa upalambhaḥ
translated: Therefore, even when there is oneness, the perception of different places is possible.

analyzed: tathā ekam eva mukham bhinneṣu ādarśeṣu yugapad dṛśyate
translated: Similarly, the same face is seen simultaneously in different mirrors.

original: nanu pratibimbaṃ nāmārthāntaraṃ tatra dṛśyate / na /
analyzed: nanu pratibimbam nāma artha antaram tatra dṛśyate na
translated: But isn't a reflection seen there as a separate object? No.

analyzed: tasya abhāvāt anupalambhāt ca
translated: Because it does not exist and is not perceived.

analyzed: na hi mūrta madhye mūrta antaram saṃbhavati
translated: For another material object cannot exist in the middle of a material object.

original: kiṃ ca śarāvasthamudakaṃ bhūmerupari nābhidadhne dhārayitvā tasyopariṣṭādaratridadhne svamukhaṃ kurvannudakasyādhastādaratrimātre mukhapratibimbaṃ
analyzed: kim ca śarāva stham udakam bhūmeḥ upari nābhi dadhne dhārayitvā tasya upariṣṭāt ara tri dadhne sva mukham kurvan udakasya adhastāt ara tri mātre mukha pratibimbam
translated: Moreover, when water in a bowl is placed on the ground and a mirror is placed above it, one's face is seen in the water at a distance of three fingers' breadth below the mirror.

original: tasmiṃśca deśe pārśvasthāḥ puruṣā na kañcidapi paśyanti tena dṛśyādarśananirastaḥ pratibimbākhyor'tho na śakyo 'bhyupagantum /
analyzed: tasmin ca deśe pārśva sthāḥ puruṣāḥ na kañcid api paśyanti tena dṛśya adarśana nirastaḥ pratibimba ākhyaḥ arthaḥ na śakyaḥ abhyupagantum
translated: And people standing on the side do not see anything at that place. Therefore, an object called reflection, which is excluded by the non-perception of what is visible, cannot be accepted.

original: tasmādādarśatejasā jalena ca pratihataṃ nāyanaṃ tejaḥ parāvṛttyā gṛhṇātīti yuktam /
analyzed: tasmāt ādarśa tejasā jalena ca pratihatam na ayanam tejaḥ parāvṛttyā gṛhṇāti iti yuktam
translated: Therefore, it is reasonable that the eye-element, being reflected by the light of the mirror and the water, perceives by turning back.

original: tasmādanaikāntiko nānādeśopalambho na nānātvaṃ śabdasya sādhayati ////
analyzed: tasmāt anaikāntikaḥ nānā deśa upalambhaḥ na nānātvam śabdasya sādhayati
translated: Therefore, the perception of a sound in different places is not conclusive, and does not prove that a sound is manifold.

original: nanu savituḥ sāṃnidhyādhyāsādyuktā nānādeśāvagatiḥ śabde tu katham /
analyzed: nanu savituḥ sāṃnidhya adhyāsa ādi uktā nānā deśa avagatiḥ śabde tu katham
translated: But the perception of the sun in different places is due to the superimposition of its proximity. How is it so in the case of a sound?

original: sarvagatatvāt sarvagato hi śabdo bhinnadeśairdhvanibhiḥ svesve deśe 'bhivyajyamāno bhinnadeśo 'vabhāsate /
analyzed: sarva gata tvāt sarva gataḥ hi śabdaḥ bhinna deśaiḥ dhvanibhiḥ sve sve deśe bhivyajyamānaḥ bhinna deśaḥ vabhāsate
translated: Because a sound is all-pervading, it appears in different places, being manifested in different places by different articulations.

original: dhvanayo hi śrotradeśamāgatyāpi śabdaṃ vyañjayantaḥ svotpattidesamiva śabdaṃ bhāsayantīti darśanabalādabhyupagamyate ////
analyzed: dhvanayaḥ hi śrotra deśam āgatya api śabdam vyañjayantaḥ śabdam bhāsayanti iti darśana balāt abhyupagamyate
translated: For it is accepted on the basis of the evidence of perception that even when the articulations reach the place of the ear, they manifest the sound as if it were in the place of their own origin.

original: nanu prāpyakāri śrotraṃ /🔽na ca dhvanyutpattideśaḥ śrotreṇa prāpyata iti kathaṃ tasya śrotreṇa grahaṇam /
analyzed: nanu prāpya kāri śrotram  na ca dhvani utpatti deśaḥ śrotreṇa prāpyate iti katham tasya śrotreṇa grahaṇam
translated: But the ear operates by coming into contact with the object.🔽And the place of origin of the articulation is not reached by the ear. How then is it apprehended by the ear?

analyzed: tad agrahe ca katham tad viśiṣṭa śabda grahaḥ
translated: And if it is not apprehended, how can there be the apprehension of the sound qualified by it?

analyzed: ucyate na ayam śrotrataḥ tad viśiṣṭa śabda pratyayaḥ
translated: It is said: This cognition of sound qualified by that (place) is not from the ear.

original: kiṃ tu śrotraṃ gi svadeśasthitaṃ śabdaṃ bodhayadapi na deśaviśiṣṭaṃ bodhayati kintu svarūpamātreṇa /
analyzed: kim tu śrotram gi sva deśa sthitam śabdam bodhayat api na deśa viśiṣṭam bodhayati kintu sva rūpa mātreṇa
translated: Rather, even when the ear, situated in its own place, produces the cognition of sound, it does not produce the cognition of sound qualified by place, but only by its own nature.

original: yatastu diśa āgatā dhvanayastayā viśiṣṭaṃ śabdaṃ bodayanti /
analyzed: yatas tu diśaḥ āgatāḥ dhvanayaḥ tayā viśiṣṭam śabdam bodayanti
translated: But since sounds come from all directions, they indicate a sound that is qualified by that direction.

original: sā hi dik śrotraprāptā śakyate śrotreṇa grahītum /
analyzed: sā hi diś śrotra prāptā śakyate śrotreṇa grahītum
translated: That direction, which is reached by the ear, can be grasped by the ear.

original: yadyapi na svātantryeṇa diśaḥ śrotragrāhyatvaṃ tathāpi rāve gṛhyamāṇe tadviśeṣaṇatayā atha ca viṣayeṣu sveṣu gṛhyamāṇeṣu tadviśeṣaṇatayā sarvairapīndriyairgṛhyate
analyzed: yadi api na svātantryeṇa diśaḥ śrotra grāhya tvam tathā api rāve gṛhyamāṇe tad viśeṣaṇa tayā atha ca viṣayeṣu sveṣu gṛhyamāṇeṣu tad viśeṣaṇa tayā sarvaiḥ api indriyaiḥ gṛhyate  /
translated: Even though the directions are not to be grasped by the ear independently, still when the sound is being grasped, they are grasped by all the senses as qualifications of their own objects, just as the color of the directions is grasped when the color is being grasped.

analyzed: tadvat
translated: In the same way.

original: tataścāsyāṃ diśi śabda iti viśiṣṭagrahaṇaṃ tāvatsiddham /
analyzed: tatas ca asyām diśi śabdaḥ iti viśiṣṭa grahaṇam tāvat siddham
translated: And so the grasping of a qualified sound, in the direction such and such, is established.
